text: I did hope that the TPP, negotiated by this administration, would put to rest a lot of the concerns that many people have expressed about trade agreements.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I said that I was holding out that hope that it would be the kind of trade agreement that I was looking for.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I waited until it had actually been negotiated because I did want to give the benefit of the doubt to the administration.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Once I saw what the outcome was, I opposed it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now I have a very clear view about this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to trade with the rest of the world.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are 5 percent of the world's population.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to trade with the other 95 percent.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And trade has to be reciprocal.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's the way the global economy works.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we have failed to provide the basic safety net support that American workers need in order to be able to compete and win in the global economy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So it's not just what's in the trade agreement that I'm interested in.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I did help to renegotiate the trade agreement that we inherited from President Bush with Korea.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We go the UAW on board because of changes we made.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So there are changes that I believe would make a real difference if they could be achieved, but I do not currently support it as it is written.

speaker: TODD
text: Well, Senator Sanders, I know you want to respond on this, you have never supported a trade deal since you've been in Congress.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Absolutely right.

speaker: TODD
text: But if you do that as president...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: If you do that as president, how are you not essentially letting China, who will do all of these deals around the world, how are you going to prevent China from essentially setting the rules of trade for the world?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Chuck, I believe in trade, but I do not believe in unfettered free trade.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I believe in fair trade which works for the middle class and working families of this country and not just large multinational corporations.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I was not only in opposition to NAFTA -- and this is an area where the secretary and I have disagreements.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I was not only in opposition to NAFTA, I was on the picket line in opposition to NAFTA because I understood -- I don't think this is really rocket science.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We heard all of the people tell us how many great jobs would be created.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I didn't believe that for a second because I understood what the function of NAFTA, CAFTA, PNTR with China, and the TPP is, it's to say to American workers, hey, you are now competing against people in Vietnam who make 56 cents an hour minimum wage.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I don't want American workers to compete against people making 56 cents an hour.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I don't want companies shutting down in America, throwing people out on the street, moving to China, and bringing their products back into this country.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So, do I believe in trade?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Of course, I believe in trade.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But the current trade agreements over the last 30 years were written by corporate America, for corporate America, resulted in the loss of millions of decent-paying jobs, 60,000 factories in America lost since 2001, millions of decent-paying jobs; and also a downward spiral, a race to the bottom where employers say, "Hey, you don't want to take a cut in pay? We're going to China."

speaker: SANDERS
text: Workers today are working longer hours for lower wages.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Trade is one of the reasons for that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: All right.

speaker: TODD
text: Thank you both.

speaker: TODD
text: We're going to sneak in one more break here, and when we come back we'll squeeze as many questions as we can before we end this thing.

speaker: TODD
text: We'll be right back.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: All right.

speaker: TODD
text: Welcome back here in the final minutes.

speaker: MADDOW
text: The home stretch.

speaker: TODD
text: The home stretch of this only Democratic debate in the final week before the primary.

speaker: TODD
text: Let me start with you, Secretary Clinton, on this question.

speaker: TODD
text: Obviously, President Obama got a lot of ambitious stuff done in his first year and a half.

speaker: TODD
text: You're going to have to make choices.

speaker: TODD
text: And there's a lot of heavy lifts.

speaker: TODD
text: And he made choices.

speaker: TODD
text: He did healthcare and it came at the expense, arguably, of immigration reform.

speaker: TODD
text: Had he put immigration reform first, perhaps that gets done and healthcare doesn't.

speaker: TODD
text: So there are three big lifts that you've talked about: immigration, gun reform, climate change.

speaker: TODD
text: What do you do first?

speaker: TODD
text: Because you know the first one is the one you have the best shot at getting done.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I -- I don't accept that premise, Chuck.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think that we've got so much business we have to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've talked a lot tonight about what we're against -- we're against income inequality.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're against the abuses of powerful interests.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're against a lot of things.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm for a lot of things.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't want to just stop bad things from happening, I want to start good things from happening.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I believe, if I'm so fortunate to get the nomination, I will begin to work immediately on putting together an agenda, beginning to talk with members of Congress and others about how we can push forward.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to have half a billion more solar panels deployed, the first four years.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to have enough clean energy to power every home the next four years.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want us to keep working on the Affordable Care Act, to get not only to 100 percent coverage, but bring down the costs of prescription drugs and out-of-pocket costs.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to move forward on paid family leave, on early childhood education, I want us to do more for small businesses.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Small businesses have to create most of the jobs, and we're not creating and growing small businesses.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think, if you have a smart agenda, you pick the committees that you know have to begin to work on these various pieces -- because that's the way Congress is set up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You go through different committees, and you really make a big push in the beginning.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Immigration reform, economic revitalization with manufacturing, with infrastructure -- we put it out there, and we begin to work on an ambitious, big, bold agenda that will actually produce the results that I want to see for our country.

speaker: TODD
text: All right, but Senator Sanders...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: ... you've still got to do something first.

speaker: TODD
text: As you know, history said -- shows what you pick first is your best shot at getting, and how you prioritize things.

speaker: SANDERS
text: No, let...

speaker: TODD
text: Immigration reform, for instance, fell by the wayside in the first term because of this.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I am absolutely supportive of comprehensive immigration reform and a path towards citizenship for 11 million people today who are living in the shadows.

speaker: SANDERS
text: All right?

speaker: SANDERS
text: We got to do that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: But you miss -- when you looked at the issues, you missed two of the most important.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And that is you're not going to accomplish what has to be done for working families and the middle class unless there is campaign finance reform.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: So long as big money interests control the United States Congress, it is gonna be very hard to do what has to be done for working families.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So let me be very clear.

speaker: SANDERS
text: No nominee of mine, if I'm elected president, to the United States Supreme Court will get that nomination unless he or she is loud and clear, and says they will vote to overturn Citizens United.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Second point -- second point is that the only way we make change in terms of health care, in terms of dealing with a broken criminal justice system which, today, allows us to have more people in jail than any other country -- largely African-American and Latino -- the only way we create millions of jobs by rebuilding our infrastructure or have a tax system that says to the wealthy that they are going to pay their fair share, is when millions of people become involved in the political process.

speaker: SANDERS
text: No, you just can't negotiate with Mitch McConnell.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Mitch is gonna have to look out the window and see a whole lot of people saying, "Mitch, stop representing the billionaire class. Start listening to working families."

speaker: SANDERS
text: And as president, that's what I will work hard on.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: OK.

speaker: TODD
text: Thank you.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Secretary Clinton, Republicans, particularly in campaign years, often talk about which departments of government -- which agencies of government they would get rid of if they were elected president.

speaker: MADDOW
text: The EPA, the Department of Education, the Commerce Department, oops -- is -- is there a department of government that you would get rid of?

speaker: MADDOW
text: Or is there a whole new one that you would create?

speaker: CLINTON
text: The answer to both of those is no.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm interested in making what we have work better.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to streamline programs that are duplicative and redundant.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to have a top-to-bottom review about what works and what doesn't work, and be absolutely clear we're getting rid of what doesn't work.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have had the opportunity to run a big agency.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I was very flattered when Henry Kissinger said I ran the State Department better -- better than anybody had run it in a long time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I have an idea of what it's going to take to make our government work more efficiently.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And when you put together a budget, you have to make a lot of hard decisions, but I think it's not appropriate to say "I'm going to get rid of this, get rid of that" until you have a very good process that gives you the information about what to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I want to add something else, you know, because look, we have so much work to do in our country, and I think it's the greatest work that Americans will be called to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And of course, we have to have people in every community involved in it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to have the political voice, the political grassroots speaking up and speaking out about what we have to try to accomplish in Washington.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we also need to have a very clear set of goals that we are going to achieve, and we need to level with the American people about what they are, what they will cost, what will be expected of our citizenry.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I see as president having a constant dialogue with Americans here's what we're trying to get done, here's why I need your help, here's why you may think comprehensive immigration reform with a path to citizenship isn't something you care about, but I'm telling you it will help fix the labor market, it will bring people out of the shadows --

speaker: MADDOW
text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: -- it will actually raise wages.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You have to make all those connections so that you've got people with you every step of the way.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's what I want to do.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Thank you very much.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: All right, before we go, I want to ask each one of these.

speaker: TODD
text: Secretary Clinton, you've made it clear when you look at Senator Sanders, you do not see a president, but do you see --

speaker: CLINTON
text: I never said that.

speaker: TODD
text: But do you see -- do you see a vice president?

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look --

speaker: TODD
text: Would you unite the party by trying to pick Senator Sanders as your running mate?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I'm certainly going to unite the party, but I'm not -- I'm not getting ahead of myself.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think that would be a little bit presumptuous.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If I'm so fortunate as to be the nominee, the first person I will call to talk to about where we go and how we get it done will be Senator Sanders.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: Senator, would you consider the secretary?

speaker: SANDERS
text: I agree with what the secretary said.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We shouldn't be getting ahead of ourselves.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And as I have said many times, you know, sometimes in these campaigns, things get a little bit out of hand.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I happen to respect the secretary very much, I hope it's mutual.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And on our worst days, I think it is fair to say we are 100 times better than any Republican candidate.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's true.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's true.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TODD
text: Secretary Clinton, closing statements.

speaker: TODD
text: You are first.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well first, thanks to MSNBC and thanks to all of you for holding this debate before the New Hampshire primary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I am going to campaign as hard as I can between now and Tuesday to earn your votes in that primary, and I hear some talk that people are trying to decide do they vote with their heart, do they vote with their head, I'm asking you to bring both your heart and your head to vote with you on Tuesday because we have a lot of work that can only come because your heart is moved.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, we didn't get to talk about the continuing struggles that Americans face with racism, with sexism, with discrimination against the LGBT community, with new Americans, with people with disabilities.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, we have income inequality, we have other forms of inequality that we need to stand up against and absolutely diminish from our society.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I have been moved by my heart ever since I was a young woman about the age of a lot of Senator Sanders' supporters worrying what I can do to make a difference for my country, and I will bring that heart with me, but I will also tell you we've got to get our heads together to come up with the best answers to solve the problems so that people can have real differences in their lives that will make them better for now and into the future.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: Thank you, Madam Secretary.

speaker: TODD
text: Senator Sanders.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I -- my dad came to this country at the age of 17 from Poland.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Didn't have any money, couldn't speak English, he died pretty young, and I think it would have been beyond his wildest dreams to see his son up here on this stage today running for president.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I love this country and my dad loved this country, and he was the most proud American because of what it gave him in terms of raising his family, even though we never had much money.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But today in America, we are the only major country on earth that doesn't guarantee health care to all people, that doesn't guarantee paid family and medical leave.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We have the highest rate of childhood poverty of almost any major country on earth.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We are seeing millions of families unable to send their kids to college in the United States of America.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I'm running for president because I believe it is just too late for establishment politics and establishment economics.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I do believe we need a political revolution where millions of people stand up and say loudly and clearly that our government belongs to all of us and not just a handful of wealthy campaign contributors.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Thank you all.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: Well, there you have it.

speaker: TODD
text: I promise you, Rachel and I have a lot more questions, but we just don't have any more time, unless we could (inaudible) a third hour, but I don't think so.

speaker: TODD
text: Our debate coverage -- (inaudible) debate coverage will continue in just a moment with our colleague (inaudible).

speaker: TODD
text: And we want to thank all of you for being here, and we want to thank the two candidates for taking part in this important event.

speaker: MADDOW
text: We also want to thank our host, the University of New Hampshire, and the people of New Hampshire.

speaker: MADDOW
text: You guys get to vote in just five days.

speaker: MADDOW
text: I can't wait to see how it turns out.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Don't screw up.

speaker: TODD
text: We'll see you in a few minutes.

speaker: TODD
text: Thank you.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: It's time for the candidates to introduce themselves right now.

speaker: BLITZER
text: You'll each have 30 seconds.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Dr. Carson, you're first.

speaker: CARSON
text: If someone had tried to describe today's America to you 30 years ago, you would have listened in disbelief.

speaker: CARSON
text: Americans know that our nation is heading off the abyss of destruction, secondary to divisiveness, fiscal irresponsibility, and failure to lead.

speaker: CARSON
text: Marco, Donald, Ted, John, we will not solve any of these problems by trying to destroy each other.

speaker: CARSON
text: What we need to do is be looking for solutions tonight.

speaker: CARSON
text: It's not about us, it's about the American people.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Governor Kasich?

speaker: KASICH
text: Well, you know, on the way over here, even getting ready earlier and sitting in the green room and watching the early coverage, you know, my father carried mail on his back and his father was a coal miner and my mother's mother was an immigrant, could barely speak English.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I'm standing on this stage.

speaker: KASICH
text: It's pretty remarkable.

speaker: KASICH
text: But I want to tell you, there's a lot of young people watching tonight.

speaker: KASICH
text: You can do whatever you want to do in your life.

speaker: KASICH
text: America is an amazing country, where a kid like me can grow up to run for president of the United States and be on this stage tonight.

speaker: KASICH
text: So to all the young people that are out there, your hopes, your dreams, pursue them.

speaker: KASICH
text: Shoot for the stars.

speaker: KASICH
text: America's great, and you can do it.

speaker: KASICH
text: Thank you, Wolf.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator Rubio?

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well, thank you.

speaker: RUBIO
text: This election, we have to decide the identity of America in the 21st century, but as part of this primary, we have to find out our identity as a party and as a movement.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Thirty-six years ago, Ronald Reagan and George H.W.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Bush began the Reagan Revolution.

speaker: RUBIO
text: For a generation, they defined conservatism as limited government and free enterprise and a strong national defense.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But they also appealed to our hopes and our dreams.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Now we have to decide if we are still that kind of party and still that kind of movement, or if we're simply going to become a party that preys on people's angers and fears.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I hope we remain that conservative movement that appeals to our hopes and our dreams and the belief that America will always be better in its future than it's been in its story history.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator Cruz?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Welcome to Texas.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CRUZ
text: Here, Texas provided my family with hope.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Here, my mom became the first in her family ever to go to college.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Here, my dad fled Cuba and washed dishes, making 50 cents an hour to pay his way through the University of Texas.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I graduated from high school at Second Baptist not too far away from here.

speaker: CRUZ
text: When I ran for Senate, I promised 27 million Texans I would fight for you every day, and not for the Washington bosses.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And, I'll tell you, as I travel the state, Democrats tell me I didn't vote for you, but you're doing what you said you would do.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And, as president, I will do the same.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Mr. Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Thank you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: My whole theme is make America great again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We don't win anymore as a country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We don't win with trade, we don't win with the military.

speaker: TRUMP
text: ISIS, we can't even knock out ISIS, and we will, believe me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We will.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We don't win in any capacity with healthcare.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have terrible health care, Obamacare is going to be repealed and replaced.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We just don't win.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You look at our borders, they're like swiss cheese, everybody pours in.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to make a great country again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to start winning again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to win a lot, it's going to be a big difference, believe me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's going to be a big difference.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you very much.

speaker: BLITZER
text: It's now time to begin questions.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Voters in the first four states have spoken, and Mr. Trump has emerged as the frontrunner, but in five days the candidates will face their biggest test yet, Super Tuesday.

speaker: BLITZER
text: When nearly half of the delegates needed to win the Republican nomination will be awarded, and the biggest prize of the night is Texas.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Immigration is a key issue in this state, for all voters nationwide, including the many people watching us on Telemundo.

speaker: BLITZER
text: So, that's where we begin.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Mr. Trump, you've called for a deportation force to remove the 11 million undocumented immigrants from the United States.

speaker: BLITZER
text: You've also promised to let what you call, "the good ones", come back in.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Your words, "the good ones", after they've been deported.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator Cruz would not allow them to come back in.

speaker: BLITZER
text: He says that's the biggest difference between the two of you.

speaker: BLITZER
text: He calls your plan amnesty.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Is it?

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, he was in charge of amnesty, he was the leader, and you can ask Marco because they've been debating this every debate that we've had.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As far as coming back in, number one, you wouldn't even be talking, and you wouldn't have asked that as the first question if it weren't for me when my opening when I talked about illegals immigration.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It wouldn't even be a big subject.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But, we either have a country, or we don't have a country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have at least 11 million people in this country that came in illegally.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They will go out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They will come back -- some will come back, the best, through a process.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They have to come back legally.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They have to come back through a process, and it may not be a very quick process, but I think that's very fair, and very fine.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're going to get in line with other people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The best of them will come back, but they're going to come back through a process.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator Cruz, what's wrong with letting what Mr. Trump calls, "the good ones" come back to the United States?

speaker: CRUZ
text: You know, the people that get forgotten in this debate over immigration are the hardworking men and women of this country -- our millions of Americans who are losing their jobs.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Millions of legal immigrants who are losing their jobs are seeing their wages driven down.

speaker: CRUZ
text: You know, in the past couple of weeks the Wall Street Journal had a very interesting article about the state of Arizona.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Arizona put in very tough laws on illegal immigration, and the result was illegal immigrants fled the state, and what's happened there -- it was a very interesting article.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Some of the business owners complained that the wages they had to pay workers went up, and from their perspective that was a bad thing.

speaker: CRUZ
text: But, what the state of Arizona has seen is the dollars they're spending on welfare, on prisons, and education, all of those have dropped by hundreds of millions of dollars.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And, the Americans, and for that matter, the legal immigrants who are in Arizona, are seeing unemployment drop are seeing wages rise.

speaker: CRUZ
text: That's who we need to be fighting for.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Listen, we have always welcomed legal immigrants, but I think it is a mistake to forgive those who break the law to allow them to become U.S. citizens, and that's why I've led the fight against granting citizenship to those here illegally, and that's why I will do the same thing as president.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CRUZ
text: Mr. Trump, do you want to respond to that?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I'm very glad that Ted mentioned Arizona because probably the toughest man on borders is Sheriff Joe Arpaio, and two days ago he totally endorsed me, so, thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator Rubio?

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator Cruz has called your immigration plan amnesty, and has an add out there comparing it to President Obama's.

speaker: BLITZER
text: He says both of you support allowing undocumented immigrants legal status here in the United States after a background check, paying a fine, and paying taxes.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Are those claims correct?

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well, first of all, and before we do anything, I've been abundantly clear on this.

speaker: RUBIO
text: When I'm president of the United States, before we do anything on immigration, we are going to secure the border.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And, that's not just the physical border with Mexico, it's Visa overstays.

speaker: RUBIO
text: That's 45 percent of the problem right there.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It also has to do -- that's why we need e-verify, and entry-exit tracking system, and so-forth.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And, until that happens, we're not doing anything else.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And then we'll see what the American people are willing to support.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And Donald mentioned, because he mentioned me in his answer, that his position on immigration is what has driven this debate.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well, the truth is, though, that a lot of these positions that he's now taking are new to him.

speaker: RUBIO
text: In 2011, he talked about the need for a pathway to citizenship.

speaker: RUBIO
text: In 2012, Donald criticized Mitt Romney, saying that Mitt lost his election because of self-deportation.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And so even today, we saw a report in one of the newspapers that Donald, you've hired a significant number of people from other countries to take jobs that Americans could have filled.

speaker: RUBIO
text: My mom and dad -- my mom was a maid at a hotel, and instead of hiring an American like her, you have brought in over a thousand people from all over the world to fill those jobs instead.

speaker: RUBIO
text: So I think this is an important issue.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And I think we are realizing increasingly that it's an important issue for the country that has been debated for 30 years, but finally needs to be solved once and for all.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Mr. Trump?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, first of all, self-deportation is people are going to leave as soon as they see others going out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If you look at Dwight Eisenhower in the 1950s, they started moving people out and the rest of them left.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Self-deportation, as I really define it, and that's the way I define it, is you're going to get some to go, and the rest are going to go out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As far as the people that I've hired in various parts of Florida during the absolute prime season, like Palm Beach and other locations, you could not get help.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's the up season.

speaker: TRUMP
text: People didn't want to have part-time jobs.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There were part-time jobs, very seasonal, 90-day jobs, 120-day jobs, and you couldn't get.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Everybody agrees with me on that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They were part-time jobs.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You needed them, or we just might as well close the doors, because you couldn't get help in those hot, hot sections of Florida.

speaker: RUBIO
text: That -- my point that I made was you had criticized Mitt Romney for self-deportation.

speaker: RUBIO
text: You said that his strategy of self- deportation is why he lost the election.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And I think people in Florida would be surprised, because, in fact, the article that was today, they interviewed a number of people that would have been willing to do those jobs, if you would have been willing to hire them to do it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I criticized Mitt Romney for losing the election.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He should have won that election.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He had a failed president.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He ran a terrible campaign.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He was a terrible candidate.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's what I criticize Mitt Romney -- I mean, ran...

speaker: RUBIO
text: No, he...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He ran one terrible campaign.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's an election that should have been won.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well, in fact, I agree we should have won and I wished we would have, but, in fact, you did criticize him for using the term "self-deportation."

speaker: RUBIO
text: I mean, that's on the record and people can look it up right now online.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But, again, I just want to reiterate, I think it's really important, this point.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I think it's fine, it's an important point that you raise and we discuss on immigration.

speaker: RUBIO
text: This is a big issue for Texas, a huge issue for the country.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But I also think that if you're going to claim that you're the only one that lifted this into the campaign, that you acknowledge that, for example, you're only person on this stage that has ever been fined for hiring people to work on your projects illegally.

speaker: RUBIO
text: You hired some workers from Poland...

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, no, I'm the only one on the stage that's hired people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You haven't hired anybody.

speaker: SYSTEM

speaker: RUBIO
text: In fact, some of the people...

speaker: TRUMP
text: You've hired nobody.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Yes, you've hired a thousand from another country...

speaker: TRUMP
text: You've had nothing but problems with your credit cards, et cetera.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So don't tell me about that.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Let me just say -- let me finish the statement.

speaker: RUBIO
text: This is important.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You haven't hired one person, you liar.

speaker: RUBIO
text: He hired workers from Poland.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And he had to pay a million dollars or so in a judgment from...

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's wrong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's wrong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Totally wrong.

speaker: RUBIO
text: That's a fact.

speaker: RUBIO
text: People can look it up.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I'm sure people are Googling it right now.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Look it up.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Trump Polish workers, you'll see a million dollars for hiring illegal workers on one of his projects.

speaker: RUBIO
text: He did it.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RUBIO
text: That happened.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've hired tens of thousands of people over my lifetime.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Tens of thousands...

speaker: RUBIO
text: Many from other countries instead of hiring Americans.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Be quiet.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Just be quiet.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've hired tens of thousands of people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He brings up something from 30 years ago, it worked out very well.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Everybody was happy.

speaker: RUBIO
text: You paid a million dollars.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And by the way, the laws were totally different.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That was a whole different world.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I've hired people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody up here has hired anybody.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator Cruz, you say you want to deport the 11 million undocumented immigrants, but you never want to allow them to come back to the United States.

speaker: BLITZER
text: What would happen to the children who are U.S.- born citizens whose parent will be deported under your plan?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Well, existing law provides that those who are deported cannot come back here legally.

speaker: CRUZ
text: U.S. citizens can come back.

speaker: CRUZ
text: That's existing law.

speaker: CRUZ
text: But let me say, Wolf, I really find it amazing that Donald believes that he is the one who discovered the issue of illegal immigration.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I can tell you, when I ran for Senate here in the state of Texas, I ran promising to lead the fight against amnesty, promising to fight to build a wall.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And in 2013, when I was fight against the "gang of eight" amnesty bill, where was Donald?

speaker: CRUZ
text: He was firing Dennis Rodman on "Celebrity Apprentice."

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: CRUZ
text: And indeed, if you look at the "gang of eight," one individual on this stage broke his promise to the men and women who elected him and wrote the amnesty bill.

speaker: CRUZ
text: If you look at the eight members of the Gang of Eight, Donald gave over $50,000 to three Democrats and two Republicans.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And when you're funding open border politicians, you shouldn't be surprised when they fight for open borders.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And I think if you want to know who actually will secure the borders and follow through, you ought to ask who has a record before they were a candidate for president of fighting to secure the borders and stop amnesty.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And I'm the only one on this stage that has that record.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And by the way, Marco is exactly right that a federal court found Donald guilty of being part of a conspiracy to hire people illegally and entered a $1 million judgment against him.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Mr. Trump?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I can only say this, and I've said it loud and clear and I've said it for years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And many of these people are sitting right in the audience right now -- your lobbyist and your special interest and your donors, because the audience is packed with them, and they're packed with you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've had an amazing relationship with politicians -- with politicians both Democrat, Republican, because I was a businessman.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As one magazine said, he's a world-class businessman; he was friendly with everybody.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I got along with everybody.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You get along with nobody.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You don't have one Republican -- you don't have one Republican senator, and you work with them every day of your life, although you skipped a lot of time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: These are minor details.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you don't have one Republican senator backing you; not one.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You don't have the endorsement of one Republican senator and you work with these people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You should be ashamed of yourself.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator Cruz?

speaker: CRUZ
text: You know, I actually think Donald is right.

speaker: CRUZ
text: He is promising if he's elected he will go and cut deals in Washington.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And he's right.

speaker: CRUZ
text: He has supported -- he has given hundreds of thousands of dollars to Democrats.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Anyone who really cared about illegal immigration wouldn't be hiring illegal immigrants.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Anyone who really cared about illegal immigration wouldn't be funding Harry Reid and Nancy Pelosi; wouldn't be funding the Gang of Eight.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And, you know, he is right.

speaker: CRUZ
text: When you stand up to Washington, when you honor the promise you made to the men and women who elected you and say enough with the corruption, enough with the cronyism, let's actually stand for the working men and women of this country, Washington doesn't like it.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And Donald, if you want to be liked in Washington, that's not a good attribute for a president.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TRUMP
text: Here's a man -- Robin Hood.

speaker: TRUMP
text: This is Robin Hood over here.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He talks about corruption.

speaker: TRUMP
text: On his financial disclosure form, he didn't even put that he's borrowed money from Citibank and from Goldman Sachs, which is a total violation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He didn't talk about the fact that he pays almost no interest.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He just left it off, and now he's going to protect the people from the big bad banks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Give me a break.

speaker: BLITZER
text: All right.

speaker: BLITZER
text: We're going to move on to Governor Kasich.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Governor Kasich...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: CRUZ
text: Wolf, can I respond to that attack?

speaker: BLITZER
text: You can respond, but let me get Governor Kasich in.

speaker: BLITZER
text: He's been waiting patiently.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Governor Kasich, the idea -- you've said this, and I want to quote you now "The idea that we're going to deport all these people is ludicrous and everybody knows it."

speaker: BLITZER
text: Those are your words.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Should people be allowed to break the law just because it's not feasible to stop them?

speaker: KASICH
text: Look, we have a great president here, George Bush, the 41st president of the United States.

speaker: KASICH
text: He worked with Ronald Reagan to pass an effort to try to solve this problem -- a path to legalization.

speaker: KASICH
text: You see, that was a time when things worked.

speaker: KASICH
text: It was a time when President Reagan and George Bush decided that we needed to make the country work.

speaker: KASICH
text: Look, I think there is an answer here.

speaker: KASICH
text: The answer is you complete the border.

speaker: KASICH
text: You let people know that once it's done, you don't have a right to come in.

speaker: KASICH
text: If you come in, we don't want any excuse.

speaker: KASICH
text: You're going to go back.

speaker: KASICH
text: But I favor a guest worker program.

speaker: KASICH
text: I think it's practical.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I think for the 11 million or 11.5 million Americans -- the illegals that are here, if they have not committed a crime since they've been here, I'd make them pay a fine, some back taxes, maybe some community service.

speaker: KASICH
text: And at the end, I'd give them a path to legalization, but not a path to citizenship.

speaker: KASICH
text: I don't think we're going to tear families apart.

speaker: KASICH
text: I don't think we're going to ride around in people's neighborhoods and grab people out of their homes.

speaker: KASICH
text: I don't think -- first of all, I don't think it's practical and I don't think it reflects America.

speaker: KASICH
text: You know what happened?

speaker: KASICH
text: The problem with President Reagan is we didn't get in there and actually finish the border.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I think it was probably business interests that affected it.

speaker: KASICH
text: But at the end of the day, let's be practical.

speaker: KASICH
text: Let's start solving problems in this country instead of kicking them upstairs.

speaker: KASICH
text: With President Reagan and George Bush, it was a bipartisan coalition to address the issue, and I think we can and should do it again.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I will have a plan in the first 100 days to get it done and get this issue behind us.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Governor.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Dr. Carson, you've been critical of mass deportation.

speaker: BLITZER
text: You said back in November you don't think Mr. Trump's plan necessarily represents the Republican Party.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Given how well Mr. Trump has been doing with the Republican primary voters, do you still believe that?

speaker: CARSON
text: I believe in liberty and justice for all.

speaker: CARSON
text: I think everything that we do should be fair.

speaker: CARSON
text: And I've already described -- you know, how we can secure the border.

speaker: CARSON
text: We need to secure all the borders, because it's not just people coming in from South America and Mexico, but there are terrorists who want to destroy us, who are getting across our borders fairly easily.

speaker: CARSON
text: And we have to stop that.

speaker: CARSON
text: But in terms of the people who are here already, after we -- after we stop the illegal immigration, we need to be reasonable.

speaker: CARSON
text: And I would give them a six-month period in which to get registered as a guest worker, assuming that they have an acceptable record.

speaker: CARSON
text: They have to pay a back-tax penalty, have to pay taxes going forward, but they don't have to live underground anymore.

speaker: CARSON
text: And I think they do not become American citizens, they do not vote.

speaker: CARSON
text: If they want to become an American citizen, they go through exactly the same process that anybody else goes through.

speaker: CARSON
text: I think that's the kind of situation that is actually fair to people.

speaker: CARSON
text: And we have other ways of -- of utilizing our facilities and our talents as foreign aid doing things in South America and Central America and Mexico that improve the economy there, so that they don't feel the need to come over here.

speaker: CARSON
text: That would cost us a lot less than borrowing money from China, paying interest on it.

text: I won with every single category.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I won with men, I won with high-income, low-income, I won with Hispanics.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I got 46 percent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody else was close.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because they know I'm going to bring jobs back from China, from Japan, from so many other places.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They get it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're incredible people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're incredible workers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They get it.

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: TRUMP
text: But one thing I'm also going to do, I'm going to be getting -- bringing a lot of people in who are Democrats, who are independents, and you're seeing that with the polls, because if you look at anywhere, look at any of the elections, every single election, it has been record-setting.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And the good news is, for the Republican Party, the Democrats are getting very poor numbers in terms of bringing them in.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're getting record-setting numbers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think I have something to do with that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're getting record-setting numbers.

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: TRUMP
text: New people are coming into the Republican Party.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are building a new Republican Party, a lot of new people are coming in.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Mr. Trump, thank you.

speaker: BLITZER
text: I want to turn our attention now to another critically important issue for the American people, the United States Supreme Court, where filling the vacancy left by the late Justice Antonin Scalia has become a major campaign issue.

speaker: BLITZER
text: I want to bring in Salem Radio Network host, Hugh Hewitt.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Hugh?

speaker: HEWITT
text: Thank you, Wolf.

speaker: HEWITT
text: To me, it's the most important issue.

speaker: HEWITT
text: I'll start with you, Senator Cruz.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Do you trust Mr. Trump to nominate conservative justices?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Well, Hugh, I agree with you that it -- Justice Scalia's passing underscores the enormous gravity of this election.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Justice Scalia was someone I knew personally for 20 years; was privileged to be at his funeral this weekend.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And with his passing, the court is now hanging in the balance.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We are one liberal justice away from a five-justice radical leftist majority that would undermine our religious liberty; that would undermine the right to life; and that would fundamentally erase the Second Amendment right to keep and bear arms from the Constitution.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Now, I think the voters of Texas, the voters across Super Tuesday are assessing everyone standing on this -- this stage.

speaker: CRUZ
text: In the past, Republican presidents always promise to nominate strict constitutionalists.

speaker: CRUZ
text: So I'm certain if you took a survey, everyone would say they would do that.

speaker: CRUZ
text: But the reality is, Democrats bat about 1,000.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Just about everyone they put on the court votes exactly as they want.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Republicans have batted worse than 500, more than half of the people we put on the court have been a disaster.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I've spent my whole life fighting to defend the Bill of Rights and the Constitution. I can tell you, for voters that care about life or marriage or religious liberty or the Second Amendment, they're asking the question "Who do you know, beyond a shadow of a doubt, who do you know will nominate principled constitutionalists to the court?"

speaker: CRUZ
text: I give you my word, every justice I nominate will vigorously defend the Bill of Rights for my children and for yours.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HEWITT
text: Mr. Trump, Senator Cruz mentioned the issue that keeps me up at night, which is religious liberty.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Churches, Catholic and Christian colleges, Catholic adoption agencies -- all sorts of religious institutions fear that Hobby Lobby, if it's repealed, it was a five-four decision, they're going to have to bend their knee and provide morning-after pills.

speaker: HEWITT
text: They fear that if Bob Jones is expanded, they will lose their tax exemption.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Will you commit to voters tonight that religious liberty will be an absolute litmus test for anyone you appoint, not just to the Supreme Court, but to all courts?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Yes, I would.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I've been there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I've been there very strongly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I do have to say something, and this is interesting and it's not anybody's fault.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's not Ted's fault.

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: TRUMP
text: Justice Roberts gave us Obamacare.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Might as well be called Roberts-care.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Two times of the Supreme Court, Justice Roberts approved something that he should have never raised his hand to approve.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we ended up with Obamacare.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That is a rough thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I know Ted feels badly about it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think he probably still respects the judge.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But that judge has been a disaster in terms of everything we stand for because there is no way -- no way that he should have approved Obamacare.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, with that being said, these are the things that happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But Ted very, very strongly pushed Judge Roberts, and Justice Roberts gave us something that we don't want.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Ted Cruz, Senator, the chief justice got Hobby Lobby right, but what do you make of Mr. Cruz's criticism?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Well, listen -- Donald knows that it was George W. Bush who appointed John Roberts.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Yes, it's true, I supported the Republican nominee once he was made.

speaker: CRUZ
text: But I would not have nominated John Roberts.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I would have nominated my former boss, Mike Luttig, who was the strongest proven conservative on the court of appeals.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And I'll tell you, Hugh...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CRUZ
text: ... you know, it's interesting now that Donald promises that he will appoint justices who -- who will defend religious liberty, but this is a man who, for 40 years, has given money to Jimmy Carter, to Joe Biden, to Hillary Clinton, to Chuck Schumer, to Harry Reid.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Nobody who supports far-left liberal Democrats who are fighting for judicial activists can possibly care about having principled constitutionalists on the court.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And what Donald has told us is he will go to Washington...

speaker: CRUZ

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well, I think you ask a very important question, because the issue here -- the next president of the United States has to fill this vacancy.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Justice Scalia -- in the history of the republic, there has never been anyone better than him at standing for the principle that the Constitution is not a living and breathing document -- it is supposed to be applied as originally meant.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And the next president of the United States has to be someone that you can trust and believe in to appoint someone just as good as Scalia -- plus there may be at least two other vacancies.

speaker: RUBIO
text: So you ask Mr. Trump to respond and say that he would, and he says that he would.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But the bottom line is, if you look at his record over the last 25 or 30 years, on issue after issue, he has not been on our side.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Now, if he's changed, we're always looking for converts into the conservative movement.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But the bottom line is that, if (ph) you don't have a record there to look at and say, "I feel at peace that when Donald Trump is president of the United States, he's going to be firmly on our side on these issues."

speaker: RUBIO

speaker: RUBIO

speaker: RUBIO

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH

speaker: HEWITT

speaker: CARSON
text: I first met him when we got an honorary degree together a long time ago.

speaker: CARSON
text: A tremendous wit and intellect.

speaker: CARSON
text: As far as religious freedom is concerned, one of the basic tenets of this nation, and I believe that the Constitution protects all of our rights.

speaker: CARSON
text: And it gives people who believe in same-sex marriage the same rights as everybody else.

speaker: CARSON
text: But what we have to remember is even though everybody has the same rights, nobody get extra rights.

speaker: CARSON
text: So nobody gets to redefine things for everybody else and then have them have to conform to it.

speaker: CARSON

speaker: CARSON

speaker: CARSON
text: That's why we have divided government.

speaker: CARSON

speaker: CARSON
text: And as president, I would go through and I would look at what a person's life has been.

speaker: CARSON

speaker: CARSON

speaker: CARSON

speaker: CARSON

speaker: CARSON

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Dr. Carson.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: All of you want to repeal and replace Obamacare, so let's talk about your plans, specific plans to replace it.

speaker: BLITZER
text: I want to bring in our chief political correspondent, Dana Bash.

speaker: BASH
text: Senator Rubio, you said yesterday, right here in Houston, that Mr. Trump thinks part of Obamacare is pretty good.

speaker: BASH
text: So, he says he is going to repeal Obamacare.

speaker: BASH
text: Are you saying that you're worried he won't?

speaker: RUBIO
text: The individual mandate.

speaker: RUBIO
text: He said he likes the individual mandate portion of it, which I don't believe that should be part of it.

speaker: RUBIO
text: That should not remain there.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I think here's what we need to replace it with.

speaker: RUBIO
text: We need to repeal Obamacare completely and replace it with a system that puts Americans in charge of their health care money again.

speaker: RUBIO
text: If your employer wants to buy health insurance for you, they can continue to do so from any company in America they want to buy it from.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Otherwise, your employers can provide you health care money, tax- free, not treated as income, and you can use that money only for health care, but you can use it to fund health care any way you want, fully fund a health savings account, the combination of a health savings account or a private plan from any company in any state in the country.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And if you don't have that, then you will have a refundable tax credit that provides you health care money to buy your own health care coverage.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And that, I think, is a much better approach than Obamacare, which, by the way, isn't just bad for health care, it's bad for our economy.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It is a health care law that is basically forcing companies to lay people off, cut people's hours, move people to part-time.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It is not just a bad health care law, it is a job-killing law.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And I will repeal it as president and we will replace it with something substantially better for all Americans.

text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BASH
text: Governor Kasich, you've said it is, quote, "Un American to deny someone health insurance if they have a preexisting condition."

speaker: BASH
text: Would you leave the individual mandate in place requiring all Americans to purchase insurance?

speaker: KASICH
text: No, I wouldn't.

speaker: KASICH
text: And -- but that doesn't matter when it comes to the issue of preexisting conditions.

speaker: KASICH
text: You don't want any American to lose their house, everything they've saved, because they get sick.

speaker: KASICH
text: Now, I think it is more complicated than what we've heard here tonight.

speaker: KASICH
text: We're actually running significant health reform in my state.

speaker: KASICH
text: I would repeal Obamacare for a variety of reasons.

speaker: KASICH
text: I would take some of the federal resources, combine it with the freed-up Medicaid program, which I would send back to the states, and cover the people who are currently the working poor because we don't want to have tens of millions of Americans losing their health insurance.

speaker: KASICH
text: And then we're driving towards total transparency.

speaker: KASICH
text: If any of you here ever get a hospital bill, it's easier to interpret the Dead Sea scrolls than to understand your hospital bill.

speaker: KASICH
text: The fact is what we need is transparency with hospitals and with the providers.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I'll tell you what we will do.

speaker: KASICH
text: We are actually going to make payments to physicians and to hospitals who actually deliver healthcare with great quality at low prices.

speaker: KASICH
text: We actually are going to make the market work.

speaker: BASH
text: Governor, let me just go back to the original question about the individual mandate.

speaker: BASH
text: In 1994 when you were in Congress, you proposed a plan requiring an individual mandate.

speaker: BASH
text: So what changed?

speaker: KASICH
text: Well, Dana, the Heritage Foundation had this position as well.

speaker: KASICH
text: And when I look at it, I don't think it's tenable.

speaker: KASICH
text: And we don't need to do that.

speaker: KASICH
text: Again, I'm telling you that we are going to -- we have a proposal, a plan that we're enacting now that says if you are a hospital or a doctor and you're providing very high quality at lower prices, below the midpoint -- some charge high, some charge low.

speaker: KASICH
text: If you are below the midpoint, we are going to give you a financial reward for allowing you to provide services that result in high quality for our people at lower pricess.

speaker: KASICH
text: That is the way in which we are going to damp down the rising costs of healthcare.

speaker: KASICH
text: Because if you think about your own deductibles today, they're going higher, higher and higher.

speaker: KASICH
text: And you know what?

speaker: KASICH
text: At some point, people can't afford it.

speaker: KASICH
text: Our plan will work.

speaker: KASICH
text: It uses the market.

speaker: KASICH
text: It uses transparency.

speaker: KASICH
text: It gets the patient in the middle.

speaker: KASICH
text: And guess what?

speaker: KASICH
text: We're actually doing it in my state, the seventh-largest state in the country.

speaker: KASICH
text: And if this will go -- this will go national, we will get our hands on healthcare where you will know what's going on.

speaker: KASICH
text: We will pay for quality, lower prices, and we will begin to see healthcare become affordable in America and where people will also be able to have health insurance, even if they have a preexisting condition.

speaker: KASICH
text: We don't want to throw millions of people out into the cold and not have the health insurance, Dana.

speaker: KASICH
text: So that's really what we're doing.

speaker: KASICH
text: This is not a theory.

speaker: KASICH
text: This is what we are actually doing in our state.

speaker: KASICH
text: We will begin payments next year based on episodes that we have in our lives.

speaker: KASICH
text: If our primary care physicians keep us healthy for a year, with really high quality, guess what?

speaker: KASICH
text: They will get a financial reward.

speaker: KASICH
text: Our primary care physicians need help.

speaker: KASICH
text: They need support.

speaker: KASICH
text: We're losing them.

speaker: KASICH
text: This will allow them to get a reward for doing a great job.

speaker: BASH
text: Governor Kasich, thank you.

speaker: KASICH
text: Thank you.

speaker: BASH
text: Dr. Carson, you have dealt with the sickest of patients.

speaker: BASH
text: You support covering preexisting conditions.

speaker: BASH
text: How would you change Obamacare, but maintain that coverage?

speaker: CARSON
text: Well, first of all, healthcare is not a right.

speaker: CARSON
text: But I do believe it is a responsibility for a responsible society, and we are that.

speaker: CARSON
text: We spend almost twice as much per capita on healthcare as many other nations who have actually much better access than we do.

speaker: CARSON
text: I propose a system in which we use health empowerment accounts, which are like a health savings account with no bureaucrats.

speaker: CARSON
text: And we give it to everybody from birth until death.

speaker: CARSON
text: They can pass it on when they die.

speaker: CARSON
text: We pay for it with the same dollars that we pay for traditional healthcare with.

speaker: CARSON
text: We give people the ability to shift money within their health empowerment account within their family.

speaker: CARSON
text: So dad's $500 short, mom can give it to him or a cousin or uncle.

speaker: CARSON
text: And it makes every family their own insurance carrier with no middle man.

speaker: CARSON
text: It gives you enormous flexibility.

speaker: CARSON
text: And also, you know, if Uncle Joe is smoking like a chimney, everybody's going to hide his cigarettes because they're all interested in what's going on there.

speaker: CARSON
text: Also, the -- your catastrophic healthcare is going to cost a lot less money now because the only thing coming out of that is catastrophic healthcare.

speaker: CARSON
text: So, it's like a homeowners policy with a large deductible, versus a homeowners policy where you want every scratch covered.

speaker: CARSON
text: One costs $1,500 a year; one costs $10,000 a year.

speaker: CARSON
text: You can buy the $1,500 one.

speaker: CARSON
text: That will take care of 75 percent of the people.

speaker: CARSON
text: The people who are indigent, how do we take care of them now?

speaker: CARSON
text: Medicaid.

speaker: CARSON
text: What's the Medicaid budget?

speaker: CARSON
text: Almost $500 billion; almost 80 million people participate, which is way too many, and that will get a lot better when we fix the economy, which I hope we get a chance to talk about.

speaker: CARSON
text: But do the math.

speaker: CARSON
text: Over $5,000 for each man, woman and child, and all -- they will have a lot more flexibility.

speaker: CARSON
text: What could you buy with that?

speaker: CARSON
text: A concierge practice.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you.

speaker: CARSON
text: And you could still have thousands of dollars left over.

speaker: CARSON
text: And let me just finish, because I don't get to talk that much.

speaker: CARSON
text: And, you know, let's...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CARSON

speaker: CARSON

speaker: CARSON
text: It will be such a good program that nobody will want Obamacare after that, and that's probably the best way do it, although if anybody still did, I would still de-fund it.

speaker: BLITZER

text: We had a balanced budget four years in a row, had to take on every interest group in Washington -- every single one of them -- and we paid down a half a trillion of the national debt.

text: Mr. Trump, yesterday, the last Republican presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, called on you to release your back tax returns, and said, and I'm quoting him now, "there is good reason to believe there is a bombshell in them."

speaker: BLITZER
text: Romney said either you're not as wealthy as you say you are, said maybe you haven't paid the kind of taxes we would expect you to pay, or you haven't been giving the money to veterans or disabled people.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Are any of those accusations that he has leveled true?

speaker: TRUMP
text: All right.

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, let me just explain.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was the first one to file a financial disclosure form -- almost 100 pages.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You don't learn anything about somebody's wealth with a tax return.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You learn it from statements.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I filed -- which shows that I'm worth over $10 billion.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I built a great company with very little debt.

speaker: TRUMP
text: People were shocked, the people in the back, the reporters, they were shocked when they went down.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I filed it on time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I didn't ask for five 45-day extensions, which I would have been entitled to.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So as far as that's concerned, I filed it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's where you find out what kind of a company.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You don't learn anything from a tax return.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will say this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Mitt Romney looked like a fool when he delayed and delayed and delayed.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Harry Reid baited him so beautifully.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Mitt Romney didn't file his return until a September 21st of 2012, about a month-and-a-half before the election.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it cost him big league.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As far as my return, I want to file it, except for many years, I've been audited every year.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Twelve years, or something like that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Every year they audit me, audit me, audit me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody gets audited -- I have friends that are very wealthy people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They never get audited.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I get audited every year.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will absolutely give my return, but I'm being audited now for two or three years, so I can't do it until the audit is finished, obviously.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think people would understand that.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Hugh, go ahead.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Mr. Trump.

speaker: HEWITT
text: You told me...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Are you going to ask anybody else that question?

speaker: CARSON
text: Yes, amen, amen.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: TRUMP
text: Every single question comes to me?

speaker: HEWITT
text: Mr. Trump...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TRUMP
text: I know I'm here for the ratings, but it's a little bit ridiculous.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: HEWITT
text: Mr. Trump, a year ago you told me on my radio show, the audio and the transcript are out there on YouTube, that you would release your tax returns.

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: HEWITT
text: Are you going back on your commitment?

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, I'm not.

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, very few people listen to your radio show.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's the good news.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me just tell you, let me just -- which happens to be true.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Check out the ratings.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, let me just tell you something.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me just tell you something.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I want to release my tax returns but I can't release it while I'm under an audit.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're under a routine audit.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've had it for years, I get audited.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And obviously if I'm being audited, I'm not going to release a return.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As soon as the audit is done, I love it.

speaker: HEWITT
text: So, Senator Rubio, Mitt Romney also called upon to you release your tax returns.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Your campaign said last spring that you would release your returns that you had not previously released.

speaker: HEWITT

speaker: RUBIO
text: Yes, tomorrow or Saturday, in fact, is our plan to release them.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And there's nothing really that interesting in them.

speaker: RUBIO
text: So I have no problem releasing them.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And luckily I'm not being audited this year, or last year, for that matter.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: RUBIO
text: But this is my time.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I want to go back to this question you asked about the debt.

speaker: RUBIO
text: This is an important issue.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It's a huge issue, OK?

speaker: RUBIO
text: In less than five years, 83 percent of our entire budget will be made up of Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, and the interest on the debt.

speaker: RUBIO
text: That means only 17 percent of our budget will be for things like the military or the Department of Education or environmental protection issues.

speaker: RUBIO
text: You cannot balance our budget unless you deal with that 83 percent, which is why I've been repeatedly talking about since my time running for the Senate in Florida, where there are a lot of people like my mother that depend on Social Security and Medicare, on the need to save those programs, by reforming the way they work for future generations.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And I think if we -- the longer we take to do this, the closer we are going to get to a debt crisis.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And, Wolf, you did not get an answer to your question.

speaker: RUBIO
text: This debt issue is -- the next president of the United States will not be able to serve four to eight years without dealing with the national debt.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It is not a question of if, it is a question of when we have a debt crisis.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And we should not leave the stage here tonight without hearing a serious answer from every single one of us about how we are going to deal bring the national debt under control once and for all.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Thank you, Senator Rubio.

speaker: HEWITT
text: But I am...

speaker: SYSTEM

speaker: HEWITT

text: We will have two more years available tomorrow.

text: And I would note that this question really goes -- you know, Donald says he's being audited.

text: Well, I would think that would underscore the need to release those returns.

speaker: CRUZ
text: If he has said something that was false and that an audit is going to find was fraudulent, the voters need to know.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And listen, people across this country, we recognize our country is in crisis.

speaker: CRUZ
text: The most important question is how do we win the general election in November, 2016.

text: And roughly 65 percent of Republicans think Donald is not the right candidate to go against Hillary Clinton.

text: Now, part of the reason in the last 10 polls...

text: Eighty-five percent say you, big difference.

speaker: CRUZ
text: In the last 10 polls on RealClearPolitics, I either tied or beat Hillary.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And this is an example.

speaker: CRUZ
text: You know, the mainstream media is laying off Donald now.

speaker: CRUZ
text: They're going to pick apart his taxes.

speaker: CRUZ
text: They're going to pick apart his business deals.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And let's take, for example, one of Hillary's great vulnerabilities, the corruption at the Clinton Foundation, the fact that she had CEOs and foreign companies giving her money while she was secretary of state.

speaker: CRUZ
text: The next Republican nominee needs to be able to make that case against Hillary.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And if Donald tried to did it, Hillary would turn to Donald and say, "but gosh, Donald, you gave $100,000 to the Clinton foundation. I even went to your wedding."

speaker: CRUZ
text: He can't prosecute the case against Hillary, and we can't risk another four years of these failed Obama policies by nominating someone who loses to Hillary Clinton in November.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TRUMP
text: So at the beginning, I said openly to everybody that I contribute to many, many politicians, both Republican and Democrat.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I have, over the years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm a businessman.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have, over the years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I'm beating him in virtually every poll.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm tied in Texas, by the way, which I shouldn't be.

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: BLITZER
text: Welcome back to the Republican presidential debate here at the University of Houston.

text: Gentlemen, I want to turn our attention right now to key issues involving foreign policy and national security.

text: You said this about the ongoing conflict between the Israelis and the Palestinians -- I'm quoting you now: "Let me be sort of a neutral guy. I don't want to say whose fault it is, I don't think it helps."

speaker: BLITZER
text: How do you remain neutral when the U.S. considers Israel to be America's closest ally in the Middle East?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think he's treated Israel horribly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was the grand marshall down 5th Avenue a number of years ago for the Israeli Day Parade, I have very close ties to Israel.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've received the Tree of Life Award and many of the greatest awards given by Israel.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As president, however, there's nothing that I would rather do to bring peace to Israel and its neighbors generally.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think it serves no purpose to say that you have a good guy and a bad guy.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, I may not be successful in doing it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's probably the toughest negotiation anywhere in the world of any kind.

text: OK?

text: But it doesn't help if I start saying, "I am very pro-Israel, very pro, more than anybody on this stage."

speaker: TRUMP
text: But it doesn't do any good to start demeaning the neighbors, because I would love to do something with regard to negotiating peace, finally, for Israel and for their neighbors.

text: And I can't do that as well -- as a negotiator, I cannot do that as well if I'm taking big, big sides.

speaker: TRUMP
text: With that being said, I am totally pro-Israel.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator Cruz?

speaker: SYSTEM

text: Both Donald and Hillary Clinton want to be neutral, to use Donald's word, between Israel and the Palestinians.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Let me be clear.

text: If I'm president, America will stand unapologetically with the nation of Israel.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

text: Listen, it is not equivalent.

text: When you have terrorist strapping dynamite around their chest, exploding and murdering innocent women and children, they are not equivalent to the IDF officers protecting Israel.

text: Just today, Iran announced they're going to pay $7,000 to each suicide bomber.

text: I have over and over again led the fight to defend Israel, to fight for Israel.

text: And this -- if you want to know who will stand with Israel, we ought to start with who has stood with Israel when the heat was on.

text: I've received many, many awards from Israel, as I've said before.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have a great relationship with Israel.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'm going to keep it that way.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And if I could bring peace, that would be a fantastic thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It would be one of my greatest achievements as president.

text: And then, you know, after 9/11, the secretary of defense called me in to help out with some things.

text: And I've been a supporter of Israel -- a strong supporter of Israel longer than anybody on this stage.

speaker: KASICH
text: I didn't give as much money as Donald gave, but I've been standing with the Israelis for a very long time.

speaker: KASICH
text: And frankly, I think the problem we have in foreign policy right now, Wolf, is that we are not certain with who we stand with.

speaker: KASICH
text: Our allies are not sure what to make of us, and our enemies are moving.

text: And one -- are moving because they're not sure what we will do.

speaker: KASICH
text: It's a very interesting development here within the 24 hours.

speaker: KASICH
text: We said to the South Koreans that we would give them the high altitude defense system.

speaker: KASICH
text: It really rattled the Chinese, and for the first time since we took positive action, the Chinese are beginning to take action against North Korea.

speaker: KASICH
text: When we stand firm and we let the world know who we're with, who we stand for, and we bring our allies together, that is the road forward.

text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

text: But Senator Rubio, what's wrong with the U.S. being an honest broker in a negotiation, as Mr. Trump is proposing?

text: They teach their four- year-old children that killing Jews is a glorious thing.

text: The bottom line is, a deal between Israel and the Palestinians, given the current makeup of the Palestinians, is not possible.

text: And so the next president of the United States needs to be someone like me who will stand firmly on the side of Israel.

text: I'm not -- I'm not going to sit here and say, "Oh, I'm not on either side."

speaker: RUBIO
text: I will be on a side.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I will be on Israel's side every single day because they are the only pro-American, free enterprise democracy in the entire Middle East.

text: It's very important that we do that.

text: I watched him melt down and I'll tell you, it was one of the saddest things I've ever seen.

text: He's not going down -- excuse me...

text: OK, no, no, no -- a deal is a deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me tell you that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I learned a long time ago.

speaker: RUBIO
text: A deal is not a deal when you're dealing with terrorists.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Have you ever negotiated with terrorists?

speaker: TRUMP
text: You are not a negotiator.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You are not a negotiator.

speaker: SYSTEM

speaker: TRUMP
text: And, with your thinking, you will never bring peace.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You will never bring peace...

speaker: RUBIO
text: ... Donald, might be able to (inaudible) Palestinians and Arabs, but it's not a real estate deal...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Excuse me, I want to be able to bring peace...

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He will never be able to do it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think I may be able to do it, although I will say this.

text: Probably the toughest deal of any kind is that particular deal.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Let's move on to talk about North Korea.

speaker: BLITZER
text: You raised it, Governor Kasich.

text: The threat posed by North Korea to the United States and its allies, the commander of American forces in South Korea said that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un would use a weapon of mass destruction if he thought his regime was being threatened.
