text: Well, at least I have a plan to fight ISIS.

speaker: HOLT
text: achieving prosperity...

text: No, we're not.

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, we're not.

text: And we're still on the issue of achieving prosperity.

text: And I want to talk about taxes.

speaker: HOLT
text: I'd like you to defend that.

speaker: HOLT
text: And this next two-minute answer goes to you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I'm really calling for major jobs, because the wealthy are going create tremendous jobs.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're going to expand their companies.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're going to do a tremendous job.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm getting rid of the carried interest provision.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And if you really look, it's not a tax -- it's really not a great thing for the wealthy.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's a great thing for the middle class.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's a great thing for companies to expand.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when these people are going to put billions and billions of dollars into companies, and when they're going to bring $2.5 trillion back from overseas, where they can't bring the money back, because politicians like Secretary Clinton won't allow them to bring the money back, because the taxes are so onerous, and the bureaucratic red tape, so what -- is so bad.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So what they're doing is they're leaving our country, and they're, believe it or not, leaving because taxes are too high and because some of them have lots of money outside of our country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And instead of bringing it back and putting the money to work, because they can't work out a deal to -- and everybody agrees it should be brought back.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Instead of that, they're leaving our country to get their money, because they can't bring their money back into our country, because of bureaucratic red tape, because they can't get together.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because we have -- we have a president that can't sit them around a table and get them to approve something.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And here's the thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Republicans and Democrats agree that this should be done, $2.5 trillion.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I happen to think it's double that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's probably $5 trillion that we can't bring into our country, Lester.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And with a little leadership, you'd get it in here very quickly, and it could be put to use on the inner cities and lots of other things, and it would be beautiful.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But we have no leadership.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And honestly, that starts with Secretary Clinton.

speaker: HOLT
text: All right.

speaker: HOLT
text: You have two minutes of the same question to defend tax increases on the wealthiest Americans, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have a feeling that by, the end of this evening, I'm going to be blamed for everything that's ever happened.

text: Why not?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Why not?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yeah, why not?

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, let me say this, it is absolutely the case...

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: HOLT

speaker: TRUMP
text: Yes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yeah, well, let's start the clock again, Lester.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've looked at your tax proposals.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't see changes in the corporate tax rates or the kinds of proposals you're referring to that would cause the repatriation, bringing back of money that's stranded overseas.

text: I happen to support that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Then you didn't read it.

speaker: CLINTON

text: You've proposed an approach that has a...

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: HOLT

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: CLINTON
text: it is...

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: CLINTON
text: as I said, trumped-up trickle-down.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Trickle-down did not work.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It got us into the mess we were in, in 2008 and 2009.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Slashing taxes on the wealthy hasn't worked.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And a lot of really smart, wealthy people know that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And they are saying, hey, we need to do more to make the contributions we should be making to rebuild the middle class.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't think top-down works in America.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think building the middle class, investing in the middle class, making college debt-free so more young people can get their education, helping people refinance their -- their debt from college at a lower rate.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Those are the kinds of things that will really boost the economy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Broad-based, inclusive growth is what we need in America, not more advantages for people at the very top.

text: Mr. Trump, we're...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Typical politician.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All talk, no action.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Sounds good, doesn't work.

text: Our country is suffering because people like Secretary Clinton have made such bad decisions in terms of our jobs and in terms of what's going on.

text: And the only thing that looks good is the stock market, but if you raise interest rates even a little bit, that's going to come crashing down.

text: And we better be awfully careful.

text: This Janet Yellen of the Fed.

speaker: TRUMP

text: And believe me: The day Obama goes off, and he leaves, and goes out to the golf course for the rest of his life to play golf, when they raise interest rates, you're going to see some very bad things happen, because the Fed is not doing their job.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The Fed is being more political than Secretary Clinton.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, we're talking about the burden that Americans have to pay, yet you have not released your tax returns.

speaker: HOLT
text: And the reason nominees have released their returns for decades is so that voters will know if their potential president owes money to -- who he owes it to and any business conflicts.

text: Don't Americans have a right to know if there are any conflicts of interest?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't mind releasing -- I'm under a routine audit.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it'll be released.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And -- as soon as the audit's finished, it will be released.

text: But you will learn more about Donald Trump by going down to the federal elections, where I filed a 104-page essentially financial statement of sorts, the forms that they have.

text: It shows income -- in fact, the income -- I just looked today -- the income is filed at $694 million for this past year, $694 million.

text: If you would have told me I was going to make that 15 or 20 years ago, I would have been very surprised.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But that's the kind of thinking that our country needs.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When we have a country that's doing so badly, that's being ripped off by every single country in the world, it's the kind of thinking that our country needs, because everybody -- Lester, we have a trade deficit with all of the countries that we do business with, of almost $800 billion a year.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know what that is?

speaker: TRUMP
text: That means, who's negotiating these trade deals?

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have people that are political hacks negotiating our trade deals.

text: The IRS says an audit...

text: Excuse me.

text: of your taxes -- you're perfectly free to release your taxes during an audit.

text: And so the question, does the public's right to know outweigh your personal...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I told you, I will release them as soon as the audit.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, I've been under audit almost for 15 years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I know a lot of wealthy people that have never been audited.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I said, do you get audited?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I get audited almost every year.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And in a way, I should be complaining.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm not even complaining.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't mind it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's almost become a way of life.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I get audited by the IRS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But other people don't.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will say this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have a situation in this country that has to be taken care of.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will release my tax returns -- against my lawyer's wishes -- when she releases her 33,000 e-mails that have been deleted.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As soon as she releases them, I will release.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will release my tax returns.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's against -- my lawyers, they say, "Don't do it."

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will tell you this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: No -- in fact, watching shows, they're reading the papers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Almost every lawyer says, you don't release your returns until the audit's complete.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When the audit's complete, I'll do it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I would go against them if she releases her e-mails.

speaker: HOLT
text: So it's negotiable?

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's not negotiable, no.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let her release the e-mails.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why did she delete 33,000...

text: But let me just admonish the audience one more time.

text: There was an agreement.

speaker: HOLT
text: We did ask you to be silent, so it would be helpful for us.

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I think you've seen another example of bait-and- switch here.

speaker: CLINTON
text: For 40 years, everyone running for president has released their tax returns.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You can go and see nearly, I think, 39, 40 years of our tax returns, but everyone has done it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We know the IRS has made clear there is no prohibition on releasing it when you're under audit.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So you've got to ask yourself, why won't he release his tax returns?

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think there may be a couple of reasons.

speaker: CLINTON
text: First, maybe he's not as rich as he says he is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Second, maybe he's not as charitable as he claims to be.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Third, we don't know all of his business dealings, but we have been told through investigative reporting that he owes about $650 million to Wall Street and foreign banks.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Or maybe he doesn't want the American people, all of you watching tonight, to know that he's paid nothing in federal taxes, because the only years that anybody's ever seen were a couple of years when he had to turn them over to state authorities when he was trying to get a casino license, and they showed he didn't pay any federal income tax.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That makes me smart.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So if he's paid zero, that means zero for troops, zero for vets, zero for schools or health.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think probably he's not all that enthusiastic about having the rest of our country see what the real reasons are, because it must be something really important, even terrible, that he's trying to hide.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the financial disclosure statements, they don't give you the tax rate.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They don't give you all the details that tax returns would.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it just seems to me that this is something that the American people deserve to see.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I have no reason to believe that he's ever going to release his tax returns, because there's something he's hiding.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we'll guess.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We'll keep guessing at what it might be that he's hiding.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I think the question is, were he ever to get near the White House, what would be those conflicts?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Who does he owe money to?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, he owes you the answers to that, and he should provide them.

text: He also -- he also raised the issue of your e-mails.

text: Do you want to respond to that?

text: I do.

text: You know, I made a mistake using a private e- mail.

text: That's for sure.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And if I had to do it over again, I would, obviously, do it differently.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I'm not going to make any excuses.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It was a mistake, and I take responsibility for that.

text: Mr. Trump?

text: That was more than a mistake.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That was done purposely.

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK?

speaker: TRUMP
text: That was not a mistake.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That was done purposely.

text: When you have your staff taking the Fifth Amendment, taking the Fifth so they're not prosecuted, when you have the man that set up the illegal server taking the Fifth, I think it's disgraceful.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And believe me, this country thinks it's -- really thinks it's disgraceful, also.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As far as my tax returns, you don't learn that much from tax returns.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That I can tell you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You learn a lot from financial disclosure.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you should go down and take a look at that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The other thing, I'm extremely underleveraged.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The report that said $650 -- which, by the way, a lot of friends of mine that know my business say, boy, that's really not a lot of money.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's not a lot of money relative to what I had.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The buildings that were in question, they said in the same report, which was -- actually, it wasn't even a bad story, to be honest with you, but the buildings are worth $3.9 billion.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And the $650 isn't even on that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But it's not $650.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's much less than that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I could give you a list of banks, I would -- if that would help you, I would give you a list of banks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: These are very fine institutions, very fine banks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I could do that very quickly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I am very underleveraged.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have a great company.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have a tremendous income.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And the reason I say that is not in a braggadocios way.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's because it's about time that this country had somebody running it that has an idea about money.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When we have $20 trillion in debt, and our country's a mess, you know, it's one thing to have $20 trillion in debt and our roads are good and our bridges are good and everything's in great shape, our airports.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Our airports are like from a third world country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You land at LaGuardia, you land at Kennedy, you land at LAX, you land at Newark, and you come in from Dubai and Qatar and you see these incredible -- you come in from China, you see these incredible airports, and you land -- we've become a third world country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So the worst of all things has happened.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We owe $20 trillion, and we're a mess.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We haven't even started.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we've spent $6 trillion in the Middle East, according to a report that I just saw.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Whether it's 6 or 5, but it looks like it's 6, $6 trillion in the Middle East, we could have rebuilt our country twice.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it's really a shame.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it's politicians like Secretary Clinton that have caused this problem.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Our country has tremendous problems.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're a debtor nation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're a serious debtor nation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have a country that needs new roads, new tunnels, new bridges, new airports, new schools, new hospitals.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we don't have the money, because it's been squandered on so many of your ideas.

speaker: HOLT
text: We'll let you respond and we'll move on to the next segment.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And maybe because you haven't paid any federal income tax for a lot of years.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the other thing I think is important...

speaker: TRUMP
text: It would be squandered, too, believe me.

speaker: CLINTON
text: is if your -- if your main claim to be president of the United States is your business, then I think we should talk about that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, your campaign manager said that you built a lot of businesses on the backs of little guys.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, indeed, I have met a lot of the people who were stiffed by you and your businesses, Donald.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've met dishwashers, painters, architects, glass installers, marble installers, drapery installers, like my dad was, who you refused to pay when they finished the work that you asked them to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have an architect in the audience who designed one of your clubhouses at one of your golf courses.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's a beautiful facility.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It immediately was put to use.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And you wouldn't pay what the man needed to be paid, what he was charging you to do...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Maybe he didn't do a good job and I was unsatisfied with his work...

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, to...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Which our country should do, too.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Do the thousands of people that you have stiffed over the course of your business not deserve some kind of apology from someone who has taken their labor, taken the goods that they produced, and then refused to pay them?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I can only say that I'm certainly relieved that my late father never did business with you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He provided a good middle-class life for us, but the people he worked for, he expected the bargain to be kept on both sides.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And when we talk about your business, you've taken business bankruptcy six times.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There are a lot of great businesspeople that have never taken bankruptcy once.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You call yourself the King of Debt.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You talk about leverage.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You even at one time suggested that you would try to negotiate down the national debt of the United States.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wrong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wrong.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, sometimes there's not a direct transfer of skills from business to government, but sometimes what happened in business would be really bad for government.

speaker: HOLT
text: Let's let Mr. Trump...

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we need to be very clear about that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So, yeah, I think -- I do think it's time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, it's all words, it's all sound bites.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I built an unbelievable company.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Some of the greatest assets anywhere in the world, real estate assets anywhere in the world, beyond the United States, in Europe, lots of different places.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's an unbelievable company.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But on occasion, four times, we used certain laws that are there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when Secretary Clinton talks about people that didn't get paid, first of all, they did get paid a lot, but taken advantage of the laws of the nation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, if you want to change the laws, you've been there a long time, change the laws.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I take advantage of the laws of the nation because I'm running a company.

speaker: TRUMP
text: My obligation right now is to do well for myself, my family, my employees, for my companies.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's what I do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But what she doesn't say is that tens of thousands of people that are unbelievably happy and that love me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'll give you an example.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're just opening up on Pennsylvania Avenue right next to the White House, so if I don't get there one way, I'm going to get to Pennsylvania Avenue another.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But we're opening the Old Post Office.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Under budget, ahead of schedule, saved tremendous money.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm a year ahead of schedule.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's what this country should be doing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We build roads and they cost two and three and four times what they're supposed to cost.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We buy products for our military and they come in at costs that are so far above what they were supposed to be, because we don't have people that know what they're doing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When we look at the budget, the budget is bad to a large extent because we have people that have no idea as to what to do and how to buy.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The Trump International is way under budget and way ahead of schedule.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we should be able to do that for our country.

speaker: HOLT
text: Well, we're well behind schedule, so I want to move to our next segment.

speaker: HOLT
text: We move into our next segment talking about America's direction.

speaker: HOLT
text: And let's start by talking about race.

speaker: HOLT
text: The share of Americans who say race relations are bad in this country is the highest it's been in decades, much of it amplified by shootings of African-Americans by police, as we've seen recently in Charlotte and Tulsa.

speaker: HOLT
text: Race has been a big issue in this campaign, and one of you is going to have to bridge a very wide and bitter gap.

speaker: HOLT
text: So how do you heal the divide?

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton, you get two minutes on this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, you're right.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Race remains a significant challenge in our country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Unfortunately, race still determines too much, often determines where people live, determines what kind of education in their public schools they can get, and, yes, it determines how they're treated in the criminal justice system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've just seen those two tragic examples in both Tulsa and Charlotte.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we've got to do several things at the same time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to restore trust between communities and the police.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to work to make sure that our police are using the best training, the best techniques, that they're well prepared to use force only when necessary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Everyone should be respected by the law, and everyone should respect the law.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Right now, that's not the case in a lot of our neighborhoods.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I have, ever since the first day of my campaign, called for criminal justice reform.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've laid out a platform that I think would begin to remedy some of the problems we have in the criminal justice system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we also have to recognize, in addition to the challenges that we face with policing, there are so many good, brave police officers who equally want reform.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we have to bring communities together in order to begin working on that as a mutual goal.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we've got to get guns out of the hands of people who should not have them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African- American men, more than the next nine causes put together.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we have to do two things, as I said.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to restore trust.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to work with the police.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to make sure they respect the communities and the communities respect them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we have to tackle the plague of gun violence, which is a big contributor to a lot of the problems that we're seeing today.

speaker: HOLT
text: All right, Mr. Trump, you have two minutes.

speaker: HOLT
text: How do you heal the divide?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, first of all, Secretary Clinton doesn't want to use a couple of words, and that's law and order.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we need law and order.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If we don't have it, we're not going to have a country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when I look at what's going on in Charlotte, a city I love, a city where I have investments, when I look at what's going on throughout various parts of our country, whether it's -- I mean, I can just keep naming them all day long -- we need law and order in our country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I just got today the, as you know, the endorsement of the Fraternal Order of Police, we just -- just came in.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have endorsements from, I think, almost every police group, very -- I mean, a large percentage of them in the United States.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have a situation where we have our inner cities, African- Americans, Hispanics are living in he'll because it's so dangerous.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You walk down the street, you get shot.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In Chicago, they've had thousands of shootings, thousands since January 1st.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Thousands of shootings.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'm saying, where is this?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Is this a war-torn country?

speaker: TRUMP
text: What are we doing?

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have to stop the violence.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to bring back law and order.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In a place like Chicago, where thousands of people have been killed, thousands over the last number of years, in fact, almost 4,000 have been killed since Barack Obama became president, over -- almost 4,000 people in Chicago have been killed.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to bring back law and order.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, whether or not in a place like Chicago you do stop and frisk, which worked very well, Mayor Giuliani is here, worked very well in New York.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It brought the crime rate way down.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you take the gun away from criminals that shouldn't be having it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have gangs roaming the street.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And in many cases, they're illegally here, illegal immigrants.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they have guns.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they shoot people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have to be very strong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have to be very vigilant.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to be -- we have to know what we're doing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Right now, our police, in many cases, are afraid to do anything.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to protect our inner cities, because African-American communities are being decimated by crime, decimated.

speaker: HOLT
text: Your two -- your two minutes expired, but I do want to follow up.

speaker: HOLT
text: Stop-and-frisk was ruled unconstitutional in New York, because it largely singled out black and Hispanic young men.

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, you're wrong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It went before a judge, who was a very against-police judge.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was taken away from her.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And our mayor, our new mayor, refused to go forward with the case.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They would have won an appeal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If you look at it, throughout the country, there are many places where it's allowed.

speaker: HOLT
text: The argument is that it's a form of racial profiling.

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, the argument is that we have to take the guns away from these people that have them and they are bad people that shouldn't have them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: These are felons.

speaker: TRUMP
text: These are people that are bad people that shouldn't be -- when you have 3,000 shootings in Chicago from January 1st, when you have 4,000 people killed in Chicago by guns, from the beginning of the presidency of Barack Obama, his hometown, you have to have stop-and-frisk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You need more police.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You need a better community, you know, relation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You don't have good community relations in Chicago.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's terrible.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have property there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's terrible what's going on in Chicago.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But when you look -- and Chicago's not the only -- you go to Ferguson, you go to so many different places.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You need better relationships.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I agree with Secretary Clinton on this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You need better relationships between the communities and the police, because in some cases, it's not good.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you look at Dallas, where the relationships were really studied, the relationships were really a beautiful thing, and then five police officers were killed one night very violently.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So there's some bad things going on.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Some really bad things.

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: TRUMP
text: But we need -- Lester, we need law and order.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we need law and order in the inner cities, because the people that are most affected by what's happening are African-American and Hispanic people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it's very unfair to them what our politicians are allowing to happen.

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I've heard -- I've heard Donald say this at his rallies, and it's really unfortunate that he paints such a dire negative picture of black communities in our country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Ugh.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, the vibrancy of the black church, the black businesses that employ so many people, the opportunities that so many families are working to provide for their kids.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There's a lot that we should be proud of and we should be supporting and lifting up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we do always have to make sure we keep people safe.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There are the right ways of doing it, and then there are ways that are ineffective.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Stop-and-frisk was found to be unconstitutional and, in part, because it was ineffective.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It did not do what it needed to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, I believe in community policing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, in fact, violent crime is one-half of what it was in 1991.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Property crime is down 40 percent.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We just don't want to see it creep back up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've had 25 years of very good cooperation.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But there were some problems, some unintended consequences.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Too many young African-American and Latino men ended up in jail for nonviolent offenses.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it's just a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we've got to address the systemic racism in our criminal justice system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We cannot just say law and order.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to say -- we have to come forward with a plan that is going to divert people from the criminal justice system, deal with mandatory minimum sentences, which have put too many people away for too long for doing too little.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need to have more second chance programs.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm glad that we're ending private prisons in the federal system; I want to see them ended in the state system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You shouldn't have a profit motivation to fill prison cells with young Americans.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So there are some positive ways we can work on this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I believe strongly that commonsense gun safety measures would assist us.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Right now -- and this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby -- right now, we've got too many military- style weapons on the streets.

speaker: CLINTON
text: In a lot of places, our police are outgunned.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need comprehensive background checks, and we need to keep guns out of the hands of those who will do harm.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we finally need to pass a prohibition on anyone who's on the terrorist watch list from being able to buy a gun in our country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If you're too dangerous to fly, you are too dangerous to buy a gun.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So there are things we can do, and we ought to do it in a bipartisan way.

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton, last week, you said we've got to do everything possible to improve policing, to go right at implicit bias.

speaker: HOLT
text: Do you believe that police are implicitly biased against black people?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Lester, I think implicit bias is a problem for everyone, not just police.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think, unfortunately, too many of us in our great country jump to conclusions about each other.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And therefore, I think we need all of us to be asking hard questions about, you know, why am I feeling this way?

speaker: CLINTON
text: But when it comes to policing, since it can have literally fatal consequences, I have said, in my first budget, we would put money into that budget to help us deal with implicit bias by retraining a lot of our police officers.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've met with a group of very distinguished, experienced police chiefs a few weeks ago.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They admit it's an issue.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They've got a lot of concerns.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Mental health is one of the biggest concerns, because now police are having to handle a lot of really difficult mental health problems on the street.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They want support, they want more training, they want more assistance.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think the federal government could be in a position where we would offer and provide that.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump...

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'd like to respond to that.

speaker: HOLT
text: Please.

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, I agree, and a lot of people even within my own party want to give certain rights to people on watch lists and no- fly lists.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I agree with you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When a person is on a watch list or a no-fly list, and I have the endorsement of the NRA, which I'm very proud of.

speaker: TRUMP
text: These are very, very good people, and they're protecting the Second Amendment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I think we have to look very strongly at no-fly lists and watch lists.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when people are on there, even if they shouldn't be on there, we'll help them, we'll help them legally, we'll help them get off.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I tend to agree with that quite strongly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I do want to bring up the fact that you were the one that brought up the words super-predator about young black youth.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's a term that I think was a -- it's -- it's been horribly met, as you know.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think you've apologized for it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I think it was a terrible thing to say.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when it comes to stop-and-frisk, you know, you're talking about takes guns away.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I'm talking about taking guns away from gangs and people that use them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I don't think -- I really don't think you disagree with me on this, if you want to know the truth.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think maybe there's a political reason why you can't say it, but I really don't believe -- in New York City, stop-and-frisk, we had 2,200 murders, and stop-and-frisk brought it down to 500 murders.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Five hundred murders is a lot of murders.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's hard to believe, 500 is like supposed to be good?

speaker: TRUMP
text: But we went from 2,200 to 500.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it was continued on by Mayor Bloomberg.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it was terminated by current mayor.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But stop-and- frisk had a tremendous impact on the safety of New York City.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Tremendous beyond belief.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So when you say it has no impact, it really did.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It had a very, very big impact.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, it's also fair to say, if we're going to talk about mayors, that under the current mayor, crime has continued to drop, including murders.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So there is...

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, you're wrong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You're wrong.

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, I'm not.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Murders are up.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All right.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You check it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: New York -- New York has done an excellent job.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I give credit -- I give credit across the board going back two mayors, two police chiefs, because it has worked.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And other communities need to come together to do what will work, as well.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look, one murder is too many.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But it is important that we learn about what has been effective.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And not go to things that sound good that really did not have the kind of impact that we would want.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Who disagrees with keeping neighborhoods safe?

speaker: CLINTON
text: But let's also add, no one should disagree about respecting the rights of young men who live in those neighborhoods.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so we need to do a better job of working, again, with the communities, faith communities, business communities, as well as the police to try to deal with this problem.

speaker: HOLT
text: This conversation is about race.

speaker: HOLT
text: And so, Mr. Trump, I have to ask you for five...

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'd like to just respond, if I might.

speaker: HOLT
text: Please -- 20 seconds.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'd just like to respond.

speaker: HOLT
text: Please respond, then I've got a quick follow-up for you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, the African-American community has been let down by our politicians.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They talk good around election time, like right now, and after the election, they said, see ya later, I'll see you in four years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The African-American community -- because -- look, the community within the inner cities has been so badly treated.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They've been abused and used in order to get votes by Democrat politicians, because that's what it is.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They've controlled these communities for up to 100 years.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, let me...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I -- I do think...

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you, you look at the inner cities -- and I just left Detroit, and I just left Philadelphia, and I just -- you know, you've seen me, I've been all over the place.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You decided to stay home, and that's OK.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I will tell you, I've been all over.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I've met some of the greatest people I'll ever meet within these communities.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they are very, very upset with what their politicians have told them and what their politicians have done.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, I...

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think -- I think -- I think Donald just criticized me for preparing for this debate.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, yes, I did.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And you know what else I prepared for?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I prepared to be president.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think that's a good thing.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, for five years, you perpetuated a false claim that the nation's first black president was not a natural-born citizen.

speaker: HOLT
text: You questioned his legitimacy.

speaker: HOLT
text: In the last couple of weeks, you acknowledged what most Americans have accepted for years: The president was born in the United States.

speaker: HOLT
text: Can you tell us what took you so long?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'll tell you very -- well, just very simple to say.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Sidney Blumenthal works for the campaign and close -- very close friend of Secretary Clinton.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And her campaign manager, Patti Doyle, went to -- during the campaign, her campaign against President Obama, fought very hard.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you can go look it up, and you can check it out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And if you look at CNN this past week, Patti Solis Doyle was on Wolf Blitzer saying that this happened.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Blumenthal sent McClatchy, highly respected reporter at McClatchy, to Kenya to find out about it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They were pressing it very hard.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She failed to get the birth certificate.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When I got involved, I didn't fail.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I got him to give the birth certificate.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I'm satisfied with it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'll tell you why I'm satisfied with it.

speaker: HOLT
text: That was...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because I want to get on to defeating ISIS, because I want to get on to creating jobs, because I want to get on to having a strong border, because I want to get on to things that are very important to me and that are very important to the country.

speaker: HOLT
text: I will let you respond.

speaker: HOLT
text: It's important.

speaker: HOLT
text: But I just want to get the answer here.

speaker: HOLT
text: The birth certificate was produced in 2011.

speaker: HOLT
text: You've continued to tell the story and question the president's legitimacy in 2012, '13, '14, '15...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Yeah.

speaker: HOLT
text: as recently as January.

speaker: HOLT
text: So the question is, what changed your mind?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, nobody was pressing it, nobody was caring much about it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I figured you'd ask the question tonight, of course.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But nobody was caring much about it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I was the one that got him to produce the birth certificate.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think I did a good job.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Secretary Clinton also fought it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, you know -- now, everybody in mainstream is going to say, oh, that's not true.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, it's true.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Sidney Blumenthal sent a reporter -- you just have to take a look at CNN, the last week, the interview with your former campaign manager.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she was involved.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But just like she can't bring back jobs, she can't produce.

speaker: HOLT
text: I'm sorry.

speaker: HOLT
text: I'm just going to follow up -- and I will let you respond to that, because there's a lot there.

speaker: HOLT
text: But we're talking about racial healing in this segment.

speaker: HOLT
text: What do you say to Americans, people of color who...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, it was very -- I say nothing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I say nothing, because I was able to get him to produce it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He should have produced it a long time before.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I say nothing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But let me just tell you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When you talk about healing, I think that I've developed very, very good relationships over the last little while with the African-American community.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think you can see that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I feel that they really wanted me to come to that conclusion.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think I did a great job and a great service not only for the country, but even for the president, in getting him to produce his birth certificate.

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, just listen to what you heard.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And clearly, as Donald just admitted, he knew he was going to stand on this debate stage, and Lester Holt was going to be asking us questions, so he tried to put the whole racist birther lie to bed.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But it can't be dismissed that easily.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He has really started his political activity based on this racist lie that our first black president was not an American citizen.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There was absolutely no evidence for it, but he persisted, he persisted year after year, because some of his supporters, people that he was trying to bring into his fold, apparently believed it or wanted to believe it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But, remember, Donald started his career back in 1973 being sued by the Justice Department for racial discrimination because he would not rent apartments in one of his developments to African-Americans, and he made sure that the people who worked for him understood that was the policy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He actually was sued twice by the Justice Department.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So he has a long record of engaging in racist behavior.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the birther lie was a very hurtful one.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, Barack Obama is a man of great dignity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I could tell how much it bothered him and annoyed him that this was being touted and used against him.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I like to remember what Michelle Obama said in her amazing speech at our Democratic National Convention: When they go low, we go high.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And Barack Obama went high, despite Donald Trump's best efforts to bring him down.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, you can respond and we're going to move on to the next segment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I would love to respond.

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, I got to watch in preparing for this some of your debates against Barack Obama.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You treated him with terrible disrespect.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I watched the way you talk now about how lovely everything is and how wonderful you are.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It doesn't work that way.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You were after him, you were trying to -- you even sent out or your campaign sent out pictures of him in a certain garb, very famous pictures.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think you can deny that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But just last week, your campaign manager said it was true.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So when you tried to act holier than thou, it really doesn't work.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It really doesn't.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, as far as the lawsuit, yes, when I was very young, I went into my father's company, had a real estate company in Brooklyn and Queens, and we, along with many, many other companies throughout the country -- it was a federal lawsuit -- were sued.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We settled the suit with zero -- with no admission of guilt.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was very easy to do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I notice you bring that up a lot.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And, you know, I also notice the very nasty commercials that you do on me in so many different ways, which I don't do on you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Maybe I'm trying to save the money.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But, frankly, I look -- I look at that, and I say, isn't that amazing?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because I settled that lawsuit with no admission of guilt, but that was a lawsuit brought against many real estate firms, and it's just one of those things.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'll go one step further.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In Palm Beach, Florida, tough community, a brilliant community, a wealthy community, probably the wealthiest community there is in the world, I opened a club, and really got great credit for it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: No discrimination against African- Americans, against Muslims, against anybody.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it's a tremendously successful club.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'm so glad I did it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I have been given great credit for what I did.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'm very, very proud of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's the way I feel.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That is the true way I feel.

speaker: HOLT
text: Our next segment is called "Securing America."

speaker: HOLT
text: We want to start with a 21st century war happening every day in this country.

speaker: HOLT
text: Our institutions are under cyber attack, and our secrets are being stolen.

speaker: HOLT
text: So my question is, who's behind it?

speaker: HOLT
text: And how do we fight it?

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton, this answer goes to you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I think cyber security, cyber warfare will be one of the biggest challenges facing the next president, because clearly we're facing at this point two different kinds of adversaries.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There are the independent hacking groups that do it mostly for commercial reasons to try to steal information that they can use to make money.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But increasingly, we are seeing cyber attacks coming from states, organs of states.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The most recent and troubling of these has been Russia.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There's no doubt now that Russia has used cyber attacks against all kinds of organizations in our country, and I am deeply concerned about this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know Donald's very praiseworthy of Vladimir Putin, but Putin is playing a really...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: CLINTON
text: tough, long game here.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And one of the things he's done is to let loose cyber attackers to hack into government files, to hack into personal files, hack into the Democratic National Committee.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we recently have learned that, you know, that this is one of their preferred methods of trying to wreak havoc and collect information.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need to make it very clear -- whether it's Russia, China, Iran or anybody else -- the United States has much greater capacity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we are not going to sit idly by and permit state actors to go after our information, our private-sector information or our public-sector information.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we're going to have to make it clear that we don't want to use the kinds of tools that we have.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We don't want to engage in a different kind of warfare.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we will defend the citizens of this country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the Russians need to understand that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think they've been treating it as almost a probing, how far would we go, how much would we do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that's why I was so -- I was so shocked when Donald publicly invited Putin to hack into Americans.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is just unacceptable.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's one of the reasons why 50 national security officials who served in Republican information -- in administrations...

speaker: HOLT
text: Your two minutes have expired.

speaker: CLINTON
text: have said that Donald is unfit to be the commander- in-chief.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's comments like that that really worry people who understand the threats that we face.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, you have two minutes and the same question.

speaker: HOLT
text: Who's behind it?

speaker: HOLT
text: And how do we fight it?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I do want to say that I was just endorsed -- and more are coming next week -- it will be over 200 admirals, many of them here -- admirals and generals endorsed me to lead this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That just happened, and many more are coming.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'm very proud of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In addition, I was just endorsed by ICE.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They've never endorsed anybody before on immigration.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was just endorsed by ICE.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was just recently endorsed -- 16,500 Border Patrol agents.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So when Secretary Clinton talks about this, I mean, I'll take the admirals and I'll take the generals any day over the political hacks that I see that have led our country so brilliantly over the last 10 years with their knowledge.

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because look at the mess that we're in.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look at the mess that we're in.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As far as the cyber, I agree to parts of what Secretary Clinton said.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We should be better than anybody else, and perhaps we're not.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think anybody knows it was Russia that broke into the DNC.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's saying Russia, Russia, Russia, but I don't -- maybe it was.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, it could be Russia, but it could also be China.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It could also be lots of other people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It also could be somebody sitting on their bed that weighs 400 pounds, OK?

speaker: TRUMP
text: You don't know who broke in to DNC.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But what did we learn with DNC?

speaker: TRUMP
text: We learned that Bernie Sanders was taken advantage of by your people, by Debbie Wasserman Schultz.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look what happened to her.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But Bernie Sanders was taken advantage of.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's what we learned.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, whether that was Russia, whether that was China, whether it was another country, we don't know, because the truth is, under President Obama we've lost control of things that we used to have control over.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We came in with the Internet, we came up with the Internet, and I think Secretary Clinton and myself would agree very much, when you look at what ISIS is doing with the Internet, they're beating us at our own game.

speaker: TRUMP
text: ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So we have to get very, very tough on cyber and cyber warfare.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It is -- it is a huge problem.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have a son.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He's 10 years old.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He has computers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He is so good with these computers, it's unbelievable.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The security aspect of cyber is very, very tough.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And maybe it's hardly doable.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I will say, we are not doing the job we should be doing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But that's true throughout our whole governmental society.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have so many things that we have to do better, Lester, and certainly cyber is one of them.

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I think there are a number of issues that we should be addressing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have put forth a plan to defeat ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It does involve going after them online.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think we need to do much more with our tech companies to prevent ISIS and their operatives from being able to use the Internet to radicalize, even direct people in our country and Europe and elsewhere.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we also have to intensify our air strikes against ISIS and eventually support our Arab and Kurdish partners to be able to actually take out ISIS in Raqqa, end their claim of being a Caliphate.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're making progress.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Our military is assisting in Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we're hoping that within the year we'll be able to push ISIS out of Iraq and then, you know, really squeeze them in Syria.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we have to be cognizant of the fact that they've had foreign fighters coming to volunteer for them, foreign money, foreign weapons, so we have to make this the top priority.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I would also do everything possible to take out their leadership.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I was involved in a number of efforts to take out Al Qaida leadership when I was secretary of state, including, of course, taking out bin Laden.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think we need to go after Baghdadi, as well, make that one of our organizing principles.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because we've got to defeat ISIS, and we've got to do everything we can to disrupt their propaganda efforts online.

speaker: HOLT
text: You mention ISIS, and we think of ISIS certainly as over there, but there are American citizens who have been inspired to commit acts of terror on American soil, the latest incident, of course, the bombings we just saw in New York and New Jersey, the knife attack at a mall in Minnesota, in the last year, deadly attacks in San Bernardino and Orlando.

speaker: HOLT
text: I'll ask this to both of you.

speaker: HOLT
text: Tell us specifically how you would prevent homegrown attacks by American citizens, Mr. Trump?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, first I have to say one thing, very important.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Secretary Clinton is talking about taking out ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We will take out ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, President Obama and Secretary Clinton created a vacuum the way they got out of Iraq, because they got out -- what, they shouldn't have been in, but once they got in, the way they got out was a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And ISIS was formed.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So she talks about taking them out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's been doing it a long time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's been trying to take them out for a long time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But they wouldn't have even been formed if they left some troops behind, like 10,000 or maybe something more than that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And then you wouldn't have had them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Or, as I've been saying for a long time, and I think you'll agree, because I said it to you once, had we taken the oil -- and we should have taken the oil -- ISIS would not have been able to form either, because the oil was their primary source of income.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And now they have the oil all over the place, including the oil -- a lot of the oil in Libya, which was another one of her disasters.

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I hope the fact-checkers are turning up the volume and really working hard.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Donald supported the invasion of Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wrong.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is absolutely proved over and over again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wrong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wrong.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He actually advocated for the actions we took in Libya and urged that Gadhafi be taken out, after actually doing some business with him one time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But the larger point -- and he says this constantly -- is George W. Bush made the agreement about when American troops would leave Iraq, not Barack Obama.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the only way that American troops could have stayed in Iraq is to get an agreement from the then-Iraqi government that would have protected our troops, and the Iraqi government would not give that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But let's talk about the question you asked, Lester.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The question you asked is, what do we do here in the United States?

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's the most important part of this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: How do we prevent attacks?

speaker: CLINTON
text: How do we protect our people?

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think we've got to have an intelligence surge, where we are looking for every scrap of information.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I was so proud of law enforcement in New York, in Minnesota, in New Jersey.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, they responded so quickly, so professionally to the attacks that occurred by Rahami.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And they brought him down.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we may find out more information because he is still alive, which may prove to be an intelligence benefit.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They're on the front lines.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I have to respond.

speaker: HOLT
text: Please respond.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The secretary said very strongly about working with -- we've been working with them for many years, and we have the greatest mess anyone's ever seen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You look at the Middle East, it's a total mess.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Under your direction, to a large extent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you look at the Middle East, you started the Iran deal, that's another beauty where you have a country that was ready to fall, I mean, they were doing so badly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They were choking on the sanctions.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And now they're going to be actually probably a major power at some point pretty soon, the way they're going.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But when you look at NATO, I was asked on a major show, what do you think of NATO?

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you have to understand, I'm a businessperson.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I did really well.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I have common sense.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I said, well, I'll tell you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I haven't given lots of thought to NATO.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But two things.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Number one, the 28 countries of NATO, many of them aren't paying their fair share.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Number two -- and that bothers me, because we should be asking -- we're defending them, and they should at least be paying us what they're supposed to be paying by treaty and contract.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And, number two, I said, and very strongly, NATO could be obsolete, because -- and I was very strong on this, and it was actually covered very accurately in the New York Times, which is unusual for the New York Times, to be honest -- but I said, they do not focus on terror.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I was very strong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I said it numerous times.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And about four months ago, I read on the front page of the Wall Street Journal that NATO is opening up a major terror division.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think that's great.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think we should get -- because we pay approximately 73 percent of the cost of NATO.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's a lot of money to protect other people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I'm all for NATO.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I said they have to focus on terror, also.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they're going to do that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that was -- believe me -- I'm sure I'm not going to get credit for it -- but that was largely because of what I was saying and my criticism of NATO.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think we have to get NATO to go into the Middle East with us, in addition to surrounding nations, and we have to knock the hell out of ISIS, and we have to do it fast, when ISIS formed in this vacuum created by Barack Obama and Secretary Clinton.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And believe me, you were the ones that took out the troops.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Not only that, you named the day.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They couldn't believe it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They sat back probably and said, I can't believe it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They said...

speaker: CLINTON
text: Lester, we've covered...

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, wait a minute.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've covered this ground.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When they formed, when they formed, this is something that never should have happened.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It should have never happened.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, you're talking about taking out ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you were there, and you were secretary of state when it was a little infant.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now it's in over 30 countries.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you're going to stop them?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think so.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, a lot of these are judgment questions.

speaker: HOLT
text: You had supported the war in Iraq before the invasion.

speaker: HOLT
text: What makes your...

speaker: TRUMP
text: I did not support the war in Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That is a mainstream media nonsense put out by her, because she -- frankly, I think the best person in her campaign is mainstream media.

speaker: HOLT
text: My question is, since you supported it...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Just -- would you like to hear...

speaker: HOLT
text: why is your -- why is your judgment...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wait a minute.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was against the war in Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Just so you put it out.

speaker: HOLT
text: The record shows otherwise, but why -- why was...

speaker: TRUMP
text: The record does not show that.

speaker: HOLT
text: Why was -- is your judgment any...

speaker: TRUMP
text: The record shows that I'm right.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When I did an interview with Howard Stern, very lightly, first time anyone's asked me that, I said, very lightly, I don't know, maybe, who knows?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Essentially.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I then did an interview with Neil Cavuto.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We talked about the economy is more important.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I then spoke to Sean Hannity, which everybody refuses to call Sean Hannity.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I had numerous conversations with Sean Hannity at Fox.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Sean Hannity said -- and he called me the other day -- and I spoke to him about it -- he said you were totally against the war, because he was for the war.

speaker: HOLT
text: Why is your judgment better than...

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when he -- excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that was before the war started.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Sean Hannity said very strongly to me and other people -- he's willing to say it, but nobody wants to call him.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was against the war.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He said, you used to have fights with me, because Sean was in favor of the war.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I understand that side, also, not very much, because we should have never been there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But nobody called Sean Hannity.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And then they did an article in a major magazine, shortly after the war started.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think in '04.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But they did an article which had me totally against the war in Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And one of your compatriots said, you know, whether it was before or right after, Trump was definitely -- because if you read this article, there's no doubt.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But if somebody -- and I'll ask the press -- if somebody would call up Sean Hannity, this was before the war started.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He and I used to have arguments about the war.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I said, it's a terrible and a stupid thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's going to destabilize the Middle East.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's exactly what it's done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's been a disaster.

speaker: HOLT
text: My reference was to what you had said in 2002, and my question was...

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, no.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You didn't hear what I said.

speaker: HOLT
text: Why is your judgment -- why is your judgment any different than Mrs. Clinton's judgment?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I have much better judgment than she does.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There's no question about that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I also have a much better temperament than she has, you know?

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have a much better -- she spent -- let me tell you -- she spent hundreds of millions of dollars on an advertising -- you know, they get Madison Avenue into a room, they put names -- oh, temperament, let's go after -- I think my strongest asset, maybe by far, is my temperament.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have a winning temperament.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I know how to win.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She does not have a...

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wait.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The AFL-CIO the other day, behind the blue screen, I don't know who you were talking to, Secretary Clinton, but you were totally out of control.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I said, there's a person with a temperament that's got a problem.

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Whew, OK.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Let's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald, first, NATO.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5, and basically it says this: An attack on one is an attack on all.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And you know the only time it's ever been invoked?

speaker: CLINTON
text: After 9/11, when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism, something that they still are doing by our side.

speaker: CLINTON
text: With respect to Iran, when I became secretary of state, Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They had built covert facilities.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we had sanctioned them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate, but it wasn't enough.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we did drive them to the negotiating table.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And my successor, John Kerry, and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran's nuclear program without firing a single shot.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's diplomacy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's coalition-building.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's working with other nations.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The other day, I saw Donald saying that there were some Iranian sailors on a ship in the waters off of Iran, and they were taunting American sailors who were on a nearby ship.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He said, you know, if they taunted our sailors, I'd blow them out of the water and start another war.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's not good judgment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That would not start a war.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief, to be taunted.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the worst part...

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, they were taunting us.

speaker: CLINTON
text: of what we heard Donald say has been about nuclear weapons.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He has said repeatedly that he didn't care if other nations got nuclear weapons, Japan, South Korea, even Saudi Arabia.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It has been the policy of the United States, Democrats and Republicans, to do everything we could to reduce the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He even said, well, you know, if there were nuclear war in East Asia, well, you know, that's fine...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wrong.

speaker: CLINTON
text: have a good time, folks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's lies.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, in fact, his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is the number-one threat we face in the world.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So a man who can be provoked by a tweet should not have his fingers anywhere near the nuclear codes, as far as I think anyone with any sense about this should be concerned.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That line's getting a little bit old, I must say.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I would like to...

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's a good one, though.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It well describes the problem.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's not an accurate one at all.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's not an accurate one.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I just want to give a lot of things -- and just to respond.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I agree with her on one thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The single greatest problem the world has is nuclear armament, nuclear weapons, not global warming, like you think and your -- your president thinks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nuclear is the single greatest threat.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Just to go down the list, we defend Japan, we defend Germany, we defend South Korea, we defend Saudi Arabia, we defend countries.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They do not pay us.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But they should be paying us, because we are providing tremendous service and we're losing a fortune.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's why we're losing -- we're losing -- we lose on everything.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I say, who makes these -- we lose on everything.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All I said, that it's very possible that if they don't pay a fair share, because this isn't 40 years ago where we could do what we're doing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We can't defend Japan, a behemoth, selling us cars by the million...

speaker: HOLT
text: We need to move on.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, wait, but it's very important.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All I said was, they may have to defend themselves or they have to help us out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're a country that owes $20 trillion.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They have to help us out.

speaker: HOLT
text: Our last...

speaker: TRUMP
text: As far as the nuclear is concerned, I agree.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It is the single greatest threat that this country has.

speaker: HOLT
text: Which leads to my next question, as we enter our last segment here (inaudible) the subject of securing America.

speaker: HOLT
text: On nuclear weapons, President Obama reportedly considered changing the nation's longstanding policy on first use.

speaker: HOLT
text: Do you support the current policy?

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, you have two minutes on that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I have to say that, you know, for what Secretary Clinton was saying about nuclear with Russia, she's very cavalier in the way she talks about various countries.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But Russia has been expanding their -- they have a much newer capability than we do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have not been updating from the new standpoint.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I looked the other night.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was seeing B-52s, they're old enough that your father, your grandfather could be flying them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are not -- we are not keeping up with other countries.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I would like everybody to end it, just get rid of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I would certainly not do first strike.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think that once the nuclear alternative happens, it's over.

speaker: TRUMP
text: At the same time, we have to be prepared.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I can't take anything off the table.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because you look at some of these countries, you look at North Korea, we're doing nothing there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: China should solve that problem for us.

speaker: TRUMP
text: China should go into North Korea.

speaker: TRUMP
text: China is totally powerful as it relates to North Korea.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And by the way, another one powerful is the worst deal I think I've ever seen negotiated that you started is the Iran deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Iran is one of their biggest trading partners.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Iran has power over North Korea.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when they made that horrible deal with Iran, they should have included the fact that they do something with respect to North Korea.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they should have done something with respect to Yemen and all these other places.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when asked to Secretary Kerry, why didn't you do that?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why didn't you add other things into the deal?

speaker: TRUMP
text: One of the great giveaways of all time, of all time, including $400 million in cash.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody's ever seen that before.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That turned out to be wrong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was actually $1.7 billion in cash, obviously, I guess for the hostages.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It certainly looks that way.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So you say to yourself, why didn't they make the right deal?

speaker: TRUMP
text: This is one of the worst deals ever made by any country in history.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The deal with Iran will lead to nuclear problems.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All they have to do is sit back 10 years, and they don't have to do much.

speaker: HOLT
text: Your two minutes is expired.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they're going to end up getting nuclear.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I met with Bibi Netanyahu the other day.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Believe me, he's not a happy camper.

speaker: HOLT
text: All right.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mrs. Clinton, Secretary Clinton, you have two minutes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, let me -- let me start by saying, words matter.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Words matter when you run for president.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And they really matter when you are president.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I want to reassure our allies in Japan and South Korea and elsewhere that we have mutual defense treaties and we will honor them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It is essential that America's word be good.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so I know that this campaign has caused some questioning and worries on the part of many leaders across the globe.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've talked with a number of them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I want to -- on behalf of myself, and I think on behalf of a majority of the American people, say that, you know, our word is good.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's also important that we look at the entire global situation.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There's no doubt that we have other problems with Iran.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But personally, I'd rather deal with the other problems having put that lid on their nuclear program than still to be facing that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And Donald never tells you what he would do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Would he have started a war?

speaker: CLINTON
