text: Would he have bombed Iran?

speaker: CLINTON
text: If he's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before, then he should tell us what his alternative would be.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But it's like his plan to defeat ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He says it's a secret plan, but the only secret is that he has no plan.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues.

speaker: CLINTON
text: People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely, trying to get hints about what we will do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Can they rely on us?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values?

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's what I intend to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on, both here at home and around the world, to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity, but also stand up to bullies, whether they're abroad or at home.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We cannot let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security...

speaker: HOLT
text: Your two minutes is...

speaker: CLINTON
text: to be given any opportunities at all.

speaker: HOLT
text: is expired.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Lester, one thing I'd like to say.

speaker: HOLT
text: Very quickly.

speaker: HOLT
text: Twenty seconds.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will go very quickly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I will tell you that Hillary will tell you to go to her website and read all about how to defeat ISIS, which she could have defeated by never having it, you know, get going in the first place.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Right now, it's getting tougher and tougher to defeat them, because they're in more and more places, more and more states, more and more nations.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump...

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it's a big problem.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And as far as Japan is concerned, I want to help all of our allies, but we are losing billions and billions of dollars.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We cannot be the policemen of the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We cannot protect countries all over the world...

speaker: HOLT
text: We have just...

speaker: TRUMP
text: where they're not paying us what we need.

speaker: HOLT
text: We have just a few final questions...

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she doesn't say that, because she's got no business ability.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We need heart.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We need a lot of things.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you have to have some basic ability.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And sadly, she doesn't have that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All of the things that she's talking about could have been taken care of during the last 10 years, let's say, while she had great power.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But they weren't taken care of.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And if she ever wins this race, they won't be taken care of.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, this year Secretary Clinton became the first woman nominated for president by a major party.

speaker: HOLT
text: Earlier this month, you said she doesn't have, quote, "a presidential look."

speaker: HOLT
text: She's standing here right now.

speaker: HOLT
text: What did you mean by that?

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't have the look.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't have the stamina.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I said she doesn't have the stamina.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I don't believe she does have the stamina.

speaker: TRUMP
text: To be president of this country, you need tremendous stamina.

speaker: HOLT
text: The quote was, "I just don't think she has the presidential look."

speaker: TRUMP
text: You have -- wait a minute.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wait a minute, Lester.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You asked me a question.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Did you ask me a question?

speaker: TRUMP
text: You have to be able to negotiate our trade deals.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You have to be able to negotiate, that's right, with Japan, with Saudi Arabia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, can you imagine, we're defending Saudi Arabia?

speaker: TRUMP
text: And with all of the money they have, we're defending them, and they're not paying?

speaker: TRUMP
text: All you have to do is speak to them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wait.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You have so many different things you have to be able to do, and I don't believe that Hillary has the stamina.

speaker: HOLT
text: Let's let her respond.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, as soon as he travels to 112 countries and negotiates a peace deal, a cease-fire, a release of dissidents, an opening of new opportunities in nations around the world, or even spends 11 hours testifying in front of a congressional committee, he can talk to me about stamina.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TRUMP
text: The world -- let me tell you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me tell you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hillary has experience, but it's bad experience.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have made so many bad deals during the last -- so she's got experience, that I agree.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TRUMP
text: But it's bad, bad experience.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Whether it's the Iran deal that you're so in love with, where we gave them $150 billion back, whether it's the Iran deal, whether it's anything you can -- name -- you almost can't name a good deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I agree.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's got experience, but it's bad experience.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And this country can't afford to have another four years of that kind of experience.

speaker: HOLT
text: We are at -- we are at the final question.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, one thing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: One thing, Lester.

speaker: HOLT
text: Very quickly, because we're at the final question now.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, he tried to switch from looks to stamina.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But this is a man who has called women pigs, slobs and dogs, and someone who has said pregnancy is an inconvenience to employers, who has said...

speaker: TRUMP
text: I never said that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: women don't deserve equal pay unless they do as good a job as men.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I didn't say that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And one of the worst things he said was about a woman in a beauty contest.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He loves beauty contests, supporting them and hanging around them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And he called this woman "Miss Piggy."

speaker: CLINTON
text: Then he called her "Miss Housekeeping," because she was Latina.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Donald, she has a name.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Where did you find this?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Where did you find this?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Her name is Alicia Machado.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Where did you find this?

speaker: CLINTON
text: And she has become a U.S. citizen, and you can bet...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Oh, really?

speaker: CLINTON
text: she's going to vote this November.

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK, good.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me just tell you...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, could we just take 10 seconds and then we ask the final question...

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know, Hillary is hitting me with tremendous commercials.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Some of it's said in entertainment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Some of it's said -- somebody who's been very vicious to me, Rosie O'Donnell, I said very tough things to her, and I think everybody would agree that she deserves it and nobody feels sorry for her.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you want to know the truth?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was going to say something...

speaker: HOLT
text: Please very quickly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: ... extremely rough to Hillary, to her family, and I said to myself, "I can't do it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I just can't do it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's inappropriate.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's not nice."

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she spent hundreds of millions of dollars on negative ads on me, many of which are absolutely untrue.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're untrue.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they're misrepresentations.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you this, Lester: It's not nice.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I don't deserve that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But it's certainly not a nice thing that she's done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's hundreds of millions of ads.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And the only gratifying thing is, I saw the polls come in today, and with all of that money...

speaker: HOLT
text: We have to move on to the final question.

speaker: TRUMP
text: $200 million is spent, and I'm either winning or tied, and I've spent practically nothing.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HOLT
text: One of you will not win this election.

speaker: HOLT
text: So my final question to you tonight, are you willing to accept the outcome as the will of the voters?

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I support our democracy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And sometimes you win, sometimes you lose.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I certainly will support the outcome of this election.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I know Donald's trying very hard to plant doubts about it, but I hope the people out there understand: This election's really up to you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's not about us so much as it is about you and your families and the kind of country and future you want.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I sure hope you will get out and vote as though your future depended on it, because I think it does.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, very quickly, same question.

speaker: HOLT
text: Will you accept the outcome as the will of the voters?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I want to make America great again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are a nation that is seriously troubled.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're losing our jobs.

speaker: TRUMP
text: People are pouring into our country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The other day, we were deporting 800 people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And perhaps they passed the wrong button, they pressed the wrong button, or perhaps worse than that, it was corruption, but these people that we were going to deport for good reason ended up becoming citizens.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Ended up becoming citizens.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it was 800.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And now it turns out it might be 1,800, and they don't even know.

speaker: HOLT
text: Will you accept the outcome of the election?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, here's the story.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I want to make America great again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm going to be able to do it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't believe Hillary will.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The answer is, if she wins, I will absolutely support her.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HOLT
text: All right.

speaker: HOLT
text: Well, that is going to do it for us.

speaker: HOLT
text: That concludes our debate for this evening, a spirit one.

speaker: HOLT
text: We covered a lot of ground, not everything as I suspected we would.

speaker: HOLT
text: The next presidential debates are scheduled for October 9th at Washington University in St. Louis and October 19th at the University of Nevada Las Vegas.

speaker: HOLT
text: The conversation will continue.

speaker: HOLT
text: A reminder.

speaker: HOLT
text: The vice presidential debate is scheduled for October 4th at Longwood University in Farmville, Virginia.

speaker: HOLT
text: My thanks to Hillary Clinton and to Donald Trump and to Hofstra University for hosting us tonight.

speaker: HOLT
text: Good night, everyone.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Good evening.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: From Longwood University in Farmville, Virginia, and welcome to the first, and only, vice presidential debate of 2016, sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I'm Elaine Quijano, anchor at CBSN, and correspondent for CBS News.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: It's an honor to moderate this debate between Senator Tim Kaine and Governor Mike Pence.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Both are longtime public servants who are also proud fathers of sons serving in the U.S. Marines.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: The campaigns have agreed to the rules of this 90-minute debate.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: There will be nine different segments covering domestic and foreign policy issues.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Each segment will begin with a question to both candidates who will each have two minutes to answer.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Then I'll ask follow-up questions to facilitate a discussion between the candidates.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: By coin toss, it's been determined that Senator Kaine will be first to answer the opening question.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: We have an enthusiastic audience tonight.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: They've agreed to only express that enthusiasm once at the end of the debate and right now as we welcome Governor Mike Pence and Senator Tim Kaine.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen, welcome.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: It truly is a privilege to be with both of you tonight.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I'd like to start with the topic of presidential leadership.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Twenty-eight years ago tomorrow night, Lloyd Bentsen said the vice presidential debate was not about the qualifications for the vice presidency, but about how if tragedy should occur, the vice president has to step in without any margin for error, without time for preparation, to take over the responsibility for the biggest job in the world.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What about your qualities, your skills, and your temperament equip you to step into that role at a moment's notice?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, thank you for being here tonight, and, Governor Pence, welcome.

speaker: KAINE
text: It is so great to be back at Longwood University in Farmville, Virginia.

speaker: KAINE
text: This is a very special place.

speaker: KAINE
text: Sixty-five years ago, a young, courageous woman, Barbara Johns, led a walkout of her high school, Moton High School.

speaker: KAINE
text: She made history by protesting school segregation.

speaker: KAINE
text: She believed our nation was stronger together.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that walkout led to the Brown v. Board of Education decision that moved us down the path toward equality.

speaker: KAINE
text: I am so proud to be running with another strong, history-making woman, Hillary Clinton, to be president of the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm proud because her vision of stronger together, building an economy that works for all, not just those at the top, being safe in the world not only with a strong military, but also strong alliances to battle terrorism and climate change, and also to build a community of respect, just like Barbara Johns tried to do 65 years ago.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's why I'm so proud to be her running mate.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary told me why she asked me to be her running mate.

speaker: KAINE
text: She said the test of a Clinton administration will not be the signing of a bill or the passage of a bill.

speaker: KAINE
text: It'll be whether we can make somebody's life better, whether we can make a classroom better learning environment for schoolkids or teachers, whether we can make a safer -- it's going to be about results.

speaker: KAINE
text: And she said to me, you've been a missionary and a civil rights lawyer.

speaker: KAINE
text: You've been a city councilman and mayor.

speaker: KAINE
text: You've been a lieutenant governor and governor and now a U.S. senator.

speaker: KAINE
text: I think you will help me figure out how to govern this nation so that we always keep in mind that the success of the administration is the difference we make in people's lives.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that's what I bring to the ticket, that experience having served at all levels of government.

speaker: KAINE
text: But my primary role is to be Hillary Clinton's right-hand person and strong supporter as she puts together the most historic administration possible.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I relish that role.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm so proud of her.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'll just say this: We trust Hillary Clinton, my wife and I, and we trust her with the most important thing in our life.

speaker: KAINE
text: We have a son deployed overseas in the Marine Corps right now.

speaker: KAINE
text: We trust Hillary Clinton as president and commander-in-chief, but the thought of Donald Trump as commander-in-chief scares us to death.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, first off, thank you, Elaine, and thank you to -- thank you to Norwood University for their wonderful hospitality and the Commission on Presidential Debates.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's deeply humbling for me to be here, to be surrounded by my -- my wonderful family.

speaker: PENCE
text: And, Senator Kaine, it's an honor to be here with you, as well.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I just -- I also want to say -- I want to say thanks to everyone that's looking in tonight, who understands what an enormously important time this is in the life of our nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: For the last seven-and-a-half years, we've seen America's place in the world weakened.

speaker: PENCE
text: We've seen an economy stifled by more taxes, more regulation, a war on coal, and a failing health care reform come to be known as Obamacare, and the American people know that we need to make a change.

speaker: PENCE
text: And so I want to thank all of you for being -- being with us tonight.

speaker: PENCE
text: I also want to thank Donald Trump for making that call and inviting us to be a part of this ticket.

speaker: PENCE
text: I have to tell you, I'm a -- I'm a small-town boy from a place not too different from Farmville.

speaker: PENCE
text: I grew up with a cornfield in my backyard.

speaker: PENCE
text: My grandfather had immigrated to this country when he was about my son's age.

speaker: PENCE
text: My mom and dad built a -- everything that matters in a small town in Southern Indiana.

speaker: PENCE
text: They built a family and -- and a good name and a business.

speaker: PENCE
text: And they raised a family.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I dreamed some day of representing my home town in Washington, D.C., but I -- honestly, Elaine, I never imagined -- never imagined I'd have the opportunity to be governor of the state that I love, let alone be sitting at a table like this in this kind of a position.

speaker: PENCE
text: So to answer your question, I would say I -- I would hope that if -- if the responsibility ever fell to me in this role, that I would meet it with the way that I'm going to meet the responsibility should I be elected vice president of the United States.

speaker: PENCE
text: And that's to bring a lifetime of experience, a lifetime growing up in a small town, a lifetime where I've served in the Congress of the United States, where -- where I've led a state that works in the great state of Indiana, and whatever other responsibilities might follow from this, I -- I would hope and, frankly, I would pray to be able to meet that moment with that -- that lifetime of experience.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, on the campaign trail, you praised Secretary Clinton's character, including her commitment to public service, yet 60 percent of voters don't think she's trustworthy.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Why do so many people distrust her?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Is it because they have questions about her e-mails and the Clinton Foundation?

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, let me tell you why I trust Hillary Clinton.

speaker: KAINE
text: Here's what people should look at as they look at a public servant.

speaker: KAINE
text: Do they have a passion in their life that showed up before they were in public life?

speaker: KAINE
text: And have they held onto that passion throughout their life, regardless of whether they were in office or not, succeeding or failing?

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton has that passion.

speaker: KAINE
text: From a time as a kid in a Methodist youth group in the suburbs of Chicago, she has been focused on serving others with a special focus on empowering families and kids.

speaker: KAINE
text: As a civil rights lawyer in the South, with the Children's Defense Fund, first lady of Arkansas and this country, senator, secretary of state, it's always been about putting others first.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that's a sharp contrast with Donald Trump.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump always puts himself first.

speaker: KAINE
text: He built a business career, in the words of one of his own campaign staffers, "off the backs of the little guy."

speaker: KAINE
text: And as a candidate, he started his campaign with a speech where he called Mexicans rapists and criminals, and he has pursued the discredited and really outrageous lie that President Obama wasn't born in the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: It is so painful to suggest that we go back to think about these days where an African-American could not be a citizen of the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I can't imagine how Governor Pence can defend the insult- driven selfish "me first" style of Donald Trump.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence, let me ask you, you have said Donald Trump is, quote, "thoughtful, compassionate, and steady."

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Yet 67 percent of voters feel he is a risky choice, and 65 percent feel he does not have the right kind of temperament to be president.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Why do so many Americans think Mr. Trump is simply too erratic?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, let me -- let me say first and foremost that, Senator, you and Hillary Clinton would know a lot about an insult- driven campaign.

speaker: PENCE
text: It really is remarkable.

speaker: PENCE
text: At a time when literally, in the wake of Hillary Clinton's tenure as secretary of state, where she was the architect of the Obama administration's foreign policy, we see entire portions of the world, particularly the wider Middle East, literally spinning out of control.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, the situation we're watching hour by hour in Syria today is the result of the failed foreign policy and the weak foreign policy that Hillary Clinton helped lead in this administration and create.

speaker: PENCE
text: The newly emboldened -- the aggression of Russia, whether it was in Ukraine or now they're heavy-handed approach...

speaker: KAINE
text: You guys love Russia.

speaker: KAINE
text: You both have said...

speaker: PENCE
text: their heavy-handed approach.

speaker: KAINE
text: You both have said -- you both have said Vladimir Putin is a better leader than the president.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Well, we're going to get to Russia in just a moment.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: But I do want to get back to the question at...

speaker: PENCE
text: But in the midst -- Elaine, thank you.

speaker: PENCE
text: Thank you.

speaker: PENCE
text: Thank you, Senator, I'll...

speaker: KAINE
text: These guys have praised Vladimir Putin as a great leader.

speaker: KAINE
text: How can that...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Yes, and we will get to that, Senator.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: We do have that coming up here.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: But in the meantime, the questions...

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, Senator, I must have hit a...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: I must have hit a nerve here.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Why the disconnect?

speaker: PENCE
text: Because at a time of great challenge in the life of this nation, where we've weakened America's place in the world, stifled America's economy, the campaign of Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine has been an avalanche of insults.

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, to get to your question about trustworthiness, Donald Trump has built a business through hard times and through good times.

speaker: PENCE
text: He's brought an extraordinary business acumen.

speaker: PENCE
text: He's employed tens of thousands of people in this country.

speaker: KAINE
text: And paid few taxes and lost a billion a year.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And why the disconnect with your running mate?

speaker: PENCE
text: But there's a -- there's a reason why people question the trustworthiness of Hillary Clinton.

speaker: PENCE
text: And that's because they're paying attention.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, the reality is, when she was secretary of state, Senator, come on.

speaker: PENCE
text: She had a Clinton Foundation accepting contributions from foreign governments.

speaker: KAINE
text: You are Donald Trump's apprentice.

speaker: KAINE
text: Let me talk about this...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, I think I'm still on my time.

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, I think -- isn't this a discussion?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: This is our open discussion.

speaker: KAINE
text: Yeah, let's talk about the state of...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, let me interrupt -- let me interrupt you and finish my sentence, if I can.

speaker: KAINE
text: Finish your sentence.

speaker: PENCE
text: The Clinton Foundation accepted foreign contributions from foreign governments and foreign donors while she was secretary of state.

speaker: KAINE
text: OK, now I can weigh in.

speaker: KAINE
text: Now...

speaker: PENCE
text: She had a private server...

speaker: KAINE
text: Now, I get to weigh in.

speaker: KAINE
text: Now, let me just say this...

speaker: PENCE
text: that was discovered...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator, you have an opportunity to respond.

speaker: PENCE
text: keep that pay to play process out of the reach of the public.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor Pence -- Governor Pence doesn't think the world's going so well and he, you know, is going to say it's everybody's fault.

speaker: PENCE
text: Do you?

speaker: KAINE
text: Let me tell you this.

speaker: KAINE
text: When Hillary Clinton became secretary of state, Governor Pence, did you know that Osama bin Laden was alive?

speaker: PENCE
text: Yes.

speaker: KAINE
text: Do you know that we had 175,000 troops deployed in the battlefield in Iraq and Afghanistan?

speaker: KAINE
text: Do you know that Iran was racing toward a nuclear weapon and Russia was expanding its stockpile?

speaker: KAINE
text: Under Secretary Clinton's leadership, she was part of the national team, public safety team that went after and revived the dormant hunt against bin Laden and wiped him off the face of the Earth.

speaker: KAINE
text: She worked to deal with the Russians to reduce their chemical weapons stockpile.

speaker: KAINE
text: She worked a tough negotiation with nations around the world to eliminate the Iranian nuclear weapons program without firing a shot.

speaker: PENCE
text: Eliminate the Iranian nuclear weapons program?

speaker: KAINE
text: Absolutely, without firing a shot.

speaker: KAINE
text: And instead of 175,000 American troops deployed overseas, we now have 15,000.

speaker: PENCE
text: Right and...

speaker: KAINE
text: These are very, very good things.

speaker: PENCE
text: And Iraq has been overrun by ISIS, because Hillary Clinton failed to renegotiate...

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, if you want to put more American troops in Iraq, you can propose that.

speaker: PENCE
text: Hillary Clinton -- Hillary Clinton -- Hillary Clinton failed to renegotiate a status of forces agreement...

speaker: KAINE
text: No, that is incorrect.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's incorrect.

speaker: PENCE
text: And so we removed -- we removed all of our...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen, we'll get to...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: troops from Iraq, and ISIS was able to be conjured up in that vacuum.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I'd like to correct...

speaker: PENCE
text: and overrun vast areas of Iraq.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor, President Bush said we would leave Iraq at the end of 2011.

speaker: KAINE
text: And, Elaine, Iraq didn't want our troops to stay, and they wouldn't give us the protection for our troops.

speaker: KAINE
text: And guess what?

speaker: KAINE
text: If a nation where our troops are serving does not want us to stay, we're not going to stay without their protection.

speaker: PENCE
text: It was a failure of the secretary of state...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: We need to move on to the next topic, gentlemen.

speaker: KAINE
text: If Governor Pence wants to put more troops back in Iraq, that's...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: There are a lot of people wondering in this country about the economy.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Let's turn to the issue of the economy.

speaker: KAINE
text: OK.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: According to the nonpartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, neither of your economic plans will reduce the growing $19 trillion gross national debt.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: In fact, your plans would add even more to it.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Both of you were governors who balanced state budgets.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Are you concerned that adding more to the debt could be disastrous for the country.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: I think the fact that -- that under this past administration was of which Hillary Clinton was a part, we've almost doubled the national debt is atrocious.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, I'm very proud of the fact that -- I come from a state that works.

speaker: PENCE
text: The state of Indiana has balanced budgets.

speaker: PENCE
text: We cut taxes, we've made record investments in education and in infrastructure, and I still finish my term with $2 billion in the bank.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's a little bit different than when Senator Kaine was governor here in Virginia.

speaker: PENCE
text: He actually -- he actually tried to raise taxes by about $4 billion.

speaker: PENCE
text: He left his state about $2 billion in the hole.

speaker: PENCE
text: In the state of Indiana, we've cut unemployment in half; unemployment doubled when he was governor.

speaker: PENCE
text: But I think he's a very fitting running mate for Hillary Clinton, because in the wake of a season where American families are struggling in this economy under the weight of higher taxes and Obamacare and the war on coal and the stifling avalanche of regulation coming out of this administration, Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine want more of the same.

speaker: PENCE
text: It really is remarkable that they actually are advocating a trillion dollars in tax increases, which I get that.

speaker: PENCE
text: You tried to raise taxes here in Virginia and were unsuccessful.

speaker: PENCE
text: But a trillion dollars in tax increases, more regulation, more of the same war on coal, and more of Obamacare that now even former President Bill Clinton calls Obamacare a crazy plan.

speaker: PENCE
text: But Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine want to build on Obamacare.

speaker: PENCE
text: They want to expand it into a single-payer program.

speaker: PENCE
text: And for all the world, Hillary Clinton just thinks Obamacare is a good start.

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, Donald Trump and I have a plan to get this economy moving again just the way that it worked in the 1980s, just the way it worked in the 1960s, and that is by lowering taxes across the board for working families, small businesses and family farms, ending the war on coal that is hurting jobs and hurting this economy even here in Virginia, repealing Obamacare lock, stock, and barrel, and repealing all of the executive orders that Barack Obama has signed that are stifling economic growth in this economy.

speaker: PENCE
text: We can get America moving again.

speaker: PENCE
text: Put on top of that the kind of trade deals that'll put the American worker first, and you've got a prescription for real growth.

speaker: PENCE
text: And when you get the economy growing, Elaine, that's when you can deal with the national debt.

speaker: PENCE
text: When we get back to 3.5 percent to 4 percent growth with Donald Trump's plan will do, then we're going to have the resources to meet our nation's needs at home and abroad, and we're going to have the ability to bring down the national debt.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, on the economy, there's a fundamental choice for the American electorate.

speaker: KAINE
text: Do you want a "you're hired" president in Hillary Clinton or do you want a "you're fired" president in Donald Trump?

speaker: KAINE
text: I think that's not such a hard choice.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I have a plan that's on the table that's a "you're hired" plan.

speaker: KAINE
text: Five components.

speaker: KAINE
text: First thing we do is we invest in manufacturing, infrastructure, and research in the clean energy jobs of tomorrow.

speaker: KAINE
text: Second thing is we invest in our workforce, from pre-K education to great teachers to debt-free college and tuition-free college for families that make less than $125,000 a year.

speaker: KAINE
text: Third, we promote fairness by raising the minimum wage, so you can't work full-time and be under the poverty level, and by paying women equal pay for equal work.

speaker: KAINE
text: Fourth, we promote small business growth, just as we've done in Virginia, to make it easier to start and grow small businesses.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I each grew up in small-business families.

speaker: KAINE
text: My dad, who ran an iron working and welding shop, is here tonight.

speaker: KAINE
text: And, fifth, we have a tax plan that targets tax relief to middle- class individuals and small businesses and asks those at the very top who've benefited as we've come out of recession to pay more.

speaker: KAINE
text: The Trump plan is a different plan.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's a "you're fired" plan.

speaker: KAINE
text: And there's two key elements to it.

speaker: KAINE
text: First, Donald Trump said wages are too high.

speaker: KAINE
text: And both Donald Trump and Mike Pence think we ought to eliminate the federal minimum wage.

speaker: KAINE
text: Mike Pence, when he was in Congress, voted against raising the minimum wage above $5.15.

speaker: KAINE
text: And he has been a one-man bulwark against minimum wage increases in Indiana.

speaker: KAINE
text: The second component of the plan is massive tax breaks for the very top, trillions of dollars of tax breaks for people just like Donald Trump.

speaker: KAINE
text: The problem with this, Elaine, is that's exactly what we did 10 years ago and it put the economy into the deepest recession -- the deepest recession since the 1930s.

speaker: KAINE
text: Independent analysts say the Clinton plan would grow the economy by 10.5 million jobs.

speaker: KAINE
text: The Trump plan would cost 3.5 million jobs.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Donald Trump -- why would he do this?

speaker: KAINE
text: Because his tax plan basically helps him.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if he ever met his promise and he gave his tax returns to the American public like he said he would, we would see just how much his economic plan is really a Trump-first plan.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: On that point, Governor Pence, recently the New York Times released part of Mr. Trump's 1995 tax return and reported that he could have avoided paying federal income taxes for years.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Yesterday, Mr. Trump said he brilliantly used the laws to pay as little tax as legally possible.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Does that seem fair to you?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, first, let me say, I appreciated the "you're hired," "you're fired" thing, Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: You use that a whole lot.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I think your running mate used a lot of pre-done lines.

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, what -- what you all just heard out there is more taxes, $2 trillion in more spending, more deficits, more debt, more government.

speaker: PENCE
text: And if you think that's all working, then you look at the other side of the table.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, the truth of the matter is, the policies of this administration, which Hillary Clinton and Senator Kaine want to continue, have run this economy into a ditch.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're in the...

speaker: KAINE
text: Fifteen million new jobs?

speaker: PENCE
text: slowest economic recovery since the Great Depression.

speaker: KAINE
text: Fifteen million new jobs?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: There are millions more people living in poverty today than the day that Barack Obama with Hillary Clinton at his side...

speaker: KAINE
text: And the poverty level and the median income...

speaker: PENCE
text: stepped into the Oval Office.

speaker: KAINE
text: improved dramatically between 2014 and 2015.

speaker: PENCE
text: You -- honestly, Senator, you can roll out the numbers and the sunny side, but I got to tell you, people in Scranton know different.

speaker: PENCE
text: People in Fort Wayne, Indiana, know different.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, this economy is struggling.

speaker: PENCE
text: The answer to this economy is not more taxes.

speaker: KAINE
text: But it's not the giveaway tax relief to the folks at the top.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's not more spending...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: I am interested to hear whether he'll defend his running mate's not releasing taxes and not paying taxes.

speaker: PENCE
text: Absolutely I will.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, with all due respect, the question was about whether it seems fair to you that Mr. Trump said he brilliantly used the laws to pay as little tax as legally possible.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, this is probably the difference between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton and Senator Kaine.

speaker: PENCE
text: And, I mean, Hillary Clinton and Senator Kaine -- God bless you for it, career public servants, that's great -- Donald Trump is a businessman, not a career politician.

speaker: PENCE
text: He actually built a business.

speaker: PENCE
text: Those tax returns that were -- that came out publicly this week show that he faced some pretty tough times 20 years ago.

speaker: PENCE
text: But like virtually every other business, including the New York Times not too long ago, he used what's called net operating loss.

speaker: PENCE
text: We have a tax code, Senator, that actually is designed to encourage entrepreneurship in this country.

speaker: KAINE
text: But why won't he release his tax returns?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, we're answering the question about -- about a business thing, is he...

speaker: KAINE
text: I do want to come back to that, but...

speaker: PENCE
text: His tax returns -- his tax returns showed he went through a very difficult time, but he used the tax code just the way it's supposed to be used.

speaker: PENCE
text: And he did it brilliantly.

speaker: KAINE
text: How do you know that?

speaker: KAINE
text: You haven't seen his tax returns.

speaker: PENCE
text: He created a runway -- because he's created a business that's worth billions of dollars today.

speaker: KAINE
text: How do you know that?

speaker: PENCE
text: And with regard to paying taxes, this whole riff about not paying taxes and people saying he didn't pay taxes for years, Donald Trump has created tens of thousands of jobs.

speaker: PENCE
text: And he's paid payroll taxes, sales taxes, property taxes...

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, let me talk about something.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator, I'm going to give you about 30 seconds to respond, and I have question on Social Security for you.

speaker: KAINE
text: OK.

speaker: PENCE
text: The only issue on taxes -- Hillary Clinton is going to raise taxes, and Donald Trump and I are going to cut them.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump started this campaign in 2014 and he said, "If I run for president, I will absolutely release my taxes."

speaker: KAINE
text: He's broken his first...

speaker: PENCE
text: And he will.

speaker: KAINE
text: He's broken his first promise.

speaker: KAINE
text: Second, he stood on the stage...

speaker: PENCE
text: He hasn't broken his promise.

speaker: PENCE
text: He said he's...

speaker: KAINE
text: He stood on the stage last week and when Hillary said, you haven't been paying taxes, he said, "That makes me smart."

speaker: KAINE
text: So it's smart not to pay for our military?

speaker: KAINE
text: It's smart not to pay for veterans?

speaker: KAINE
text: It's smart not to pay for teachers?

speaker: KAINE
text: And I guess all of us who do pay for those things, I guess we're stupid.

speaker: KAINE
text: And the last thing I'll say is this...

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, do you take all the deductions that you're entitled to?

speaker: KAINE
text: The last thing -- the last thing I want to ask Governor Pence is...

speaker: PENCE
text: I do.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor Pence had to give Donald Trump his tax returns to show he was qualified to be vice president.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump must give the American public his tax returns to show that he's qualified to be president.

speaker: KAINE
text: And he's breaking his promise.

speaker: PENCE
text: Elaine, I have to respond to this.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: You get very little time, 20 seconds.

speaker: PENCE
text: I'll be -- I'll be very respectful.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor?

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, Donald Trump has filed over 100 pages of financial disclosure, which is what the law requires.

speaker: KAINE
text: But he said he would release his tax returns.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right, Gentlemen...

speaker: PENCE
text: The American people can review that.

speaker: PENCE
text: And he's going -- Senator, he's going to release his tax returns when the audit is over...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I need to ask you about Social Security...

speaker: KAINE
text: Richard Nixon released tax returns when he was under audit.

speaker: PENCE
text: They're going to raise your taxes.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to cut your taxes.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen...

speaker: KAINE
text: If you can't meet Nixon's standard...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: The people at home cannot understand either one of you when you speak over each other.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I would please ask you to wait until it is that the other is finished.

speaker: KAINE
text: All right.

speaker: KAINE
text: We're having fun up here.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, on the issue of Social Security, in 18 years, when the Social Security Trust Funds run out of money, you'll be 76.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: The Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget estimates your benefits could be cut by as much as $7,500 per year.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What would your administration do to prevent this cut?

speaker: KAINE
text: First, we're going to protect Social Security, which is one of the greatest programs that the American government has ever done.

speaker: KAINE
text: It happened at a time when you would work your whole life, your whole life, raising your kids, working, being a Little League coach or a Sunday school teacher, and then you would retire into poverty.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Social Security has enabled people to retire with dignity and overwhelmingly not be in poverty.

speaker: KAINE
text: We have to keep it solvent.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we will keep it solvent.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we'll look for strategies like adjusting the payroll tax cap upward in order to do that.

speaker: KAINE
text: Here's what Hillary and I will not do.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I want to make this very plain.

speaker: KAINE
text: We will never, ever engage in a risky scheme to privatize Social Security.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump wrote a book and he said Social Security is a Ponzi scheme and privatization would be good for all of us.

speaker: KAINE
text: And when Congressman Pence was in Congress, he was the chief cheerleader for the privatization of Social Security.

speaker: KAINE
text: Even after President Bush stopped pushing for it, Congressman Pence kept pushing for it.

speaker: KAINE
text: We're going to stand up against efforts to privatize Social Security.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we'll look for ways to keep it solvent going forward, focusing primarily on the payroll tax cap.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence, I'll give you an opportunity to respond.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, thanks, Elaine.

speaker: PENCE
text: There they go again.

speaker: PENCE
text: OK...

speaker: KAINE
text: Go read -- go read the book.

speaker: PENCE
text: All Donald Trump -- all Donald Trump and I have said about Social Security is we're going to meet our obligations to our seniors.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's it.

speaker: KAINE
text: Go read the book.

speaker: PENCE
text: We've said we're going to meet the obligations of Medicare.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's what this campaign is really about, Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I get, this is -- this is the old scare tactic that they roll out...

speaker: KAINE
text: But -- but you have a voting record, Governor.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I get all of that.

speaker: PENCE
text: I just, look...

speaker: PENCE
text: There's a question that you asked a little bit earlier that I want to go back to.

speaker: KAINE
text: I can't believe that you won't defend your own voting record.

speaker: PENCE
text: I have to go back to.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: We...

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, look, I -- you're running with Hillary Clinton, who wants to raise taxes by $1 trillion, increase spending by $2 trillion, and you say you're going to keep the promises of Social Security.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump and I are going to cut taxes.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to -- we're going to -- we're going to...

speaker: KAINE
text: You're not going to cut taxes.

speaker: KAINE
text: You're going to raise taxes on the middle class.

speaker: PENCE
text: reform government programs so we can meet the obligations of Social Security and Medicare.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right.

speaker: PENCE
text: Stay on the path that your party has us on, we're going to be in a -- in a mountain range of debt.

speaker: PENCE
text: And we're going to face hard choices and...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentleman, I want to move on now.

speaker: KAINE
text: You did ask this question about debt, and the debt explosion on the Trump plan is much, much bigger than anything on the Clinton side.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Let me move on now...

speaker: PENCE
text: Three hundred and five (ph) economists said your plan is bad for the economy.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: to the issue of law enforcement and race relations.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Law enforcement and race relations.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: After the Dallas police shooting, Police Chief David Brown said, quote, "We're asking cops to do too much in this country.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Every societal failure we put it off on the cops to solve.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Not enough mental health funding, not enough drug addiction funding, schools fail, let's give it to the cops."

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Do we ask too much of police officers in this country?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And how would you specifically address the chief's concerns?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, I think that's a very fair comment.

speaker: KAINE
text: I think we put a lot on police shoulders.

speaker: KAINE
text: And this is something I got a lot of scar tissue and experience on.

speaker: KAINE
text: I was a city councilman and mayor in Richmond.

speaker: KAINE
text: And when I came in, we had one of the highest homicide rates in the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: We fought very, very hard over the course of my time in local office with our police department, and we reduced our homicide rate nearly in half.

speaker: KAINE
text: And then when I was governor of Virginia, we worked hard, too.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we did something we had really wanted to do.

speaker: KAINE
text: For the first time ever, we cracked the top 10, 10 safest states, because we worked together.

speaker: KAINE
text: Here's what I learned as a mayor and a governor.

speaker: KAINE
text: The way you make communities safer and the way you make police safer is through community policing.

speaker: KAINE
text: You build the bonds between the community and the police force, build bonds of understanding, and then when people feel comfortable in their communities, that gap between the police and the communities they serve narrows.

speaker: KAINE
text: And when that gap narrows, it's safer for the communities and it's safer for the police.

speaker: KAINE
text: That model still works across our country, but there are some other models that don't work, an overly aggressive, more militarized model.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump recently said we need to do more stop-and-frisk around the country.

speaker: KAINE
text: That would be a big mistake because it polarizes the relationship between the police and the community.

speaker: KAINE
text: So here's what we'll do.

speaker: KAINE
text: We'll focus on community policing.

speaker: KAINE
text: We will focus on -- and Hillary Clinton has rolled out a really comprehensive mental health reform package that she worked on with law enforcement professionals, and we will also fight the scourge of gun violence in the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm a gun-owner.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm a strong Second Amendment supporter.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I've got a lot of scar tissue, because when I was governor of Virginia, there was a horrible shooting at Virginia Tech, and we learned that through that painful situation that gaps in the background record check system should have been closed and it could have prevented that crime, and so we're going to work to do things like close background record checks.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if we do, we won't have the tragedies that we did.

speaker: KAINE
text: One of those killed at Virginia Tech was a guy named Liviu Librescu.

speaker: KAINE
text: He was a 70-plus-year-old Romanian Holocaust survivor.

speaker: KAINE
text: He had survived the Holocaust.

speaker: KAINE
text: Then he survived the Soviet Union takeover of his country.

speaker: KAINE
text: But then he was a visiting professor at Virginia Tech, and he couldn't survive the scourge of gun violence.

speaker: KAINE
text: We can support the Second Amendment and do things like background record checks and make us safer, and that will make police safer, too.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: You know, my uncle was a cop, a career cop, on the beat in downtown Chicago.

speaker: PENCE
text: He was my hero when I was growing up.

speaker: PENCE
text: And we'd go up to visit my dad's family in Chicago.

speaker: PENCE
text: My three brothers and I would marvel at my uncle when he would come out in his uniform, sidearm at his side.

speaker: PENCE
text: Police officers are the best of us.

speaker: PENCE
text: And the men and women, white, African-American, Asian, Latino, Hispanic, they put their lives on the line every single day.

speaker: PENCE
text: And let my say, at the risk of agreeing with you, community policing is a great idea.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's worked in the Hoosier state.

speaker: PENCE
text: And we fully support that.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump and I are going to make sure that law enforcement have the resources and the tools to be able to really restore law and order to the cities and communities in this nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's probably -- probably why the 330,000 members of the Fraternal Order of Police endorsed Donald Trump as the next president of the United States of America, because they see his commitment to them.

speaker: PENCE
text: They see his commitment to law and order.

speaker: PENCE
text: But they also -- they also hear the bad mouthing, the bad mouthing that comes from people that seize upon tragedy in the wake of police action shootings as -- as a reason to -- to use a broad brush to accuse law enforcement of -- of implicit bias or institutional racism.

speaker: PENCE
text: And that really has got to stop.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, when an African-American police officer in Charlotte named Brentley Vinson, an all-star football player who went to Liberty University here in the state, came home, followed his dad into law enforcement, joined the force in Charlotte, joined the force in Charlotte in 2014, was involved in a police action shooting that claimed the life of Keith -- Keith Lamont Scott, it was a tragedy.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, I -- we -- we mourn with those who mourn.

speaker: PENCE
text: We -- we grieve with those who grieve.

speaker: PENCE
text: And we're saddened at the loss of life.

speaker: PENCE
text: But Hillary Clinton actually referred to that moment as an example of implicit bias in the police force, where -- where she used -- when she was asked in the debate a week ago whether there was implicit bias in law enforcement, her only answer was that there's implicit bias in everyone in the United States.

speaker: PENCE
text: I just think...

speaker: KAINE
text: Can I -- can I explain...

speaker: PENCE
text: I just think what we ought to do is we ought to stop seizing on these moments of tragedy.

speaker: PENCE
text: We ought to assure the public that we'll have a full and complete and transparent investigation whenever there's a loss of life because of police action.

speaker: PENCE
text: But, Senator, please, you know, enough of this seeking every opportunity to demean law enforcement broadly by making the accusation of implicit bias every time tragedy occurs.

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine -- Elaine, people shouldn't be afraid to bring up issues of bias in law enforcement.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if you're afraid to have...

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm not afraid to bring that up.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if -- if you're afraid to have the discussion, you'll never solve it.

speaker: KAINE
text: And so here's -- here's an example, heartbreaking.

speaker: KAINE
text: We would agree this was a heartbreaking example.

speaker: KAINE
text: The guy, Philando Castile, who was killed in St. Paul, he was a worker, a valued worker in a local school.

speaker: KAINE
text: And he was killed for no apparent reason in an incident that will be discussed and will be investigated.

speaker: KAINE
text: But when folks went and explored this situation, what they found is that Philando Castile, who was a -- they called him Mr. Rogers with Dreadlocks in the school that he worked.

speaker: KAINE
text: The kids loved him.

speaker: KAINE
text: But he had been stopped by police 40 or 50 times before that fatal incident.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if you look at sentencing in this country, African-Americans and Latinos get sentenced for the same crimes at very different rates.

speaker: PENCE
text: We need criminal justice reform.

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, we do.

speaker: PENCE
text: Indiana has passed criminal justice reform.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I just want to say, those who say that we should not...

speaker: PENCE
text: But that's not what you're talking about.

speaker: KAINE
text: we should not be able to bring up and talk about bias in the system, we'll never solve the problem...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence...

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, when African-American police officers involved in a police action shooting involving an African-American, why would Hillary Clinton accuse that African-American police officer of implicit bias?

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, I guess I can't believe you are defending the position that there is no bias and it's a topic we don't even...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence, I have a question on that point.

speaker: PENCE
text: I did not make that statement.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Your fellow Republican, Governor Pence, Senator Tim Scott, who is African-American, recently spoke on the Senate floor.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: He said he was stopped seven times by law enforcement in one year.

speaker: KAINE
text: A U.S. senator.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: He said, "I have felt the anger, the frustration, the sadness, and the humiliation that comes with feeling like you're being targeted for nothing more than being just yourself."

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What would you say to Senator Scott about his experiences?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, I have the deepest respect for Senator Scott, and he's a close friend.

speaker: PENCE
text: And what I would say is that we -- we need to adopt criminal justice reform nationally.

speaker: PENCE
text: I -- I signed criminal justice reform in the state of Indiana, Senator, and we're very proud of it.

speaker: PENCE
text: I worked when I was Congress on a second chance act.

speaker: PENCE
text: We have got to do a better job recognizing and correcting the errors in the system that do reflect on institutional bias in criminal justice.

speaker: PENCE
text: But what -- what -- what Donald Trump and I are saying is let's not have the reflex of assuming the worst of men and women in law enforcement.

speaker: PENCE
text: We truly do believe that law enforcement is not a force for racism or division in our country...

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, can I...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: So what would you say to Senator Scott, Governor?

speaker: PENCE
text: Law enforcement in this country is a force for good.

speaker: PENCE
text: They are the -- they truly are people that put their lives on the line every single day.

speaker: PENCE
text: But I would -- I would suggest to you, what we need to do is assert a stronger leadership at the national level to support law enforcement.

speaker: PENCE
text: You just heard Senator Kaine reject stop-and-frisk.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, I would suggest to you that the families that live in our inner cities that are besieged by crime...

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, let me -- let me...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, the question is about Senator Scott.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What would -- what would you tell Senator Scott?

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, if I could -- if I could jump in.

speaker: KAINE
text: I've heard Senator Scott make that eloquent plea.

speaker: KAINE
text: And look, criminal justice is about respecting the law and being respected by the law.

speaker: KAINE
text: So there is a fundamental respect issue here.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I just want to talk about the tone that's set from the top.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump during his campaign has called Mexicans rapists and criminals.

speaker: KAINE
text: He's called women slobs, pigs, dogs, disgusting.

speaker: KAINE
text: I don't like saying that in front of my wife and my mother.

speaker: KAINE
text: He attacked an Indiana-born federal judge and said he was unqualified to hear a federal lawsuit because his parents were Mexican.

speaker: KAINE
text: He went after John McCain, a POW, and said he wasn't hero because he'd been captured.

speaker: KAINE
text: He said African-Americans are living in Hell.

speaker: KAINE
text: And he perpetrated this outrageous and bigoted lie that President Obama is not a U.S. citizen.

speaker: KAINE
text: If you want to have a society where people are respected and respect laws, you can't have somebody at the top who demeans every group that he talks about.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I just -- again, I cannot believe that Governor Pence will defend the insult-driven campaign that Donald Trump has run.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I want to turn to our next segment now, immigration.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Your running mates have both said that undocumented immigrants who have committed violent crimes should be deported.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What would you tell the millions of undocumented immigrants who have not committed violent crimes?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump's laid out a plan to end illegal immigration once and for all in this country.

speaker: PENCE
text: We've been talking it to death for 20 years.

speaker: PENCE
text: Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine want to continue the policies of open borders, amnesty, catch and release, sanctuary cities, all the things that are driving -- that are driving wages down in this country, Senator, and also too often with criminal aliens in the country, it's bringing heartbreak.

speaker: PENCE
text: But I -- Donald Trump has a plan that he laid out in Arizona, that will deal systemically with illegal immigration, beginning with border security, internal enforcement.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's probably why for the first time in the history of Immigration and Customs Enforcement their union actually endorsed Donald Trump as the next president of the United States, because they know they need help to enforce the laws of this country.

speaker: PENCE
text: And Donald Trump has laid out a priority to remove criminal aliens, remove people that have overstayed their visas.

speaker: PENCE
text: And -- and once we have accomplished all of that, which will -- which will strengthen our economy, strengthen the rule of law in the country and make our communities safer once the criminal aliens are out, then we'll deal with those that remain.

speaker: PENCE
text: But I have to tell you, I just -- I was listening to the avalanche of insults coming out of Senator Kaine a minute ago.

speaker: KAINE
text: These were Donald's -- hold on a second, Governor.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: It's my time, Senator.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: It is, in fact, the governor's time.

speaker: KAINE
text: I apologize.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's your two minutes.

speaker: KAINE
text: I apologize.

speaker: PENCE
text: Thanks.

speaker: PENCE
text: I forgive you.

speaker: PENCE
text: He says ours is an insult-driven campaign.

speaker: PENCE
text: Did you all just hear that?

speaker: PENCE
text: Ours is an insult-driven campaign?

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, to be honest with you, if Donald Trump had said all of the things that you've said he said in the way you said he said them, he still wouldn't have a fraction of the insults that Hillary Clinton leveled when she said that half of our supporters were a basket of deplorables.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's -- she said they were irredeemable, they were not American.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, it's extraordinary.

speaker: PENCE
text: And then she labeled one after another "ism" on millions of Americans who believe that we can have a stronger America at home and abroad, who believe we can get this economy moving again, who believe that we can end illegal immigration once and for all.

speaker: PENCE
text: So, Senator, this -- this insult-driven campaign, I mean...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor...

speaker: PENCE
text: That's small potatoes compared to Hillary Clinton...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: PENCE
text: calling half of Donald Trump's supporters a basket of deplorables.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton said something on the campaign trail, and the very next day, she said, you know what, I shouldn't have said that.

speaker: PENCE
text: She said she shouldn't have said half.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, this is Senator Kaine's two minutes, please.

speaker: KAINE
text: Yeah, that's right, so now we're even.

speaker: PENCE
text: Yeah.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: KAINE
text: Look for Donald trump apologizing to John McCain for saying he wasn't a hero...

speaker: PENCE
text: Oh...

speaker: KAINE
text: to Donald Trump apologizing for calling women slobs, pigs, dogs, disgusting.

speaker: PENCE
text: She apologized for saying "half."

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: It is his two minutes, please.

speaker: KAINE
text: Did Donald Trump apologize for taking after somebody in a Twitter war and making fun of her weight?

speaker: KAINE
text: Did he apologize for saying African-Americans are living in Hell?

speaker: KAINE
text: Did he apologize for saying President Obama was not even a citizen of the United States?

speaker: KAINE
text: You will look in vain to see Donald Trump ever taking responsibility for anybody and apologizing.

speaker: KAINE
text: Immigration.

speaker: KAINE
text: There's two plans on the table.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I believe in comprehensive immigration reform.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump believes in deportation nation.

speaker: KAINE
text: You've got to pick your choice.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I want a bipartisan reform that will put keeping families together as the top goal, second, that will help focus enforcement efforts on those who are violent, third, that will do more border control, and, fourth, that will provide a path to citizenship for those who work hard, pay taxes, play by the rules, and take criminal background record checks.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's our proposal.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump proposes to deport 16 million people, 11 million who are here without documents.

speaker: KAINE
text: And both Donald Trump and Mike Pence want to get rid of birthright citizenship.

speaker: KAINE
text: So if you're born here, but your parents don't have documents, they want to eliminate that.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's another 4.5 million people.

speaker: KAINE
text: These guys -- and Donald Trump have said it -- deportation force.

speaker: KAINE
text: They want to go house to house, school to school, business to business, and kick out 16 million people.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I cannot believe...

speaker: PENCE
text: That's nonsense.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's nonsense.

speaker: KAINE
text: I cannot believe that Governor Pence would sit here and defend his running mate's claim that we should create a deportation force to -- so that they'll all be gone.

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, we have a deportation force.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's called Immigrations and Customs Enforcement.

speaker: PENCE
text: And the union for Immigrations and Customs Enforcement for the first time in their history endorsed Donald Trump to be the next president of the United States of America.

speaker: KAINE
text: So you like the 16 million deportations?

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, that's -- that's nonsense.

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, what you just heard is they have a plan for open borders, amnesty.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: Our plan is like Ronald Reagan's plan from 1986.

speaker: PENCE
text: They call it comprehensive immigration reform -- they call it comprehensive immigration reform on Capitol Hill.

speaker: PENCE
text: We all know the routine.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's amnesty.

speaker: PENCE
text: And you heard one of the last things he mentioned was border security.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's how Washington always plays it.

speaker: KAINE
text: No, I...

speaker: PENCE
text: They always say we're going to do this, we're going to do that, we'll eventually get the border...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: border security three years ago, and Governor Pence was against it.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, Mr. Trump has said...

speaker: PENCE
text: Ronald Reagan said a nation without borders is not a nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump is committed to restoring the borders of this nation and securing our nation, enforcing our laws.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: So, Governor, how would these millions of undocumented immigrants leave?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Would they be forcibly removed?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, I think Donald Trump laid out a series of priorities that doesn't ends with border security.

speaker: PENCE
text: It begins with border security.

speaker: PENCE
text: And after we secure the border, not only build a wall, but beneath the ground and in the air, we do internal enforcement.

speaker: PENCE
text: But he said the focus has to be on criminal aliens.

speaker: PENCE
text: We just -- we just had a conversation about law enforcement.

speaker: PENCE
text: We just had a conversation about the -- the violence that's besetting our cities.

speaker: PENCE
text: The reality is that there's heartbreak and tragedy that has struck American families because people that came into this country illegally are now involved in criminal enterprise and activity.

speaker: PENCE
text: And we don't have the resources or the will to deport them systemically.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump has said we're going to move those people out, people who've overstayed their visas.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to enforce the law of this country.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to strengthen Immigrations and Customs Enforcements with more resources and more personnel to be able to do that.

speaker: PENCE
text: And then Donald Trump has made it clear, once we've done all of those things, that we're going to reform the immigration system that we have...

speaker: KAINE
text: I just have to correct Governor Pence....

speaker: PENCE
text: where people can come into this country.

speaker: KAINE
text: I have to...

speaker: PENCE
text: That's the order that you should do it.

speaker: PENCE
text: Border security, removing criminal aliens, upholding with law, and then -- but then, Senator, I'll work you when you go back to the Senate, I promise you, we'll work you to reform the immigration system.

speaker: KAINE
text: I look forward to working together in whatever capacities we serve in.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I just want to make it very, very clear that he's trying to fuzz up what Donald Trump has said.

speaker: KAINE
text: When Donald Trump spoke in Phoenix, he looked the audience in the eye and he said, no, we're building a wall, and we're deporting everybody.

speaker: KAINE
text: He said, quote, "They will all be gone."

speaker: KAINE
text: They will all be gone.

speaker: KAINE
text: And this is one of these ones where you can just go to the tape on it and see what Donald Trump has said.

speaker: KAINE
text: And to add...

speaker: PENCE
text: He's talking about criminal aliens.

speaker: KAINE
text: And to add to it, and to add to it, and to add to it, we are a nation of immigrants.

speaker: KAINE
text: Mike Pence and I both are descended from immigrant families.

speaker: KAINE
text: Some things, you know, maybe weren't said so great about the Irish when they came, but we've done well by absorbing immigrants, and it's made our nation stronger.

speaker: KAINE
text: When Donald Trump says Mexicans are rapists and criminals, Mexican immigrants, when Donald Trump says about your judge, a Hoosier judge, he said that Judge Curiel was unqualified to hear a case because his parents were Mexican, I can't imagine how you could defend that.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentleman, I'd like to shift now to the threat of terrorism.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Do you think the world today is a safer or more dangerous place than it was eight years ago?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Has the terrorist threat increased or decreased?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: The terrorist threat has decreased in some ways, because bin Laden is dead.

speaker: KAINE
text: The terrorist threat has decreased in some ways because an Iranian nuclear weapons program has been stopped.

speaker: KAINE
text: The terrorist threat to United States troops has been decreased in some ways because there's not 175,000 in a dangerous part of the world.

speaker: KAINE
text: There's only 15,000.

speaker: KAINE
text: But there are other parts of the world that are challenging.

speaker: KAINE
text: Let me tell you this: To beat terrorism, there's only one candidate who can do it, and it's Hillary Clinton.

speaker: KAINE
text: Remember, Hillary Clinton was the senator from New York on 9/11.

speaker: KAINE
text: She was there at the World Trade Center when they were still searching for victims and survivors.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's seared onto her, the need to beat terrorism.

speaker: KAINE
text: And she's got a plan to do it.

speaker: KAINE
text: She was part of the national security team that wiped out bin Laden.

speaker: KAINE
text: Here's her plan to defeat ISIL.

speaker: KAINE
text: First, we've got to keep taking out their leaders on the battlefield.

speaker: KAINE
text: She was part of the team that got bin Laden, and she'll lead the team that will get Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the head of ISIS.

speaker: KAINE
text: Second, we've got to disrupt financing networks, third, disrupt their ability to recruit on the Internet, in their safe havens.

speaker: KAINE
text: But, fourth, we also have to work with allies to share and surge intelligence.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's the Hillary Clinton plan; she's got the experience to do it.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump can't start a Twitter war with Miss Universe without shooting himself in the foot.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump doesn't have a plan.

speaker: KAINE
text: He said, I have a secret plan," and then he said, Um, I know more than all the generals about ISIL.

speaker: KAINE
text: And then he said, "I'm going to call the generals to help me figure out a plan."

speaker: KAINE
text: And finally he said, "I'm going to fire all the generals."

speaker: KAINE
text: He doesn't have a plan.

speaker: KAINE
text: But he does have dangerous ideas.

speaker: KAINE
text: Here's four.

speaker: KAINE
text: He trash talks the military.

speaker: KAINE
text: The military is a disaster, John McCain's no hero, the generals need all to be fired, and I know more than them.

speaker: KAINE
text: He wants to tear up alliances.

speaker: KAINE
text: NATO is obsolete, and we'll only work together with Israel if they pay "big league."

speaker: KAINE
text: Third, he loves dictators.

speaker: KAINE
text: He's got kind of a personal Mount Rushmore, Vladimir Putin, Kim Jong-un, Moammar Gadhafi...

speaker: PENCE
text: Oh, please.

speaker: PENCE
text: Come on.

speaker: KAINE
text: and Saddam Hussein.

speaker: KAINE
text: And last and most dangerously, Donald Trump believes -- Donald Trump believes that the world will be safer if more nations have nuclear weapons.

speaker: KAINE
text: He's said Saudi Arabia should get them, Japan should get them, Korea should get them.

speaker: KAINE
text: And when he was confronted with this, and told, wait a minute, terrorists could get those, proliferation could lead to nuclear war, here's what Donald Trump said, and I quote: "Go ahead, folks, enjoy yourselves."

speaker: KAINE
text: I'd love to hear Governor Pence tell me what's so enjoyable or comical about nuclear war.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: Did you work on that one a long time?

speaker: PENCE
text: Because that had a lot of really creative lines in it.

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, I'm going to see if you can defend any of it.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, look, I can defend -- I -- I -- I can -- I can make very clear to the American people, after traveling millions of miles as our secretary of state, after being the architect of the foreign policy of this administration, America is less safe today than it was the day that Barack Obama became president of the United States.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's absolutely inarguable.

speaker: PENCE
text: We've weakened America's place in the world.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's been a combination of factors, but mostly it's been a lack of leadership.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, I will give you -- and I was in Washington, D.C., on 9/11.

speaker: PENCE
text: I saw the clouds of smoke rise from the Pentagon.

speaker: KAINE
text: I was in Virginia where the Pentagon's...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: I know you were.

speaker: PENCE
text: We all lived through that day as a nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: It was heartbreaking.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I want to give this president credit for bringing Osama bin Laden to justice.

speaker: PENCE
text: But the truth is, Osama bin Laden led Al Qaida.

speaker: PENCE
text: Our primary threat today is ISIS.

speaker: PENCE
text: And because Hillary Clinton failed to renegotiate a status of forces agreement that would have allowed some American combat troops to remain in Iraq and secure the hard fought gains the American soldier had won by 2009, ISIS was able to be literally conjured up out of the desert, and it's overrun vast areas that the American soldier had won in Operation Iraqi Freedom.

speaker: PENCE
text: My heart breaks for the likes of Lance Cpl.

speaker: PENCE
text: Scott Zubowski.

speaker: PENCE
text: He fell in Fallujah in 2005.

speaker: PENCE
text: He fought hard through some of the most difficult days in Operation Iraqi Freedom, and he paid the ultimate sacrifice to defend our freedom and secure that nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: And that nation was secured in 2009.

speaker: PENCE
text: But because Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama failed to provide a status of forces agreement and leave sufficient troops in there, we are back at war.

speaker: PENCE
text: The president just ordered more troops on the ground.

speaker: PENCE
text: We are back at war in Iraq.

speaker: PENCE
text: And Scott Zubowski, whose mom would always come to Memorial Day events in Newcastle, Indiana, to see me, and I'd give her a hug and tell her we're never going to forget her son and we never will, Scott Zubowski and the sacrifices the American soldier made were squandered in Iraq because this administration created a vacuum in which ISIS was able to grow.

speaker: PENCE
text: And a reference to the Iranian deal, the Iranian deal that Hillary Clinton initiated, $150 billion to the radical mullahs in Iran.

speaker: KAINE
text: Stopping a nuclear weapons program without firing a shot?

speaker: PENCE
text: You didn't stop the nuclear weapons program.

speaker: KAINE
text: Yes, we did.

speaker: PENCE
text: You essentially...

speaker: KAINE
text: Even the Israeli military says it stopped.

speaker: PENCE
text: guaranteed that Iran will someday become a nuclear power, because there's no limitations once the period of time of the treaty comes off.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence, Mr. Trump has proposed extreme vetting of immigrants from parts of the world that export terrorism.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: But that does not address many of the recent terrorist attacks in the United States, such as the Orlando nightclub massacre and the recent bombings in New York and New Jersey.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Those were homegrown, committed by U.S. citizens and legal residents.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What specific tools would you use to prevent those kinds of attacks?

speaker: PENCE
