text: Well, I think it's -- I think it's a great question, Elaine, but it really does begin with us reforming our immigration system and putting the interests, particularly the safety and security of the American people, first.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, Donald Trump has called for extreme vetting for people coming into this country so that we don't bring people into the United States who are hostile to our Bill of Rights freedoms, who are hostile to the American way life.

speaker: PENCE
text: But also, Donald Trump and I are committed to suspending the Syrian refugee program and programs and immigration from areas of the world that have been compromised by terrorism.

speaker: PENCE
text: Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine want to increase the Syrian refugee program by 500...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, I want to...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, the question was about homegrown.

speaker: PENCE
text: Yeah, and so -- but first, you know, let's make sure we're putting the safety and security of the American people first instead of Hillary Clinton expanding the Syrian refugee program...

speaker: KAINE
text: Or instead of you violating the Constitution by blocking people based on their national origin rather than whether they're dangerous.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's not -- that's absolutely false.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's what the Seventh Circuit decided just -- here's the difference, Elaine.

speaker: PENCE
text: The Seventh Circuit...

speaker: KAINE
text: We have different views on -- on refugee issues and on immigration.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I want to do enforcement based on, are people dangerous?

speaker: KAINE
text: These guys say all Mexicans are bad.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's absolutely false.

speaker: KAINE
text: And with respect to refugees, we want to keep people out if they're dangerous.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump said keep them out if they're Muslim.

speaker: KAINE
text: Mike Pence...

speaker: PENCE
text: Absolutely...

speaker: KAINE
text: put a program in place to keep them out if they're from Syria.

speaker: KAINE
text: And yesterday an appellate court with three Republican judges struck down the Pence plan...

speaker: PENCE
text: Right.

speaker: PENCE
text: Right.

speaker: KAINE
text: and said it was discriminatory...

speaker: PENCE
text: And those judges -- those judges said...

speaker: KAINE
text: We should focus upon danger, not upon discrimination.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor?

speaker: PENCE
text: Elaine, to your point, those judges said it was because there wasn't any evidence yet that -- that ISIS had infiltrated the United States.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, Germany just arrested three Syrian refugees that were connected to ISIS.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: But they told you there's a right way and a wrong way to do it.

speaker: PENCE
text: But, look, if you're going to be critical of me on that, that's fair game.

speaker: PENCE
text: I will tell you, after two Syrian refugees were involved in the attack in Paris that is called Paris' 9/11, as governor of the state of Indiana, I have no higher priority than the safety and security of the people of my state.

speaker: KAINE
text: But, Governor Pence...

speaker: PENCE
text: So you bet I suspended that program.

speaker: KAINE
text: But, Governor Pence, I just...

speaker: PENCE
text: And I stand by that decision.

speaker: PENCE
text: And if I'm vice president of the United States or Donald Trump is president, we're going to put the safety and security of the American people first.

speaker: KAINE
text: Sure.

speaker: KAINE
text: Can we just be clear -- Hillary and I will do immigration enforcement and we'll vet refugees based on whether they're dangerous or not.

speaker: KAINE
text: We won't do it based on discriminating against you from the country you come from or the religion that you practice.

speaker: PENCE
text: But the problem with that...

speaker: KAINE
text: That is completely antithetical to the Jeffersonian values of...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: Elaine, the director of the FBI, our homeland security, said we can't know for certain who these people are coming from Syria.

speaker: KAINE
text: Yes, we can, and when we don't let them know, we don't let them in.

speaker: PENCE
text: So -- the FBI...

speaker: KAINE
text: When we don't know who they are, we don't let them in.

speaker: PENCE
text: The FBI and homeland security said we can't know for certain.

speaker: PENCE
text: You've got to err on the side of the safety and security of the American people, Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: I understand the...

speaker: KAINE
text: By trashing all Syrians or trashing all Muslims?

speaker: PENCE
text: the U.N. wants us to expand the Syrian refugee program...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, let me ask you this.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to put the safety and security of the American people first.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: has talked about an intelligence surge.

speaker: KAINE
text: Yes.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What exactly would an intelligence surge look like?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And how would that help identify terrorists with no operational connection to a foreign terrorist organization?

speaker: KAINE
text: Intelligence surge is two-thirds, Elaine.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's two things.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's, first, dramatically expanding our intelligence capacities by hiring great professionals, but also we've got some of the best intel and cyber employees in the world right here in the United States working for many of our private sector companies.

speaker: KAINE
text: So it involves increasing our own workforce, but striking great partnerships with some of our cyber and intel experts in the private sector so that we can, consistent with constitutional principles, gather more intelligence.

speaker: KAINE
text: But the second piece of this is really, really important.

speaker: KAINE
text: It also means creating stronger alliances, because you gather intelligence and then you share your intelligence back and forth with allies.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that's how you find out who may be trying to recruit, who may be trying to come to one country or the next.

speaker: KAINE
text: Alliances are critical.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's why Donald Trump's claim that he wants to -- that NATO is obsolete and that we need to get rid of NATO is so dangerous.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's not his plan.

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, he said NATO is obsolete.

speaker: KAINE
text: And, look, if you put aside -- push aside your alliances, who you're going to share intelligence with?

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton is the secretary of state who knows how to build alliances.

speaker: KAINE
text: She built the sanctions regime around the word that stopped the Iranian nuclear weapons program.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that's what an intelligence surge means.

speaker: KAINE
text: Better skill and capacity, but also better alliances.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I'd like to turn now to the tragedy in Syria.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Two hundred fifty thousand...

speaker: PENCE
text: Can I speak about the cybersecurity surge at all?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: You can -- you can have 30 seconds, Governor, quickly, please.

speaker: PENCE
text: First, Donald Trump just spoke about this issue this week.

speaker: PENCE
text: We have got to bring together the best resources of this country to understand that cyber warfare is the new warfare of the asymmetrical enemies that we face in this country.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I look forward if I'm privileged to be in this role of working with you in the Senate to make sure that we resource that effort.

speaker: KAINE
text: We will work together in whatever roles we inhabit.

speaker: PENCE
text: We have an intelligence, sir (ph).

speaker: PENCE
text: But I will also tell you that it's important in this moment to remember that Hillary Clinton had a private server in her home that had classified information on it...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And I don't -- 30 seconds is on up.

speaker: PENCE
text: about drone strikes, e-mails from the president of the United States of America were on there.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Right.

speaker: PENCE
text: Her private server was subject to being hacked by foreign...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I'd like to ask you about Syria, Governor.

speaker: PENCE
text: We could put cybersecurity first if we just make sure the next secretary of state doesn't have a private server.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: And all investigation concluded that not one reasonable prosecutor would take any additional step.

speaker: KAINE
text: You don't get to decide the rights and wrongs of this.

speaker: KAINE
text: We have a justice system that does that.

speaker: KAINE
text: And a Republican FBI director did an investigation and concluded that...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right, we are moving on now.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Two hundred fifty thousand people...

speaker: PENCE
text: If your son or my son handled classified information the way Hillary Clinton did...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: one hundred thousand of them children -- Governor...

speaker: PENCE
text: they'd be court martialed.

speaker: KAINE
text: That is absolutely false and you know that.

speaker: PENCE
text: Absolutely true.

speaker: KAINE
text: And you know that, Governor.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor...

speaker: PENCE
text: It's absolutely true.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen, please.

speaker: KAINE
text: Because the FBI did an investigation.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen.

speaker: KAINE
text: And they concluded that there was no reasonable prosecutor who would take it further.

speaker: KAINE
text: Sorry.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, Governor Pence, please.

speaker: KAINE
text: Syria.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I want to turn now to Syria.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Two hundred fifty thousand people, 100,000 of them children, are under siege in Aleppo, Syria.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Bunker buster bombs, cluster munitions, and incendiary weapons are being dropped on them by Russian and Syrian militaries.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Does the U.S. have a responsibility to protect civilians and prevent mass casualties on this scale, Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: The United States of America needs to begin to exercise strong leadership to protect the vulnerable citizens and over 100,000 children in Aleppo.

speaker: PENCE
text: Hillary Clinton's top priority when she became secretary of state was the Russian reset, the Russians reset.

speaker: PENCE
text: After the Russian reset, the Russians invaded Ukraine and took over Crimea.

speaker: PENCE
text: And the small and bullying leader of Russia is now dictating terms to the United States to the point where all the United States of America -- the greatest nation on Earth -- just withdraws from talks about a cease-fire while Vladimir Putin puts a missile defense system in Syria while he marshals the forces and begins -- look, we have got to begin to lean into this with strong, broad-shouldered American leadership.

speaker: PENCE
text: It begins by rebuilding our military.

speaker: PENCE
text: And the Russians and the Chinese have been making enormous investments in the military.

speaker: PENCE
text: We have the smallest Navy since 1916.

speaker: PENCE
text: We have the lowest number of troops since the end of the Second World War.

speaker: PENCE
text: We've got to work with Congress, and Donald Trump will, to rebuild our military and project American strength in the world.

speaker: PENCE
text: But about Aleppo and about Syria, I truly do believe that what America ought to do right now is immediately establish safe zones, so that families and vulnerable families with children can move out of those areas, work with our Arab partners, real time, right now, to make that happen.

speaker: PENCE
text: And secondly, I just have to tell you that the provocations by Russia need to be met with American strength.

speaker: PENCE
text: And if Russia chooses to be involved and continue, I should say, to be involved in this barbaric attack on civilians in Aleppo, the United States of America should be prepared to use military force to strike military targets of the Assad regime to prevent them from this humanitarian crisis that is taking place in Aleppo.

speaker: PENCE
text: There's a broad range of other things that we ought to do, as well.

speaker: PENCE
text: We ought to deploy a missile defense shield to the Czech Republic and Poland which Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama pulled back on out of not wanting to offend the Russians back in 2009.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, your two minutes are up.

speaker: PENCE
text: We've just got to have American strength on the world stage.

speaker: PENCE
text: When Donald Trump becomes president of the United States, the Russians and other countries in the world will know they're dealing with a strong American president.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I also agree that the establishment of humanitarian zones in northern Syria with the provision of international human aid, consistent with the U.N. Security Council resolution that was passed in February 2014, would be a very, very good idea.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Hillary also has the ability to stand up to Russia in a way that this ticket does not.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump, again and again, has praised Vladimir Putin.

speaker: KAINE
text: And it's clear that he has business dealings with Russian oligarchs who are very connected to Putin.

speaker: KAINE
text: The Trump campaign management team had to be fired a month or so ago because of those shadowy connections with pro-Putin forces.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor Pence made the odd claim, he said inarguably Vladimir Putin is a better leader than President Obama.

speaker: KAINE
text: Vladimir Putin has run his economy into the ground.

speaker: KAINE
text: He persecutes LGBT folks and journalists.

speaker: KAINE
text: If you don't know the difference between dictatorship and leadership, then you got to go back to a fifth-grade civics class.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'll tell you what offends me...

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, that offended me.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor Pence just said -- Governor Pence just said that Donald Trump will rebuild the military.

speaker: KAINE
text: No, he won't.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump is avoiding paying taxes.

speaker: KAINE
text: The New York Times story -- and we need to get this -- but the New York Times suggested that he probably didn't pay taxes for about 18 years starting in 1995.

speaker: KAINE
text: Those years included the years of 9/11.

speaker: KAINE
text: So get this.

speaker: KAINE
text: On 9/11, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump's hometown was attacked by the worst terrorist attack in the history of the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: Young men and women -- young men and women signed up to serve in the military to fight terrorism.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton went to Washington to get funds to rebuild her city and protect first responders, but Donald Trump was fighting a very different fight.

speaker: KAINE
text: It was a fight to avoid paying taxes so that he wouldn't support the fight against terror.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: The question was about Aleppo, Senator.

speaker: KAINE
text: He wouldn't support troops.

speaker: KAINE
text: He wouldn't -- he wouldn't support -- this is important, Elaine.

speaker: KAINE
text: When a guy running for president will not support the troops, not support veterans, not support teachers, that's really important.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Right.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I said about Aleppo, we do agree the notion is we have to create a humanitarian zone in northern Syria.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's very important.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence, you had mentioned no-fly zone.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Where would you propose setting up a safe zone specifically?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: How would you keep it safe?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, first and foremost, Donald Trump supports our troops.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump supports our veterans.

speaker: KAINE
text: He won't pay taxes.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump has paid all the taxes that he's -- do you not take deductions?

speaker: PENCE
text: How does that work?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen, this is about Syria.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I'd like to...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: Honestly, Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: Honestly, Senator.

speaker: KAINE
text: It is about our troops.

speaker: KAINE
text: It is about our troops.

speaker: PENCE
text: I understand why you want to change -- I understand why you want to change the subject.

speaker: KAINE
text: How can you support the troops if you won't pay taxes?

speaker: PENCE
text: I understand why you want to change the subject.

speaker: PENCE
text: And let me be very clear on this Russian thing.

speaker: PENCE
text: The larger question here...

speaker: KAINE
text: Do you think Donald Trump is smart to not pay taxes?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen, we're going to have time to get to Russia here.

speaker: PENCE
text: What we're dealing with is the -- you know, there's an old proverb that says the Russian bear never dies, it just hibernates.

speaker: PENCE
text: And the truth of the matter is, the weak and feckless foreign policy of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama has awakened an aggression in Russia that first appeared a few years ago with their move in Georgia, now their move into Crimea, now their move into the wider Middle East.

speaker: PENCE
text: And all the while, all we do is fold our arms and say we're not having talks anymore.

speaker: PENCE
text: To answer your question, we just need American strength.

speaker: PENCE
text: We need to -- we need to marshal the resources of our allies in the region, and in the immediate, we need to act and act now to get people out of harm's way.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And exactly how would those safe zones work?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: How would they remain safe?

speaker: PENCE
text: The -- the safe zones would have to be -- as the senator said, there's already a framework for this that's been recognized by the international community.

speaker: PENCE
text: The United States of America needs to be prepared to work with our allies in the region to create a route for safe passage and then to protect people in those areas, including with a no-fly zone.

speaker: PENCE
text: But, look, this is very tough stuff.

speaker: PENCE
text: I served on the Foreign Affairs Committee for a decade.

speaker: PENCE
text: I traveled in and out of that region for 10 years.

speaker: PENCE
text: I saw what the American soldier won in Operation Iraqi Freedom.

speaker: PENCE
text: And to see the weak and feckless leadership that Hillary Clinton was the architect of and the foreign policy of the Obama administration...

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, let me -- let me come back...

speaker: PENCE
text: is deeply troubling to me.

speaker: PENCE
text: That will all change the day Donald Trump becomes president of the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: and talk about -- let me talk about the things that Governor Pence doesn't want to acknowledge, Elaine.

speaker: KAINE
text: He doesn't want to acknowledge that we stopped the Iranian nuclear weapons program.

speaker: KAINE
text: He doesn't want to acknowledge...

speaker: PENCE
text: We didn't.

speaker: KAINE
text: that Hillary was part of a team that got bin Laden.

speaker: KAINE
text: He doesn't want to acknowledge...

speaker: PENCE
text: I just did.

speaker: KAINE
text: that it's a good thing, not a bad thing, that it's a good thing -- not a bad thing -- that we're down from 175,000 troops deployed overseas to 15,000.

speaker: KAINE
text: But let me tell you what will really make the Middle East dangerous.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump's idea that more nations should get nuclear weapons, Saudi Arabia, Japan, South Korea.

speaker: KAINE
text: Ronald Reagan said something really interesting about nuclear proliferation back in the 1980s.

speaker: KAINE
text: He said the problem with nuclear proliferation is that some fool or maniac could trigger a catastrophic event.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I think that's who Governor Pence's running mate is, exactly who Governor Reagan warned us about.

speaker: PENCE
text: And come on.

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, that was even beneath you and Hillary Clinton.

speaker: PENCE
text: And that -- that's pretty low.

speaker: KAINE
text: But do you -- do you think -- do you think we should have -- more nuclear weapons in the world will make us safer?

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, the...

speaker: KAINE
text: That's what Donald Trump thinks.

speaker: PENCE
text: Ronald Reagan also said nuclear war should never be fought because it can never be won.

speaker: PENCE
text: And the United States of America needs to make investments in modernizing our nuclear force for both deterrence...

speaker: KAINE
text: But can you defend Donald Trump's claim that more nations should get nuclear weapons?

speaker: PENCE
text: and assurance to our allies.

speaker: PENCE
text: But let me go back to this Iran thing.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, he keeps saying that they prevented -- that Hillary Clinton started the deal with the Iranians prevented Iran from getting a nuclear weapon.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: That's what the Israeli joint chiefs of staff is saying right now.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, that's not what -- that's not what Israel thinks.

speaker: KAINE
text: Gadi Eizenkot, you can go check it.

speaker: PENCE
text: You wouldn't necessarily know that.

speaker: KAINE
text: Go to the tape.

speaker: PENCE
text: I know you boycotted Prime Minister Netanyahu's speech when he came before the Congress.

speaker: KAINE
text: No, I visited him in his office.

speaker: KAINE
text: I visited him in his office.

speaker: PENCE
text: You boycotted the speech.

speaker: PENCE
text: The point is, what this Iran -- so-called Iran deal did was essentially guarantee -- I mean, when I was in Congress, I fought hard on a bipartisan basis with Republican and Democrat members to move forward the toughest sanctions, it -- literally in the history of the United States, against Iran.

speaker: KAINE
text: And then Hillary used them to get a deal.

speaker: PENCE
text: We were bringing them to heel, but the goal was always that we would only lift the sanctions if Iran permanently renounced their nuclear ambitions.

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, let me just mention one thing.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: They have not -- Elaine, let me finish a sentence.

speaker: PENCE
text: They have not renounced their nuclear ambitions.

speaker: PENCE
text: And when the deal's period runs out, there's no limitation on them obtaining weapons.

speaker: PENCE
text: That...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And very quickly, Senator.

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine...

speaker: PENCE
text: and the fact that they got $1.7 billion in a ransom payment...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: We need to talk about Russia.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Very quickly, though, Senator, please.

speaker: PENCE
text: is astonishing to the American people.

speaker: KAINE
text: Six times tonight, I have said to Governor Pence I can't imagine how you can defend your running mate's position on one issue after the next.

speaker: KAINE
text: And in all six cases, he's refused to defend his running mate.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, let's -- no, no, don't put words in my mouth.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right.

speaker: PENCE
text: He's going...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: And yet he is asking everybody to vote for somebody that he cannot defend.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I just think that should be underlined.

speaker: PENCE
text: No, I'm -- look...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right, gentlemen, let's talk about Russia.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: This is a topic that has come up.

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm very, very happy to defend Donald Trump.

speaker: PENCE
text: If he wants to take these one at a time, I'll take them one at a time.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I will give you an opportunity to do that.

speaker: KAINE
text: More nations should get nuclear weapons.

speaker: KAINE
text: Try to defend that.

speaker: PENCE
text: Don't put words in my mouth.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, he never said that, Senator.

speaker: KAINE
text: He absolutely said it.

speaker: KAINE
text: Saudi Arabia, South Korea, Japan.

speaker: PENCE
text: Most of the stuffy you've said, he's never said.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen, Russia.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Russian President Vladimir Putin invaded Ukraine, annexed Crimea, and has provided crucial military support to the Assad regime.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What steps, if any, would your administration take to counter these actions?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: You've got to be tough on Russia.

speaker: KAINE
text: So let's start with not praising Vladimir Putin as a great leader.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump and Mike Pence have said he's a great leader.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Donald Trump has business...

speaker: PENCE
text: No, we haven't.

speaker: KAINE
text: has business dealings -- has business dealings with Russia that he refuses to disclose.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton has gone toe-to- toe with Russia.

speaker: KAINE
text: She went toe-to-toe with Russia as secretary of state to do the New START Agreement to reduce Russia's nuclear stockpile.

speaker: KAINE
text: She's had the experience doing it.

speaker: KAINE
text: She went toe-to-toe with Russia and lodged protests when they went into Georgia.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we've done the same thing about Ukraine, but more than launching protests, we've put punishing economic sanctions on Russia that we need to continue.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump, on the other hand, didn't know that Russia had invaded the Crimea.

speaker: PENCE
text: Oh, that's nonsense.

speaker: KAINE
text: He was on a TV show a couple months back, and he said, "I'll guarantee you this, Russia's not going into the Ukraine."

speaker: KAINE
text: And he had to be reminded that they had gone into the Crimea two years before.

speaker: PENCE
text: He knew that.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton has gone toe-to-toe with Russia to work out a deal on New START.

speaker: KAINE
text: She got them engaged on a meaningful way to cap Iran's nuclear weapons program.

speaker: KAINE
text: And yet she stood up to them on issues such as Syria and their invasion of Georgia.

speaker: KAINE
text: You've got to have the ability to do that, and Hillary does.

speaker: KAINE
text: On the other hand, in Donald Trump, you have somebody who praises Vladimir Putin all the time.

speaker: KAINE
text: America should really wonder about a President Trump, who had a campaign manager with ties to Putin, pro- Putin elements in the Ukraine, who had to be fired for that reason.

speaker: KAINE
text: They should wonder -- when Donald Trump is sitting down with Vladimir Putin, is it going to be America's bottom line or is it going to be Donald Trump's bottom line that he's going to be worried about with all of his business dealings?

speaker: KAINE
text: Now, this could be solved if Donald Trump would be willing to release his tax returns, as he told the American public that he would do.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I know he's laughing at this, but every president...

speaker: PENCE
text: But what's it got to do with Russia?

speaker: KAINE
text: Every president since Richard Nixon has done it, and Donald Trump has said I'm doing business with Russia.

speaker: KAINE
text: The only way the American public will see whether he has a conflict of interest...

speaker: PENCE
text: No, he hasn't said that.

speaker: KAINE
text: He has, actually.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator, your time is up.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, thanks.

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm just trying to keep up with the insult-driven campaign on the other side of the table.

speaker: KAINE
text: You know, I'm just saying facts about your running mate.

speaker: PENCE
text: Yeah.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I know you can't defend.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator, please.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: This is the governor's two minutes.

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm happy to defend him, Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: Don't put words in my mouth that I'm not defending him.

speaker: KAINE
text: You're not.

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm happy to defend him.

speaker: PENCE
text: Most of what you said is completely false, and the American people know that.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'll run through the list of things where you won't defend...

speaker: PENCE
text: This isn't the old days where you can just say stuff and people believe it.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator, please.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: This is Governor Pence's two minutes.

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, this is the alternative universe of Washington, D.C., versus reality.

speaker: PENCE
text: Hillary Clinton said her number-one priority was a reset with Russia.

speaker: PENCE
text: That reset resulted in the invasion of Ukraine, after they'd infiltrated with what are called little green men, Russian soldiers that were dressing up like Ukrainian dissidents, and then they moved all the way into Crimea, took over the Crimean Peninsula.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump knew that happened.

speaker: PENCE
text: He basically was saying it's not going to happen again.

speaker: PENCE
text: The truth of the matter is that what you have in the rise of aggressive Russia, which has had -- increased its influence in Iran, that's now -- now because of this deal is on a pathway in the future to obtain a nuclear -- the leading state sponsor of terror in the world in Iran now has a closer working relationship with Russia because of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama's foreign policy and $150 billion and sanctions all being lifted.

speaker: PENCE
text: And then, of course, Syria, I mean, it really is extraordinary that -- Syria is imploding.

speaker: PENCE
text: You just asked a very thoughtful question about the disaster in Aleppo.

speaker: PENCE
text: ISIS is headquartered in Raqqa.

speaker: PENCE
text: It is -- ISIS from Raqqa has overrun vast areas that at great sacrifice the American soldier won in Operation Iraqi Freedom, and yet Senator Kaine still sits here, loyal soldier -- I get all that -- in saying that the foreign policy of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama somehow made the world more secure.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, it really is astonishing that on the day...

speaker: KAINE
text: We even wiped out the leader of Al Qaida.

speaker: PENCE
text: on the day that Iran released four American hostages...

speaker: KAINE
text: We stopped Iran from getting nuclear weapons.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor...

speaker: PENCE
text: we delivered $400 million in cash as a ransom payment for Americans held by the radical mullahs in Tehran.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, yesterday, Mr. Trump said...

speaker: KAINE
text: And we stopped a nuclear weapons program without a shot.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: quote, "Putin has no respect for Hillary Clinton and no respect for Obama."

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Why do you think he'll respect a Trump- Pence administration?

speaker: PENCE
text: Strength.

speaker: PENCE
text: Plain and simple.

speaker: KAINE
text: Business dealings.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump -- that's nonsense.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump is a strong leader...

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump's son says that the Trump organization...

speaker: PENCE
text: who is going to lead with American strength.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Please, Senator, I'll give you a chance to respond.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to rebuild our military.

speaker: PENCE
text: And let me -- let me -- this whole Putin thing.

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, America is stronger than Russia.

speaker: PENCE
text: Our economy is 16 times larger than the Russian economy.

speaker: PENCE
text: America's political system is superior to the crony, corrupt capitalist system in Russia in every way.

speaker: PENCE
text: When Donald Trump and I observe that, as I've said in Syria, in Iran, in Ukraine, that the small and bullying leader of Russia has been stronger on the world stage than this administration, that's stating painful facts.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's not an endorsement of Vladimir Putin.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's an indictment of the weak and feckless leadership...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: PENCE
text: of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, this is one where we can just kind of go to the tape on it.

speaker: KAINE
text: But Governor Pence said, inarguably, Vladimir Putin is a better leader than President Obama.

speaker: PENCE
text: That is absolutely inaccurate.

speaker: KAINE
text: And -- and -- and I just think a guy who praises...

speaker: PENCE
text: He said he's stronger -- he's been stronger on the world stage.

speaker: KAINE
text: No, he said leader.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if -- and I'll just say this, Governor.

speaker: PENCE
text: You just said better.

speaker: KAINE
text: If you mistake leadership for dictatorship, and you can't tell the difference, a country that's running its economy into the ground...

speaker: PENCE
text: Yeah, here we go.

speaker: PENCE
text: This is the grade school thing again?

speaker: KAINE
text: persecuting journalists...

speaker: PENCE
text: Right, this is grade school.

speaker: KAINE
text: if you can't tell the difference, you shouldn't be commander-in-chief.

speaker: PENCE
text: Yeah.

speaker: KAINE
text: And with Donald Trump -- Donald Trump's sons say that they have all these business dealings with Russia.

speaker: KAINE
text: Those could be disclosed with tax returns, but they refuse to do them.

speaker: KAINE
text: Americans need to worry about whether Donald Trump will be watching out for America's bottom line or his own bottom line.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, what went wrong with the Russia reset?

speaker: KAINE
text: Vladimir Putin.

speaker: KAINE
text: Vladimir Putin is a dictator.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And what would do you differently?

speaker: KAINE
text: Vladimir Putin is a dictator.

speaker: KAINE
text: He's not a leader.

speaker: KAINE
text: Anybody who thinks otherwise doesn't know Russian history and they don't know Vladimir Putin.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton knows exactly who this guy is.

speaker: KAINE
text: John McCain said, I look in his eyes and I see KGB.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Hillary kind of has that same feeling.

speaker: PENCE
text: Right.

speaker: KAINE
text: So how do deal with him?

speaker: KAINE
text: You've got to -- we do have to deal with Russia in a lot of different ways.

speaker: KAINE
text: There are areas where we can cooperate.

speaker: KAINE
text: So it was Hillary Clinton who worked with Russia on the New START Treaty to reduce their nuclear weapons stockpile.

speaker: KAINE
text: It was Hillary Clinton that worked with Russia to get them engaged in a community of nations to stop the Iranian nuclear weapons without firing a shot.

speaker: KAINE
text: She's not going around praising Vladimir Putin as a great guy.

speaker: KAINE
text: But she knows how to sit down at a table and negotiate tough deals.

speaker: KAINE
text: This is a very challenging part of the world, and we ought to have a commander-in-chief who is prepared and done it, rather than somebody who goes around praising Vladimir Putin as a great leader.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right, I'd like to ask now about North Korea, Iran and the threat of nuclear weapons.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: North Korea recently conducted its fifth and most powerful nuclear test.

speaker: PENCE
text: Right.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What specific steps would you take to prevent North Korea from developing a nuclear-armed missile capable of reaching the United States?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, first, we need to -- we need to make a commitment to rebuild our military, including modernizing our nuclear forces.

speaker: PENCE
text: And we also need -- we also need an effective American diplomacy that will marshal the resources of nations in the Asian Pacific Rim to put pressure on North Korea, on Kim Jong-un, to abandon his nuclear ambitions.

speaker: PENCE
text: It has to remain the policy of the United States of America the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, plain and simple.

speaker: PENCE
text: And when Donald Trump is president of the United States, we're -- we're not going to have the -- the kind of posture in the world that has Russia invading Crimea and Ukraine, that has the Chinese building new islands in the South China Sea, that has literally the world, including North Korea, flouting American power.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to -- we're going to go back to the days of peace through strength.

speaker: PENCE
text: But I have to tell you that -- that all this talk about tax returns -- and I get it, you know, you want to keep bringing that up.

speaker: PENCE
text: It must have -- must have...

speaker: KAINE
text: Until he...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: done well in some focus group.

speaker: PENCE
text: But here -- Hillary Clinton and her husband set up a private foundation called the Clinton Foundation.

speaker: PENCE
text: While she was secretary of state, the Clinton Foundation accepted tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments and foreign donors.

speaker: PENCE
text: Now, you all need to know out there, this is basic stuff.

speaker: PENCE
text: Foreign donors, and certainly foreign governments, cannot participate in the American political process.

speaker: PENCE
text: They cannot make financial contributions.

speaker: PENCE
text: But the Clintons figured out a way to create a foundation where foreign governments and foreign donors could donate millions of dollars.

speaker: PENCE
text: And then we found, thanks to the good work of the Associated Press, that more than half her private meetings when she was secretary of state were given to major donors of the Clinton Foundation.

speaker: PENCE
text: When you talk about all these -- all these baseless rumors about Russia and the rest, Hillary Clinton -- you asked the trustworthy question at the very beginning -- the reason...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, your two minutes are up.

speaker: PENCE
text: the reason the American people don't trust Hillary Clinton is because they are looking at the pay to play politics that she operated with the Clinton Foundation through a private server...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, please.

speaker: PENCE
text: while she's secretary of state.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Your two minutes are up, Governor.

speaker: PENCE
text: And they're saying enough is enough.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm going to talk about the foundation, and then I'll talk about North Korea.

speaker: KAINE
text: So, on the foundation.

speaker: KAINE
text: I am glad to talk about the foundation.

speaker: KAINE
text: The Clinton Foundation is one of the highest- rated charities in the world.

speaker: KAINE
text: It provides AIDS drugs to about 11.5 million people.

speaker: KAINE
text: It helps Americans deal with opioid overdoses.

speaker: KAINE
text: It gets higher rankings for its charity than the American Red Cross does.

speaker: KAINE
text: The Clinton foundation does an awful lot of good work.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton as secretary of state took no action to benefit the foundation.

speaker: KAINE
text: The State Department did an investigation, and they concluded that everything Hillary Clinton did as secretary of state was completely in the interest of the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: So the foundation does good work.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Hillary Clinton as secretary of state acted in the interests of the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: But let's compare this now with the Trump organization and the Trump Foundation.

speaker: KAINE
text: The Trump organization is an octopus-like organization with tentacles all over the world whose conflict of interests could only be known if Donald Trump would release his tax returns.

speaker: KAINE
text: He's refused to do it.

speaker: KAINE
text: His sons have said that the organization has a lot of business dealings in Russia.

speaker: KAINE
text: And remember, the Trump organization is not a non-profit.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's putting money into Donald Trump's pockets and into the pockets of his children, whereas the Clinton Foundation is a non- profit and no Clinton family member draws any salary.

speaker: PENCE
text: The Trump Foundation is non-profit.

speaker: KAINE
text: In addition, Donald Trump has a foundation.

speaker: KAINE
text: The foundation was just fined for illegally contributing foundation dollars to a political campaign of a Florida attorney general.

speaker: KAINE
text: They made an illegal contribution, and then they tried to hide it by disguising it to somebody else.

speaker: KAINE
text: And the person they donated to was somebody whose office was charged with investigating Trump University.

speaker: KAINE
text: This is the difference between a foundation that does good work and a secretary of state who acted in accordance with American interest and somebody who is conflicted and doing work around the world and won't share with the American public what he's doing and what those conflicts are.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, I will give you 30 seconds to respond, because I know you want to, but, again, I would remind you both this was about North Korea.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, Thank you.

speaker: PENCE
text: Thank you.

speaker: PENCE
text: The Trump Foundation is a private family foundation.

speaker: PENCE
text: They give virtually every cent in the Trump Foundation to charitable causes.

speaker: KAINE
text: Political contributions?

speaker: PENCE
text: Less than ten cents on the dollar in the Clinton Foundation has gone to charitable causes.

speaker: KAINE
text: A $20,000 portrait of Donald Trump?

speaker: PENCE
text: Less than 10 cents on the dollar of the Clinton Foundation has gone to charitable causes.

speaker: KAINE
text: Ninety percent.

speaker: PENCE
text: It has been a platform for the Clintons to travel the world, to have staff.

speaker: PENCE
text: But honestly, Senator, we would know a lot more about it if Hillary Clinton would just turn over the 33,000 e-mails...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right, let's turn back to North Korea...

speaker: PENCE
text: that she refused to turn over in her private server...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine...

speaker: PENCE
text: and we'd have a much better picture of what the Clinton Foundation was about.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, if you had intelligence that North Korea was about to launch a missile, a nuclear-armed missile capable of reaching the United States, would you take preemptive action?

speaker: KAINE
text: If we -- look, a president should take action to defend the United States against imminent threat.

speaker: KAINE
text: You have to.

speaker: KAINE
text: A president has to do that.

speaker: KAINE
text: Now exactly what action, you would have to determine what your intelligence was, how certain you were of that intelligence, but you would have to take action.

speaker: KAINE
text: You asked the question about how do we deal with a North Korea.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm on the Foreign Relations Committee.

speaker: KAINE
text: We just did an extensive sanctions package against North Korea.

speaker: KAINE
text: And interestingly enough, Elaine, the U.N. followed and did this -- virtually the same package.

speaker: KAINE
text: Often China will use their veto in the Security Council to veto a package like that.

speaker: KAINE
text: They're starting to get worried about North Korea, too.

speaker: KAINE
text: So they actually supported the sanctions package, even though many of the sanctions are against Chinese firms, Chinese financial institutions.

speaker: KAINE
text: So we're working together with China, and we need to.

speaker: KAINE
text: China's another one of those relationships where it's competitive, it's also challenging, and in times like North Korea, we have to be able to cooperate.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary understands that very well.

speaker: KAINE
text: She went once famously to China and stood up at a human rights meeting and looked them in the eye and said, "Women's rights are human rights."

speaker: KAINE
text: They didn't want her to say that, but she did.

speaker: KAINE
text: But she's also worked on a lot of diplomatic and important diplomatic deals with China.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that's what it's going to take.

speaker: KAINE
text: The thing I would worry a little bit about is that Donald Trump owes about $650 million to banks, including the Bank of China.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm not sure he could stand up so tough to the people who have loaned him money.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I'd like to turn to our next segment now.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And in this, I'd like to focus on social issues.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: You have both been open about the role that faith has played in your lives.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Can you discuss in detail a time when you struggled to balance your personal faith and a public policy position?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: Yeah, that's an easy one for me, Elaine.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's an easy one.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm really fortunate.

speaker: KAINE
text: I grew up in a wonderful household with great Irish Catholic parents.

speaker: KAINE
text: My mom and dad are sitting right here.

speaker: KAINE
text: I was educated by Jesuits at Rockhurst High School in Kansas City.

speaker: KAINE
text: My 40th reunion is in 10 days.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I worked with Jesuit missionaries in Honduras, now nearly 35 years ago, and they were the heroes of my life.

speaker: KAINE
text: I try to practice my religion in a very devout way and follow the teachings of my church in my own personal life.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I don't believe in this nation, a First Amendment nation, where we don't raise any religion over the other, and we allow people to worship as they please, that the doctrines of any one religion should be mandated for everyone.

speaker: KAINE
text: For me, the hardest struggle in my faith life was the Catholic Church is against the death penalty and so am I.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I was governor of a state, and the state law said that there was a death penalty for crimes if the jury determined them to be heinous.

speaker: KAINE
text: And so I had to grapple with that.

speaker: KAINE
text: When I was running for governor, I was attacked pretty strongly because of my position on the death penalty.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I looked the voters of Virginia in the eye and said, look, this is my religion.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm not going to change my religious practice to get one vote, but I know how to take an oath and uphold the law.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if you elect me, I will uphold the law.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I was elected, and I did.

speaker: KAINE
text: It was very, very difficult to allow executions to go forward, but in circumstances where I didn't feel like there was a case for clemency, I told Virginia voters I would uphold the law, and I did.

speaker: KAINE
text: That was a real struggle.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I think it is really, really important that those of us who have deep faith lives don't feel that we could just substitute our own views for everybody else in society, regardless of their views.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, it's a wonderful question.

speaker: PENCE
text: And my Christian faith is at the very heart of who I am.

speaker: PENCE
text: I was also raised in a wonderful family of faith.

speaker: PENCE
text: It was a church on Sunday morning and grace before dinner.

speaker: PENCE
text: But my Christian faith became real for me when I made a personal decision for Christ when I was a freshman in college.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I've tried to live that out however imperfectly every day of my life since.

speaker: PENCE
text: And with my wife at my side, we've followed a calling into public service, where we've -- we've tried to -- we've tried to keep faith with the values that we cherish.

speaker: PENCE
text: And with regard to when I struggle, I appreciate, and -- and -- and -- I have a great deal of respect for Senator Kaine's sincere faith.

speaker: PENCE
text: I truly do.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's shared.

speaker: PENCE
text: But for me, I would tell you that for me the sanctity of life proceeds out of the belief that -- that ancient principle that -- where God says before you were formed in the womb, I knew you, and so for my first time in public life, I sought to stand with great compassion for the sanctity of life.

speaker: PENCE
text: The state of Indiana has also sought to make sure that we expand alternatives in health care counseling for women, non-abortion alternatives.

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm also very pleased at the fact we're well on our way in Indiana to becoming the most pro-adoption state in America.

speaker: PENCE
text: I think if you're going to be pro-life, you should -- you should be pro- adoption.

speaker: PENCE
text: But what I can't understand is with Hillary Clinton and now Senator Kaine at her side is to support a practice like partial-birth abortion.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, to hold to the view -- and I know Senator Kaine, you hold pro-life views personally -- but the very idea that a child that is almost born into the world could still have their life taken from them is just anathema to me.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I cannot -- I can't conscience about -- about a party that supports that.

speaker: PENCE
text: Or that -- I know you've historically opposed taxpayer funding of abortion.

speaker: PENCE
text: But Hillary Clinton wants to -- wants to repeal the longstanding provision in the law where we said we wouldn't use taxpayer dollars to fund abortion.

speaker: PENCE
text: So for me, my faith informs my life.

speaker: PENCE
text: I try and spend a little time on my knees every day.

speaker: PENCE
text: But it all for me begins with cherishing the dignity, the worth, the value of every human life.

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, this is a fundamental question, a fundamental question.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I are both people out of religious backgrounds, from Methodist church experience, which was really formative for her as a public servant.

speaker: KAINE
text: But we really feel like you should live fully and with enthusiasm the commands of your faith.

speaker: KAINE
text: But it is not the role of the public servant to mandate that for everybody else.

speaker: KAINE
text: So let's talk about abortion and choice.

speaker: KAINE
text: Let's talk about them.

speaker: KAINE
text: We support Roe v. Wade.

speaker: KAINE
text: We support the constitutional right of American women to consult their own conscience, their own supportive partner, their own minister, but then make their own decision about pregnancy.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's something we trust American women to do that.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we don't think that women should be punished, as Donald Trump said they should, for making the decision to have an abortion.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor Pence wants to repeal Roe v. Wade.

speaker: KAINE
text: He said he wants to put it on the ash heap of history.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we have some young people in the audience who weren't even born when Roe was decided.

speaker: KAINE
text: This is pretty important.

speaker: KAINE
text: Before Roe v. Wade, states could pass criminal laws to do just that, to punish women if they made the choice to terminate a pregnancy.

speaker: KAINE
text: I think you should live your moral values.

speaker: KAINE
text: But the last thing, the very last thing that government should do is have laws that would punish women who make reproductive choices.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that is the fundamental difference between a Clinton-Kaine ticket and a Trump- Pence ticket that wants to punish women who make that choice.

speaker: PENCE
text: No, it's really not.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump and I would never support legislation that punished women who made the heartbreaking choice to end a pregnancy.

speaker: KAINE
text: Then why did Donald Trump say that?

speaker: PENCE
text: We just never would.

speaker: KAINE
text: Why did he say that?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, look, it's -- look, he's not a polished politician like you and Hillary Clinton.

speaker: PENCE
text: And so...

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, I would admit that's not a polished...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: You know, things don't always come out exactly the way he means them.

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, can I say...

speaker: PENCE
text: But I'm telling you what the policy of our administration would be.

speaker: KAINE
text: Great line from the -- great line from the gospel of Matthew.

speaker: KAINE
text: From the fullness of the heart, the mouth speaks.

speaker: PENCE
text: Yeah.

speaker: KAINE
text: When Donald Trump says women should be punished or Mexicans are rapists and criminals...

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm telling you...

speaker: KAINE
text: or John McCain is not a hero, he is showing you who he is.

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, you've whipped out that Mexican thing again.

speaker: PENCE
text: He -- look...

speaker: KAINE
text: Can you defend it?

speaker: PENCE
text: There are criminal aliens in this country, Tim, who have come into this country illegally who are perpetrating violence and taking American lives.

speaker: KAINE
text: You want to -- you want to use a big broad brush against Mexicans on that?

speaker: PENCE
text: He also said and many of them are good people.

speaker: PENCE
text: You keep leaving that out of your quote.

speaker: PENCE
text: And if you want me to go there, I'll go there.

speaker: PENCE
text: But here's -- there is a choice, and it is a choice on life.

speaker: PENCE
text: I couldn't be more proud to be standing with Donald Trump, who's standing for the right to life.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's a principle that -- Senator Kaine -- and I'm very gentle about this, because I really do respect you -- it's a principle that you embrace.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I have appreciated the fact that you've supported the Hyde amendment, which bans the use of taxpayer funding for abortion, in the past, but that's not Hillary Clinton's view.

speaker: PENCE
text: People need to understand, we can come together as a nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: We can create a culture of life.

speaker: PENCE
text: More and more young people today are embracing life because we know we are -- we're better for it.

speaker: PENCE
text: We can -- like Mother Teresa said at that famous national prayer breakfast...

speaker: KAINE
text: This is important --

speaker: PENCE
text: bring the -- let's welcome the children into our world.

speaker: PENCE
text: There are so many families around the country who can't have children.

speaker: PENCE
text: We could improve adoption...

speaker: KAINE
text: But, Governor...

speaker: PENCE
text: so that families that can't have children can adopt more readily those children from crisis pregnancies.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor, why don't you trust women to make this choice for themselves?

speaker: KAINE
text: We can encourage people to support life.

speaker: KAINE
text: Of course we can.

speaker: KAINE
text: But why don't you trust women?

speaker: KAINE
text: Why doesn't Donald Trump trust women to make this choice for themselves?

speaker: KAINE
text: That's what we ought to be doing in public life.

speaker: KAINE
text: Living our lives of faith or motivation with enthusiasm and excitement, convincing other, dialoguing with each other about important moral issues of the day...

speaker: PENCE
text: Because there are...

speaker: KAINE
text: but on fundamental issues of morality, we should let women make their own decisions.

speaker: PENCE
text: Because there is -- a society can be judged by how it deals with its most vulnerable, the aged, the infirm, the disabled, and the unborn.

speaker: PENCE
text: I believe it with all my heart.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I couldn't be more proud to be standing with a pro-life candidate in Donald Trump.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I do have one final question for you both tonight.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: It has been a divisive campaign.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, if your ticket wins, what specifically are you going to do to unify the country and reassure the people who voted against you?

speaker: KAINE
text: That's a really important one.

speaker: KAINE
text: That may be the $64,000 question, because it has been a divisive campaign.

speaker: KAINE
text: And again, Hillary is running a campaign about stronger together, and Donald Trump -- and this is -- this is not directed at this man, except to the extent that he can't defend Donald Trump -- Donald Trump has run a campaign that's been about one insult after the next.

speaker: KAINE
text: But we do have to bring the country together.

speaker: KAINE
text: So here's what we'll do.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton was first lady, then senator for eight years and secretary of state.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I served in the Senate.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I'm really amazed, Elaine, as I talk to Republican senators, how well they regard and respect Hillary Clinton.

speaker: KAINE
text: She was on the Armed Services Committee.

speaker: KAINE
text: She was on other committees.

speaker: KAINE
text: She worked across the aisle when she was first lady to get the CHIP program passed so that 8 million low-income kids have health insurance in this country, including 150,000 in Indiana.

speaker: KAINE
text: She worked across the aisle after 9/11 to get health benefits for the first responders who bravely went into the towers and into the Pentagon.

speaker: KAINE
text: She worked to get benefits for -- TRICARE benefits for National Guard members, including Hoosiers and Virginians in the National Guard.

speaker: KAINE
text: She has a track record of working across the aisle to make things happen.

speaker: KAINE
text: And, you know, Elaine, I have the same track record.

speaker: KAINE
text: I was a governor of Virginia with two Republican houses.

speaker: KAINE
text: And in the Senate, I have good working relationships across the aisle.

speaker: KAINE
text: Because I think it's fine to be a Democrat or Republican or independent, but after Election Day, the goal is work together.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Hillary Clinton has a track record of accomplishment across the aisle that will enable her to do just that when we work with the new Congress in January.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, how will you unify the country if you win?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, thank you, Elaine, and thanks for a great discussion...

speaker: KAINE
text: Absolutely.

speaker: PENCE
text: tonight.

speaker: PENCE
text: Thank you, Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: This is a very challenging time in the life of our nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: Weakened America's place in the world after the leadership of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama on the world stage has been followed by an economy that is truly struggling, stifled by an avalanche of more taxes, more regulation, Obamacare, the war on coal, and the kind of trade deals that have put American workers in the back seat.

speaker: PENCE
text: I think the best way that we can bring people together is through change in Washington, D.C.

speaker: PENCE
text: You know, I served in Washington, D.C., for 12 years in the Congress of the United States.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I served with many Republicans and Democrats, men and women of goodwill.

speaker: PENCE
text: The potential is there to really change the direction of this country, but it's going to take leadership to do it.

speaker: PENCE
text: The American people want to see our nation standing tall on the world stage again.

speaker: PENCE
text: They want to see us supporting our military, rebuilding our military, commanding the respect of the world, and they want to see the American economy off to the races again.

speaker: PENCE
text: They want to see an American comeback.

speaker: PENCE
text: And Donald Trump's entire career has been about building.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's been about -- it's going through hardship just like a businessperson does and finding a way through smarts and ingenuity and resilience to fight forward and -- when Donald Trump becomes president of the United States, we're going to have a stronger America.

speaker: PENCE
text: When you hear him say he wants to make America great again, when we do that, I truly do believe the American people are going to be standing taller.

speaker: PENCE
text: They're going to see that real change can happen after decades of just talking about it.

speaker: PENCE
text: And when that happens, the American people are going to stand tall, stand together, and we'll have the kind of unity that's been missing for way too long.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right, gentlemen, thank you so much.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: This concludes the vice presidential debate.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: My thanks to the candidates, the commission, and to you for watching.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Please tune in this Sunday for the second presidential debate at Washington University in St. Louis and the final debate on October 19th at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: From Farmville, Virginia, I'm Elaine Quijano of CBS News.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Good night.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen the Republican nominee for president, Donald J. Trump, and the Democratic nominee for president, Hillary Clinton.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you very much for being here.

speaker: COOPER
text: We're going to begin with a question from one of the members in our town hall.

speaker: COOPER
text: Each of you will have two minutes to respond to this question.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, you won the coin toss, so you'll go first.

speaker: COOPER
text: Our first question comes from Patrice Brock.

speaker: COOPER
text: Patrice?

speaker: QUESTION
text: Thank you, and good evening.

speaker: QUESTION
text: The last debate could have been rated as MA, mature audiences, per TV parental guidelines.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Knowing that educators assign viewing the presidential debates as students' homework, do you feel you're modeling appropriate and positive behavior for today's youth?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, thank you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Are you a teacher?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, I think that that's a very good question, because I've heard from lots of teachers and parents about some of their concerns about some of the things that are being said and done in this campaign.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think it is very important for us to make clear to our children that our country really is great because we're good.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we are going to respect one another, lift each other up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are going to be looking for ways to celebrate our diversity, and we are going to try to reach out to every boy and girl, as well as every adult, to bring them in to working on behalf of our country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have a very positive and optimistic view about what we can do together.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's why the slogan of my campaign is "Stronger Together," because I think if we work together, if we overcome the divisiveness that sometimes sets Americans against one another, and instead we make some big goals -- and I've set forth some big goals, getting the economy to work for everyone, not just those at the top, making sure that we have the best education system from preschool through college and making it affordable, and so much else.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If we set those goals and we go together to try to achieve them, there's nothing in my opinion that America can't do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So that's why I hope that we will come together in this campaign.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Obviously, I'm hoping to earn your vote, I'm hoping to be elected in November, and I can promise you, I will work with every American.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to be the president for all Americans, regardless of your political beliefs, where you come from, what you look like, your religion.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want us to heal our country and bring it together because that's, I think, the best way for us to get the future that our children and our grandchildren deserve.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, thank you.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, you have two minutes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I actually agree with that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I agree with everything she said.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I began this campaign because I was so tired of seeing such foolish things happen to our country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: This is a great country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: This is a great land.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've gotten to know the people of the country over the last year-and-a-half that I've been doing this as a politician.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I cannot believe I'm saying that about myself, but I guess I have been a politician.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And my whole concept was to make America great again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When I watch the deals being made, when I watch what's happening with some horrible things like Obamacare, where your health insurance and health care is going up by numbers that are astronomical, 68 percent, 59 percent, 71 percent, when I look at the Iran deal and how bad a deal it is for us, it's a one-sided transaction where we're giving back $150 billion to a terrorist state, really, the number one terror state, we've made them a strong country from really a very weak country just three years ago.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When I look at all of the things that I see and all of the potential that our country has, we have such tremendous potential, whether it's in business and trade, where we're doing so badly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Last year, we had almost $800 billion trade deficit.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In other words, trading with other countries.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We had an $800 billion deficit.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's hard to believe.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Inconceivable.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You say who's making these deals?

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going the make great deals.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to have a strong border.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to bring back law and order.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Just today, policemen was shot, two killed.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And this is happening on a weekly basis.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to bring back respect to law enforcement.

speaker: TRUMP
text: At the same time, we have to take care of people on all sides.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We need justice.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I want to do things that haven't been done, including fixing and making our inner cities better for the African-American citizens that are so great, and for the Latinos, Hispanics, and I look forward to doing it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's called make America great again.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: COOPER
text: The question from Patrice was about are you both modeling positive and appropriate behavior for today's youth?

speaker: COOPER
text: We received a lot of questions online, Mr. Trump, about the tape that was released on Friday, as you can imagine.

speaker: COOPER
text: You called what you said locker room banter.

speaker: COOPER
text: You described kissing women without consent, grabbing their genitals.

speaker: COOPER
text: That is sexual assault.

speaker: COOPER
text: You bragged that you have sexually assaulted women.

speaker: COOPER
text: Do you understand that?

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, I didn't say that at all.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think you understood what was -- this was locker room talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm not proud of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I apologize to my family.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I apologize to the American people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Certainly I'm not proud of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But this is locker room talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know, when we have a world where you have ISIS chopping off heads, where you have -- and, frankly, drowning people in steel cages, where you have wars and horrible, horrible sights all over, where you have so many bad things happening, this is like medieval times.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We haven't seen anything like this, the carnage all over the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they look and they see.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Can you imagine the people that are, frankly, doing so well against us with ISIS?

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they look at our country and they see what's going on.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Yes, I'm very embarrassed by it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I hate it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But it's locker room talk, and it's one of those things.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will knock the hell out of ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to defeat ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: ISIS happened a number of years ago in a vacuum that was left because of bad judgment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you, I will take care of ISIS.

speaker: COOPER
text: So, Mr. Trump...

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we should get on to much more important things and much bigger things.

speaker: COOPER
text: Just for the record, though, are you saying that what you said on that bus 11 years ago that you did not actually kiss women without consent or grope women without consent?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have great respect for women.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody has more respect for women than I do.

speaker: COOPER
text: So, for the record, you're saying you never did that?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've said things that, frankly, you hear these things I said.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I was embarrassed by it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I have tremendous respect for women.

speaker: COOPER
text: Have you ever done those things?

speaker: TRUMP
text: And women have respect for me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you: No, I have not.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you that I'm going to make our country safe.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to have borders in our country, which we don't have now.

speaker: TRUMP
text: People are pouring into our country, and they're coming in from the Middle East and other places.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to make America safe again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to make America great again, but we're going to make America safe again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we're going to make America wealthy again, because if you don't do that, it just -- it sounds harsh to say, but we have to build up the wealth of our nation.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Right now, other nations are taking our jobs and they're taking our wealth.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's what I want to talk about.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, do you want to respond?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, like everyone else, I've spent a lot of time thinking over the last 48 hours about what we heard and saw.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, with prior Republican nominees for president, I disagreed with them on politics, policies, principles, but I never questioned their fitness to serve.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Donald Trump is different.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I said starting back in June that he was not fit to be president and commander-in-chief.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And many Republicans and independents have said the same thing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: What we all saw and heard on Friday was Donald talking about women, what he thinks about women, what he does to women.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And he has said that the video doesn't represent who he is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I think it's clear to anyone who heard it that it represents exactly who he is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because we've seen this throughout the campaign.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have seen him insult women.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've seen him rate women on their appearance, ranking them from one to ten.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've seen him embarrass women on TV and on Twitter.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We saw him after the first debate spend nearly a week denigrating a former Miss Universe in the harshest, most personal terms.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, yes, this is who Donald Trump is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But it's not only women, and it's not only this video that raises questions about his fitness to be our president, because he has also targeted immigrants, African- Americans, Latinos, people with disabilities, POWs, Muslims, and so many others.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So this is who Donald Trump is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the question for us, the question our country must answer is that this is not who we are.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's why -- to go back to your question -- I want to send a message -- we all should -- to every boy and girl and, indeed, to the entire world that America already is great, but we are great because we are good, and we will respect one another, and we will work with one another, and we will celebrate our diversity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: These are very important values to me, because this is the America that I know and love.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I can pledge to you tonight that this is the America that I will serve if I'm so fortunate enough to become your president.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And we want to get to some questions from online...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Am I allowed to respond to that?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I assume I am.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Yes, you can respond to that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's just words, folks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's just words.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Those words, I've been hearing them for many years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I heard them when they were running for the Senate in New York, where Hillary was going to bring back jobs to upstate New York and she failed.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've heard them where Hillary is constantly talking about the inner cities of our country, which are a disaster education-wise, jobwise, safety-wise, in every way possible.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm going to help the African-Americans.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm going to help the Latinos, Hispanics.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I am going to help the inner cities.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's done a terrible job for the African-Americans.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She wants their vote, and she does nothing, and then she comes back four years later.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We saw that firsthand when she was United States senator.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She campaigned where the primary part of her campaign...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, Mr. Trump -- I want to get to audience questions and online questions.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So, she's allowed to do that, but I'm not allowed to respond?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You're going to have -- you're going to get to respond right now.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Sounds fair.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: This tape is generating intense interest.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: In just 48 hours, it's become the single most talked about story of the entire 2016 election on Facebook, with millions and millions of people discussing it on the social network.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: As we said a moment ago, we do want to bring in questions from voters around country via social media, and our first stays on this topic.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Jeff from Ohio asks on Facebook, "Trump says the campaign has changed him.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: When did that happen?"

speaker: RADDATZ
text: So, Mr. Trump, let me add to that.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: When you walked off that bus at age 59, were you a different man or did that behavior continue until just recently?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And you have two minutes for this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was locker room talk, as I told you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That was locker room talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm not proud of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I am a person who has great respect for people, for my family, for the people of this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And certainly, I'm not proud of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But that was something that happened.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If you look at Bill Clinton, far worse.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Mine are words, and his was action.

speaker: TRUMP
text: His was what he's done to women.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There's never been anybody in the history politics in this nation that's been so abusive to women.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So you can say any way you want to say it, but Bill Clinton was abusive to women.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hillary Clinton attacked those same women and attacked them viciously.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Four of them here tonight.

speaker: TRUMP
text: One of the women, who is a wonderful woman, at 12 years old, was raped at 12.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Her client she represented got him off, and she's seen laughing on two separate occasions, laughing at the girl who was raped.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Kathy Shelton, that young woman is here with us tonight.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So don't tell me about words.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I am absolutely -- I apologize for those words.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But it is things that people say.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But what President Clinton did, he was impeached, he lost his license to practice law.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He had to pay an $850,000 fine to one of the women.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Paula Jones, who's also here tonight.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you that when Hillary brings up a point like that and she talks about words that I said 11 years ago, I think it's disgraceful, and I think she should be ashamed of herself, if you want to know the truth.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Can we please hold the applause?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, you have two minutes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, first, let me start by saying that so much of what he's just said is not right, but he gets to run his campaign any way he chooses.

speaker: CLINTON
