text: He gets to decide what he wants to talk about.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Instead of answering people's questions, talking about our agenda, laying out the plans that we have that we think can make a better life and a better country, that's his choice.

speaker: CLINTON
text: When I hear something like that, I am reminded of what my friend, Michelle Obama, advised us all: When they go low, you go high.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, look, if this were just about one video, maybe what he's saying tonight would be understandable, but everyone can draw their own conclusions at this point about whether or not the man in the video or the man on the stage respects women.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But he never apologizes for anything to anyone.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He never apologized to Mr. and Mrs. Khan, the Gold Star family whose son, Captain Khan, died in the line of duty in Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And Donald insulted and attacked them for weeks over their religion.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He never apologized to the distinguished federal judge who was born in Indiana, but Donald said he couldn't be trusted to be a judge because his parents were, quote, "Mexican."

speaker: CLINTON
text: He never apologized to the reporter that he mimicked and mocked on national television and our children were watching.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And he never apologized for the racist lie that President Obama was not born in the United States of America.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He owes the president an apology, he owes our country an apology, and he needs to take responsibility for his actions and his words.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, you owe the president an apology, because as you know very well, your campaign, Sidney Blumenthal -- he's another real winner that you have -- and he's the one that got this started, along with your campaign manager, and they were on television just two weeks ago, she was, saying exactly that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So you really owe him an apology.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You're the one that sent the pictures around your campaign, sent the pictures around with President Obama in a certain garb.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That was long before I was ever involved, so you actually owe an apology.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Number two, Michelle Obama.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've gotten to see the commercials that they did on you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I've gotten to see some of the most vicious commercials I've ever seen of Michelle Obama talking about you, Hillary.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So, you talk about friend?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Go back and take a look at those commercials, a race where you lost fair and square, unlike the Bernie Sanders race, where you won, but not fair and square, in my opinion.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And all you have to do is take a look at WikiLeaks and just see what they say about Bernie Sanders and see what Deborah Wasserman Schultz had in mind, because Bernie Sanders, between super-delegates and Deborah Wasserman Schultz, he never had a chance.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I was so surprised to see him sign on with the devil.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But when you talk about apology, I think the one that you should really be apologizing for and the thing that you should be apologizing for are the 33,000 e-mails that you deleted, and that you acid washed, and then the two boxes of e-mails and other things last week that were taken from an office and are now missing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'll tell you what.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I didn't think I'd say this, but I'm going to say it, and I hate to say it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But if I win, I am going to instruct my attorney general to get a special prosecutor to look into your situation, because there has never been so many lies, so much deception.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There has never been anything like it, and we're going to have a special prosecutor.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When I speak, I go out and speak, the people of this country are furious.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In my opinion, the people that have been long-term workers at the FBI are furious.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There has never been anything like this, where e-mails -- and you get a subpoena, you get a subpoena, and after getting the subpoena, you delete 33,000 e-mails, and then you acid wash them or bleach them, as you would say, very expensive process.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So we're going to get a special prosecutor, and we're going to look into it, because you know what?

speaker: TRUMP
text: People have been -- their lives have been destroyed for doing one-fifth of what you've done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it's a disgrace.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And honestly, you ought to be ashamed of yourself.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, I want to follow up on that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I'm going to let you talk about e-mails.

speaker: CLINTON
text: because everything he just said is absolutely false, but I'm not surprised.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Oh, really?

speaker: CLINTON
text: In the first debate...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And really, the audience needs to calm down here.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I told people that it would be impossible to be fact-checking Donald all the time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'd never get to talk about anything I want to do and how we're going to really make lives better for people.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, once again, go to HillaryClinton.com.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have literally Trump -- you can fact check him in real time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Last time at the first debate, we had millions of people fact checking, so I expect we'll have millions more fact checking, because, you know, it is -- it's just awfully good that someone with the temperament of Donald Trump is not in charge of the law in our country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because you'd be in jail.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: COOPER
text: We want to remind the audience to please not talk out loud.

speaker: COOPER
text: Please do not applaud.

speaker: COOPER
text: You're just wasting time.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And, Secretary Clinton, I do want to follow up on e- mails.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You've said your handing of your e-mails was a mistake.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You disagreed with FBI Director James Comey, calling your handling of classified information, quote, "extremely careless."

speaker: RADDATZ
text: The FBI said that there were 110 classified e-mails that were exchanged, eight of which were top secret, and that it was possible hostile actors did gain access to those e-mails.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You don't call that extremely careless?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, Martha, first, let me say -- and I've said before, but I'll repeat it, because I want everyone to hear it -- that was a mistake, and I take responsibility for using a personal e-mail account.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Obviously, if I were to do it over again, I would not.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm not making any excuses.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It was a mistake.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I am very sorry about that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I think it's also important to point out where there are some misleading accusations from critics and others.

speaker: CLINTON
text: After a year-long investigation, there is no evidence that anyone hacked the server I was using and there is no evidence that anyone can point to at all -- anyone who says otherwise has no basis -- that any classified material ended up in the wrong hands.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I take classified materials very seriously and always have.

speaker: CLINTON
text: When I was on the Senate Armed Services Committee, I was privy to a lot of classified material.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Obviously, as secretary of state, I had some of the most important secrets that we possess, such as going after bin Laden.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I am very committed to taking classified information seriously.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And as I said, there is no evidence that any classified information ended up in the wrong hands.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: OK, we're going to move on.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And yet she didn't know the word -- the letter C on a document.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Right?

speaker: TRUMP
text: She didn't even know what that word -- what that letter meant.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know, it's amazing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm watching Hillary go over facts.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she's going after fact after fact, and she's lying again, because she said she -- you know, what she did with the e-mail was fine.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You think it was fine to delete 33,000 e-mails?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think so.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She said the 33,000 e-mails had to do with her daughter's wedding, number one, and a yoga class.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, maybe we'll give three or three or four or five or something.

speaker: TRUMP
text: 33,000 e-mails deleted, and now she's saying there wasn't anything wrong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And more importantly, that was after getting a subpoena.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That wasn't before.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That was after.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She got it from the United States Congress.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'll be honest, I am so disappointed in congressmen, including Republicans, for allowing this to happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Our Justice Department, where our husband goes on to the back of a airplane for 39 minutes, talks to the attorney general days before a ruling is going to be made on her case.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But for you to say that there was nothing wrong with you deleting 39,000 e-mails, again, you should be ashamed of yourself.

speaker: TRUMP
text: What you did -- and this is after getting a subpoena from the United States Congress.

speaker: COOPER
text: We have to move on.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You did that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wait a minute.

speaker: TRUMP
text: One second.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, you can respond, and then we got to move on.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We want to give the audience a chance.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If you did that in the private sector, you'd be put in jail, let alone after getting a subpoena from the United States Congress.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, you can respond.

speaker: COOPER
text: Then we have to move on to an audience question.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look, it's just not true.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so please, go to...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Oh, you didn't delete them?

speaker: COOPER
text: Allow her to respond, please.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It was personal e-mails, not official.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Yeah.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Not -- well, we turned over 35,000, so...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Oh, yeah.

speaker: TRUMP
text: What about the other 15,000?

speaker: COOPER
text: Please allow her to respond.

speaker: COOPER
text: She didn't talk while you talked.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, that's true, I didn't.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because you have nothing to say.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I didn't in the first debate, and I'm going to try not to in this debate, because I'd like to get to the questions that the people have brought here tonight to talk to us about.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Get off this question.

speaker: CLINTON
text: OK, Donald.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know you're into big diversion tonight, anything to avoid talking about your campaign and the way it's exploding and the way Republicans are leaving you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But let's at least focus...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let's see what happens...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: COOPER
text: Allow her to respond.

speaker: CLINTON
text: on some of the issues that people care about tonight.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Let's get to their questions.

speaker: COOPER
text: We have a question here from Ken Karpowicz.

speaker: COOPER
text: He has a question about health care.

speaker: COOPER
text: Ken?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'd like to know, Anderson, why aren't you bringing up the e-mails?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'd like to know.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why aren't you bringing...

speaker: COOPER
text: We brought up the e-mails.

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, it hasn't.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It hasn't.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it hasn't been finished at all.

speaker: COOPER
text: Ken Karpowicz has a question.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's nice to -- one on three.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Thank you.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Affordable Care Act, known as Obamacare, it is not affordable.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Premiums have gone up.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Deductibles have gone up.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Copays have gone up.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Prescriptions have gone up.

speaker: QUESTION
text: And the coverage has gone down.

speaker: QUESTION
text: What will you do to bring the cost down and make coverage better?

speaker: COOPER
text: That first one goes to Secretary Clinton, because you started out the last one to the audience.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If he wants to start, he can start.

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, go ahead, Donald.

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, I'm a gentlemen, Hillary.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Go ahead.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I think Donald was about to say he's going to solve it by repealing it and getting rid of the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I'm going to fix it, because I agree with you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Premiums have gotten too high.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Copays, deductibles, prescription drug costs, and I've laid out a series of actions that we can take to try to get those costs down.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But here's what I don't want people to forget when we're talking about reining in the costs, which has to be the highest priority of the next president, when the Affordable Care Act passed, it wasn't just that 20 million got insurance who didn't have it before.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But that in and of itself was a good thing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I meet these people all the time, and they tell me what a difference having that insurance meant to them and their families.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But everybody else, the 170 million of us who get health insurance through our employees got big benefits.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number one, insurance companies can't deny you coverage because of a pre-existing condition.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number two, no lifetime limits, which is a big deal if you have serious health problems.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number three, women can't be charged more than men for our health insurance, which is the way it used to be before the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number four, if you're under 26, and your parents have a policy, you can be on that policy until the age of 26, something that didn't happen before.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I want very much to save what works and is good about the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we've got to get costs down.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've got to provide additional help to small businesses so that they can afford to provide health insurance.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But if we repeal it, as Donald has proposed, and start over again, all of those benefits I just mentioned are lost to everybody, not just people who get their health insurance on the exchange.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And then we would have to start all over again.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Right now, we are at 90 percent health insurance coverage.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's the highest we've ever been in our country.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, your time is up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I want us to get to 100 percent, but get costs down and keep quality up.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, you have two minutes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It is such a great question and it's maybe the question I get almost more than anything else, outside of defense.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Obamacare is a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We all know it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's going up at numbers that nobody's ever seen worldwide.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody's ever seen numbers like this for health care.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's only getting worse.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In '17, it implodes by itself.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Their method of fixing it is to go back and ask Congress for more money, more and more money.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have right now almost $20 trillion in debt.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Obamacare will never work.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's very bad, very bad health insurance.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Far too expensive.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And not only expensive for the person that has it, unbelievably expensive for our country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's going to be one of the biggest line items very shortly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to repeal it and replace it with something absolutely much less expensive and something that works, where your plan can actually be tailored.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to get rid of the lines around the state, artificial lines, where we stop insurance companies from coming in and competing, because they want -- and President Obama and whoever was working on it -- they want to leave those lines, because that gives the insurance companies essentially monopolies.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We want competition.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You will have the finest health care plan there is.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She wants to go to a single-payer plan, which would be a disaster, somewhat similar to Canada.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And if you haven't noticed the Canadians, when they need a big operation, when something happens, they come into the United States in many cases because their system is so slow.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's catastrophic in certain ways.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she wants to go to single payer, which means the government basically rules everything.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hillary Clinton has been after this for years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Obamacare was the first step.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Obamacare is a total disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And not only are your rates going up by numbers that nobody's ever believed, but your deductibles are going up, so that unless you get hit by a truck, you're never going to be able to use it.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, your time...

speaker: TRUMP
text: It is a disastrous plan, and it has to be repealed and replaced.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, let me follow up with you.

speaker: COOPER
text: Your husband called Obamacare, quote, "the craziest thing in the world," saying that small-business owners are getting killed as premiums double, coverage is cut in half.

speaker: COOPER
text: Was he mistaken or was the mistake simply telling the truth?

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, I mean, he clarified what he meant.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it's very clear.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look, we are in a situation in our country where if we were to start all over again, we might come up with a different system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we have an employer-based system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's where the vast majority of people get their health care.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the Affordable Care Act was meant to try to fill the gap between people who were too poor and couldn't put together any resources to afford health care, namely people on Medicaid.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Obviously, Medicare, which is a single-payer system, which takes care of our elderly and does a great job doing it, by the way, and then all of the people who were employed, but people who were working but didn't have the money to afford insurance and didn't have anybody, an employer or anybody else, to help them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That was the slot that the Obamacare approach was to take.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And like I say, 20 million people now have health insurance.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So if we just rip it up and throw it away, what Donald's not telling you is we just turn it back to the insurance companies the way it used to be, and that means the insurance companies...

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: CLINTON
text: get to do pretty much whatever they want, including saying, look, I'm sorry, you've got diabetes, you had cancer, your child has asthma...

speaker: COOPER
text: Your time is up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: you may not be able to have insurance because you can't afford it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So let's fix what's broken about it, but let's not throw it away and give it all back to the insurance companies and the drug companies.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's not going to work.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, let me follow up on this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I just want -- just one thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, Hillary, everything's broken about it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Everything.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Number two, Bernie Sanders said that Hillary Clinton has very bad judgment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: This is a perfect example of it, trying to save Obamacare, which is a disaster.

speaker: COOPER
text: You've said you want to end Obamacare...

speaker: TRUMP
text: By the way...

speaker: COOPER
text: You've said you want to end Obamacare.

speaker: COOPER
text: You've also said you want to make coverage accessible for people with pre-existing conditions.

speaker: COOPER
text: How do you force insurance companies to do that if you're no longer mandating that every American get insurance?

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to be able to.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You're going to have plans...

speaker: COOPER
text: What does that mean?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I'll tell you what it means.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You're going to have plans that are so good, because we're going to have so much competition in the insurance industry.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Once we break out -- once we break out the lines and allow the competition to come...

speaker: COOPER
text: Are you going -- are you going to have a mandate that Americans have to have health insurance?

speaker: TRUMP
text: President Obama -- Anderson, excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: President Obama, by keeping those lines, the boundary lines around each state, it was almost gone until just very toward the end of the passage of Obamacare, which, by the way, was a fraud.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know that, because Jonathan Gruber, the architect of Obamacare, was said -- he said it was a great lie, it was a big lie.

speaker: TRUMP
text: President Obama said you keep your doctor, you keep your plan.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The whole thing was a fraud, and it doesn't work.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But when we get rid of those lines, you will have competition, and we will be able to keep pre-existing, we'll also be able to help people that can't get -- don't have money because we are going to have people protected.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Republicans feel this way, believe it or not, and strongly this way.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to block grant into the states.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to block grant into Medicaid into the states...

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: so that we will be able to take care of people without the necessary funds to take care of themselves.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We now go to Gorbah Hamed with a question for both candidates.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Hi.

speaker: QUESTION
text: There are 3.3 million Muslims in the United States, and I'm one of them.

speaker: QUESTION
text: You've mentioned working with Muslim nations, but with Islamophobia on the rise, how will you help people like me deal with the consequences of being labeled as a threat to the country after the election is over?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, you're first.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, you're right about Islamophobia, and that's a shame.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But one thing we have to do is we have to make sure that -- because there is a problem.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, whether we like it or not, and we could be very politically correct, but whether we like it or not, there is a problem.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have to be sure that Muslims come in and report when they see something going on.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When they see hatred going on, they have to report it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As an example, in San Bernardino, many people saw the bombs all over the apartment of the two people that killed 14 and wounded many, many people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Horribly wounded.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They'll never be the same.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Muslims have to report the problems when they see them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And, you know, there's always a reason for everything.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If they don't do that, it's a very difficult situation for our country, because you look at Orlando and you look at San Bernardino and you look at the World Trade Center.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Go outside.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look at Paris.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look at that horrible -- these are radical Islamic terrorists.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she won't even mention the word and nor will President Obama.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He won't use the term "radical Islamic terrorism."

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, to solve a problem, you have to be able to state what the problem is or at least say the name.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She won't say the name and President Obama won't say the name.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But the name is there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's radical Islamic terror.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And before you solve it, you have to say the name.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, thank you for asking your question.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I've heard this question from a lot of Muslim-Americans across our country, because, unfortunately, there's been a lot of very divisive, dark things said about Muslims.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And even someone like Captain Khan, the young man who sacrificed himself defending our country in the United States Army, has been subject to attack by Donald.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to say just a couple of things.

speaker: CLINTON
text: First, we've had Muslims in America since George Washington.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we've had many successful Muslims.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We just lost a particular well-known one with Muhammad Ali.

speaker: CLINTON
text: My vision of America is an America where everyone has a place, if you're willing to work hard, you do your part, you contribute to the community.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's what America is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's what we want America to be for our children and our grandchildren.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's also very short-sighted and even dangerous to be engaging in the kind of demagogic rhetoric that Donald has about Muslims.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need American Muslims to be part of our eyes and ears on our front lines.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've worked with a lot of different Muslim groups around America.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've met with a lot of them, and I've heard how important it is for them to feel that they are wanted and included and part of our country, part of our homeland security, and that's what I want to see.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's also important I intend to defeat ISIS, to do so in a coalition with majority Muslim nations.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Right now, a lot of those nations are hearing what Donald says and wondering, why should we cooperate with the Americans?

speaker: CLINTON
text: And this is a gift to ISIS and the terrorists, violent jihadist terrorists.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are not at war with Islam.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it is a mistake and it plays into the hands of the terrorists to act as though we are.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I want a country where citizens like you and your family are just as welcome as anyone else.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, in December, you said this.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Donald J. Trump is calling for a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States until our country's representatives can figure out what the hell is going on.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We have no choice.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We have no choice.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Your running mate said this week that the Muslim ban is no longer your position.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Is that correct?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And if it is, was it a mistake to have a religious test?

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, Captain Khan is an American hero, and if I were president at that time, he would be alive today, because unlike her, who voted for the war without knowing what she was doing, I would not have had our people in Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Iraq was disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So he would have been alive today.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The Muslim ban is something that in some form has morphed into a extreme vetting from certain areas of the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hillary Clinton wants to allow hundreds of thousands -- excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Excuse me..

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And why did it morph into that?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: No, did you -- no, answer the question.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Do you still believe...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why don't you interrupt her?

speaker: TRUMP
text: You interrupt me all the time.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why don't you interrupt her?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Would you please explain whether or not the Muslim ban still stands?

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's called extreme vetting.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are going to areas like Syria where they're coming in by the tens of thousands because of Barack Obama.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Hillary Clinton wants to allow a 550 percent increase over Obama.

speaker: TRUMP
text: People are coming into our country like we have no idea who they are, where they are from, what their feelings about our country is, and she wants 550 percent more.

speaker: TRUMP
text: This is going to be the great Trojan horse of all time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have enough problems in this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I believe in building safe zones.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I believe in having other people pay for them, as an example, the Gulf states, who are not carrying their weight, but they have nothing but money, and take care of people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I don't want to have, with all the problems this country has and all of the problems that you see going on, hundreds of thousands of people coming in from Syria when we know nothing about them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We know nothing about their values and we know nothing about their love for our country.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And, Secretary Clinton, let me ask you about that, because you have asked for an increase from 10,000 to 65,000 Syrian refugees.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We know you want tougher vetting.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: That's not a perfect system.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: So why take the risk of having those refugees come into the country?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, first of all, I will not let anyone into our country that I think poses a risk to us.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But there are a lot of refugees, women and children -- think of that picture we all saw of that 4-year-old boy with the blood on his forehead because he'd been bombed by the Russian and Syrian air forces.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There are children suffering in this catastrophic war, largely, I believe, because of Russian aggression.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we need to do our part.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We by no means are carrying anywhere near the load that Europe and others are.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we will have vetting that is as tough as it needs to be from our professionals, our intelligence experts and others.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But it is important for us as a policy, you know, not to say, as Donald has said, we're going to ban people based on a religion.

speaker: CLINTON
text: How do you do that?

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are a country founded on religious freedom and liberty.

speaker: CLINTON
text: How do we do what he has advocated without causing great distress within our own county?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Are we going to have religious tests when people fly into our country?

speaker: CLINTON
text: And how do we expect to be able to implement those?

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I thought that what he said was extremely unwise and even dangerous.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And indeed, you can look at the propaganda on a lot of the terrorists sites, and what Donald Trump says about Muslims is used to recruit fighters, because they want to create a war between us.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the final thing I would say, this is the 10th or 12th time that he's denied being for the war in Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have it on tape.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The entire press corps has looked at it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's been debunked, but it never stops him from saying whatever he wants to say.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's not been debunked.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, please...

speaker: TRUMP
text: That has not been debunked.

speaker: CLINTON
text: go to HillaryClinton.com and you can see it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was against -- I was against the war in Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Has not been debunked.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you voted for it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you shouldn't have.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I just want to say...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: There's been lots of fact-checking on that.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I'd like to move on to an online question...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She just went about 25 seconds over her time.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: She did not.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Could I just respond to this, please?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Very quickly, please.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hillary Clinton, in terms of having people come into our country, we have many criminal illegal aliens.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When we want to send them back to their country, their country says we don't want them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In some cases, they're murderers, drug lords, drug problems.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they don't want them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Hillary Clinton, when she was secretary of state, said that's OK, we can't force it into their country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me tell you, I'm going to force them right back into their country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're murderers and some very bad people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you very strongly, when Bernie Sanders said she had bad judgment, she has really bad judgment, because we are letting people into this country that are going to cause problems and crime like you've never seen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're also letting drugs pour through our southern border at a record clip.

speaker: TRUMP
text: At a record clip.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it shouldn't be allowed to happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: ICE just endorsed me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They've never endorsed a presidential candidate.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The Border Patrol agents, 16,500, just recently endorsed me, and they endorsed me because I understand the border.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She wants amnesty for everybody.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Come right in.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Come right over.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's a horrible thing she's doing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's got bad judgment, and honestly, so bad that she should never be president of the United States.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That I can tell you.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I want to move on.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: This next question from the public through the Bipartisan Open Debate Coalition's online forum, where Americans submitted questions that generated millions of votes.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: This question involves WikiLeaks release of purported excerpts of Secretary Clinton's paid speeches, which she has refused to release, and one line in particular, in which you, Secretary Clinton, purportedly say you need both a public and private position on certain issues.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: So, Tu (ph), from Virginia asks, is it OK for politicians to be two-faced?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Is it acceptable for a politician to have a private stance on issues?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, your two minutes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, right.

speaker: CLINTON
text: As I recall, that was something I said about Abraham Lincoln after having seen the wonderful Steven Spielberg movie called "Lincoln."

speaker: CLINTON
text: It was a master class watching President Lincoln get the Congress to approve the 13th Amendment.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It was principled, and it was strategic.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I was making the point that it is hard sometimes to get the Congress to do what you want to do and you have to keep working at it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, yes, President Lincoln was trying to convince some people, he used some arguments, convincing other people, he used other arguments.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That was a great -- I thought a great display of presidential leadership.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But, you know, let's talk about what's really going on here, Martha, because our intelligence community just came out and said in the last few days that the Kremlin, meaning Putin and the Russian government, are directing the attacks, the hacking on American accounts to influence our election.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And WikiLeaks is part of that, as are other sites where the Russians hack information, we don't even know if it's accurate information, and then they put it out.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have never in the history of our country been in a situation where an adversary, a foreign power, is working so hard to influence the outcome of the election.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And believe me, they're not doing it to get me elected.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They're doing it to try to influence the election for Donald Trump.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, maybe because he has praised Putin, maybe because he says he agrees with a lot of what Putin wants to do, maybe because he wants to do business in Moscow, I don't know the reasons.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we deserve answers.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we should demand that Donald release all of his tax returns so that people can see what are the entanglements and the financial relationships that he has...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We're going to get to that later.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, you're out of time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: with the Russians and other foreign powers.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I think I should respond, because -- so ridiculous.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, now she's blaming -- she got caught in a total lie.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Her papers went out to all her friends at the banks, Goldman Sachs and everybody else, and she said things -- WikiLeaks that just came out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she lied.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now she's blaming the lie on the late, great Abraham Lincoln.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's one that I haven't...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK, Honest Abe, Honest Abe never lied.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's the good thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's the big difference between Abraham Lincoln and you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's a big, big difference.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're talking about some difference.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But as far as other elements of what she was saying, I don't know Putin.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think it would be great if we got along with Russia because we could fight ISIS together, as an example.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I don't know Putin.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I notice, anytime anything wrong happens, they like to say the Russians are -- she doesn't know if it's the Russians doing the hacking.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Maybe there is no hacking.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But they always blame Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And the reason they blame Russia because they think they're trying to tarnish me with Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I know nothing about Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I know -- I know about Russia, but I know nothing about the inner workings of Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't deal there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have no businesses there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have no loans from Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have a very, very great balance sheet, so great that when I did the Old Post Office on Pennsylvania Avenue, the United States government, because of my balance sheet, which they actually know very well, chose me to do the Old Post Office, between the White House and Congress, chose me to do the Old Post Office.

speaker: TRUMP
text: One of the primary area things, in fact, perhaps the primary thing was balance sheet.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I have no loans with Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You could go to the United States government, and they would probably tell you that, because they know my sheet very well in order to get that development I had to have.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, the taxes are a very simple thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As soon as I have -- first of all, I pay hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Many of her friends took bigger deductions.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Warren Buffett took a massive deduction.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Soros, who's a friend of hers, took a massive deduction.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Many of the people that are giving her all this money that she can do many more commercials than me gave her -- took massive deductions.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I pay hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But -- but as soon as my routine audit is finished, I'll release my returns.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'll be very proud to.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're actually quite great.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: COOPER
text: We want to turn, actually, to the topic of taxes.

speaker: COOPER
text: We have a question from Spencer Maass.

speaker: COOPER
text: Spencer?

speaker: QUESTION
text: Good evening.

speaker: QUESTION
text: My question is, what specific tax provisions will you change to ensure the wealthiest Americans pay their fair share in taxes?

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, you have two minutes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, one thing I'd do is get rid of carried interest.

speaker: TRUMP
text: One of the greatest provisions for people like me, to be honest with you, I give up a lot when I run, because I knock out the tax code.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she could have done this years ago, by the way.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's a United States -- she was a United States senator.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She complains that Donald Trump took advantage of the tax code.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, why didn't she change it?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why didn't you change it when you were a senator?

speaker: TRUMP
text: The reason you didn't is that all your friends take the same advantage that I do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You have provisions in the tax code that, frankly, we could change.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you wouldn't change it, because all of these people gave you the money so you can take negative ads on Donald Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But -- and I say that about a lot of things.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know, I've heard Hillary complaining about so many different things over the years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I wish you would have done this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she's been there for 30 years she's been doing this stuff.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She never changed.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she never will change.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She never will change.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're getting rid of carried interest provisions.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm lowering taxes actually, because I think it's so important for corporations, because we have corporations leaving -- massive corporations and little ones, little ones can't form.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're getting rid of regulations which goes hand in hand with the lowering of the taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But we're bringing the tax rate down from 35 percent to 15 percent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're cutting taxes for the middle class.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you, we are cutting them big league for the middle class.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you, Hillary Clinton is raising your taxes, folks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You can look at me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's raising your taxes really high.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And what that's going to do is a disaster for the country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she is raising your taxes and I'm lowering your taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That in itself is a big difference.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are going to be thriving again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have no growth in this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There's no growth.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If China has a GDP of 7 percent, it's like a national catastrophe.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're down at 1 percent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's, like, no growth.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we're going lower, in my opinion.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And a lot of it has to do with the fact that our taxes are so high, just about the highest in the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'm bringing them down to one of the lower in the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think it's so important -- one of the most important things we can do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she is raising everybody's taxes massively.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, you have two minutes.

speaker: COOPER
text: The question was, what specific tax provisions will you change to ensure the wealthiest Americans pay their fair share of taxes?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, everything you've heard just now from Donald is not true.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm sorry I have to keep saying this, but he lives in an alternative reality.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it is sort of amusing to hear somebody who hasn't paid federal income taxes in maybe 20 years talking about what he's going to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I'll tell you what he's going to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: His plan will give the wealthy and corporations the biggest tax cuts they've ever had, more than the Bush tax cuts by at least a factor of two.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Donald always takes care of Donald and people like Donald, and this would be a massive gift.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, indeed, the way that he talks about his tax cuts would end up raising taxes on middle-class families, millions of middle-class families.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, here's what I want to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have said nobody who makes less than $250,000 a year -- and that's the vast majority of Americans as you know -- will have their taxes raised, because I think we've got to go where the money is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the money is with people who have taken advantage of every single break in the tax code.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, yes, when I was a senator, I did vote to close corporate loopholes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I voted to close, I think, one of the loopholes he took advantage of when he claimed a billion-dollar loss that enabled him to avoid paying taxes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to have a tax on people who are making a million dollars.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's called the Buffett rule.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, Warren Buffett is the one who's gone out and said somebody like him should not be paying a lower tax rate than his secretary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to have a surcharge on incomes above $5 million.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to make up for lost times, because I want to invest in you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to invest in hard-working families.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think it's been unfortunate, but it's happened, that since the Great Recession, the gains have all gone to the top.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we need to reverse that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: People like Donald, who paid zero in taxes, zero for our vets, zero for our military, zero for health and education, that is wrong.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we're going to make sure that nobody, no corporation, and no individual can get away without paying his fair share to support our country.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you.

speaker: COOPER
text: I want to give you -- Mr. Trump, I want to give you the chance to respond.

speaker: COOPER
text: I just wanted to tell our viewers what she's referring to.

speaker: COOPER
text: In the last month, taxes were the number-one issue on Facebook for the first time in the campaign.

speaker: COOPER
text: The New York Times published three pages of your 1995 tax returns.

speaker: COOPER
text: They show you claimed a $916 million loss, which means you could have avoided paying personal federal income taxes for years.

speaker: COOPER
text: You've said you pay state taxes, employee taxes, real estate taxes, property taxes.

speaker: COOPER
text: You have not answered, though, a simple question.

speaker: COOPER
text: Did you use that $916 million loss to avoid paying personal federal income taxes for years?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Of course I do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Of course I do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And so do all of her donors, or most of her donors.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I know many of her donors.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Her donors took massive tax write-offs.

speaker: COOPER
text: So have you (inaudible) personal federal income tax?

speaker: TRUMP
text: A lot of my -- excuse me, Anderson -- a lot of my write- off was depreciation and other things that Hillary as a senator allowed.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she'll always allow it, because the people that give her all this money, they want it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's why.

speaker: TRUMP
text: See, I understand the tax code better than anybody that's ever run for president.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hillary Clinton -- and it's extremely complex -- Hillary Clinton has friends that want all of these provisions, including they want the carried interest provision, which is very important to Wall Street people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But they really want the carried interest provision, which I believe Hillary's leaving.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Very interesting why she's leaving carried interest.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I will tell you that, number one, I pay tremendous numbers of taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I absolutely used it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And so did Warren Buffett and so did George Soros and so did many of the other people that Hillary is getting money from.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, I won't mention their names, because they're rich, but they're not famous.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So we won't make them famous.

speaker: COOPER
text: So can you -- can you say how many years you have avoided paying personal federal income taxes?

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, but I pay tax, and I pay federal tax, too.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I have a write-off, a lot of it's depreciation, which is a wonderful charge.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I love depreciation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know, she's given it to us.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hey, if she had a problem -- for 30 years she's been doing this, Anderson.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I say it all the time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She talks about health care.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why didn't she do something about it?

speaker: TRUMP
text: She talks about taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why didn't she do something about it?

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't do anything about anything other than talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: With her, it's all talk and no action.

speaker: COOPER
text: In the past...

speaker: TRUMP
text: And, again, Bernie Sanders, it's really bad judgment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She has made bad judgment not only on taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's made bad judgments on Libya, on Syria, on Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, her and Obama, whether you like it or not, the way they got out of Iraq, the vacuum they've left, that's why ISIS formed in the first place.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They started from that little area, and now they're in 32 different nations, Hillary.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Congratulations.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Great job.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary -- I want you to be able to respond, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, here we go again.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've been in favor of getting rid of carried interest for years, starting when I was a senator from New York.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But that's not the point here.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why didn't you do it?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why didn't you do it?

speaker: COOPER
text: Allow her to respond.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because I was a senator with a Republican president.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Oh, really?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I will be the president and we will get it done.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's exactly right.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You could have done it, if you were an effective -- if you were an effective senator, you could have done it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If you were an effective senator, you could have done it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you were not an effective senator.

speaker: COOPER
text: Please allow her to respond.

speaker: COOPER
text: She didn't interrupt you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, under our Constitution, presidents have something called veto power.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look, he has now said repeatedly, "30 years this and 30 years that."

speaker: CLINTON
text: So let me talk about my 30 years in public service.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm very glad to do so.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Eight million kids every year have health insurance, because when I was first lady I worked with Democrats and Republicans to create the Children's Health Insurance Program.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Hundreds of thousands of kids now have a chance to be adopted because I worked to change our adoption and foster care system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: After 9/11, I went to work with Republican mayor, governor and president to rebuild New York and to get health care for our first responders who were suffering because they had run toward danger and gotten sickened by it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Hundreds of thousands of National Guard and Reserve members have health care because of work that I did, and children have safer medicines because I was able to pass a law that required the dosing to be more carefully done.

speaker: CLINTON
text: When I was secretary of state, I went around the world advocating for our country, but also advocating for women's rights, to make sure that women had a decent chance to have a better life and negotiated a treaty with Russia to lower nuclear weapons.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Four hundred pieces of legislation have my name on it as a sponsor or cosponsor when I was a senator for eight years.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I worked very hard and was very proud to be re-elected in New York by an even bigger margin than I had been elected the first time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And as president, I will take that work, that bipartisan work, that finding common ground, because you have to be able to get along with people to get things done in Washington.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, secretary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've proven that I can, and for 30 years, I've produced results for people.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, secretary.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We're going to move on to Syria.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Both of you have mentioned that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She said a lot of things that were false.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, I think we should be allowed to maybe...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: No, we can -- no, Mr. Trump, we're going to go on.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: This is about the audience.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because she has been a disaster as a senator.

speaker: TRUMP
text: A disaster.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, we're going to move on.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: The heart-breaking video of a 5-year-old Syrian boy named Omran sitting in an ambulance after being pulled from the rubble after an air strike in Aleppo focused the world's attention on the horrors of the war in Syria, with 136 million views on Facebook alone.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: But there are much worse images coming out of Aleppo every day now, where in the past few weeks alone, 400 people have been killed, at least 100 of them children.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Just days ago, the State Department called for a war crimes investigation of the Syrian regime of Bashar al-Assad and its ally, Russia, for their bombardment of Aleppo.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: So this next question comes through social media through Facebook.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Diane from Pennsylvania asks, if you were president, what would you do about Syria and the humanitarian crisis in Aleppo?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Isn't it a lot like the Holocaust when the U.S. waited too long before we helped?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, we will begin with your two minutes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, the situation in Syria is catastrophic.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And every day that goes by, we see the results of the regime by Assad in partnership with the Iranians on the ground, the Russians in the air, bombarding places, in particular Aleppo, where there are hundreds of thousands of people, probably about 250,000 still left.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And there is a determined effort by the Russian air force to destroy Aleppo in order to eliminate the last of the Syrian rebels who are really holding out against the Assad regime.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Russia hasn't paid any attention to ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They're interested in keeping Assad in power.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I, when I was secretary of state, advocated and I advocate today a no-fly zone and safe zones.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need some leverage with the Russians, because they are not going to come to the negotiating table for a diplomatic resolution, unless there is some leverage over them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we have to work more closely with our partners and allies on the ground.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I want to emphasize that what is at stake here is the ambitions and the aggressiveness of Russia.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Russia has decided that it's all in, in Syria.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And they've also decided who they want to see become president of the United States, too, and it's not me.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've stood up to Russia.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've taken on Putin and others, and I would do that as president.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think wherever we can cooperate with Russia, that's fine.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I did as secretary of state.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's how we got a treaty reducing nuclear weapons.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's how we got the sanctions on Iran that put a lid on the Iranian nuclear program without firing a single shot.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I would go to the negotiating table with more leverage than we have now.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I do support the effort to investigate for crimes, war crimes committed by the Syrians and the Russians and try to hold them accountable.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump?

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, she was there as secretary of state with the so-called line in the sand, which...

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, I wasn't.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I was gone.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I hate to interrupt you, but at some point...

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you were in contact -- excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You were...

speaker: CLINTON
text: At some point, we need to do some fact-checking here.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You were in total contact with the White House, and perhaps, sadly, Obama probably still listened to you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think he would be listening to you very much anymore.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Obama draws the line in the sand.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was laughed at all over the world what happened.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, with that being said, she talks tough against Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But our nuclear program has fallen way behind, and they've gone wild with their nuclear program.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Not good.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Our government shouldn't have allowed that to happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Russia is new in terms of nuclear.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are old.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're tired.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're exhausted in terms of nuclear.

speaker: TRUMP
text: A very bad thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, she talks tough, she talks really tough against Putin and against Assad.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She talks in favor of the rebels.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't even know who the rebels are.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know, every time we take rebels, whether it's in Iraq or anywhere else, we're arming people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you know what happens?

speaker: TRUMP
text: They end up being worse than the people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look at what she did in Libya with Gadhafi.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Gadhafi's out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's a mess.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And, by the way, ISIS has a good chunk of their oil.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm sure you probably have heard that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because the fact is, almost everything she's done in foreign policy has been a mistake and it's been a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But if you look at Russia, just take a look at Russia, and look at what they did this week, where I agree, she wasn't there, but possibly she's consulted.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We sign a peace treaty.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Everyone's all excited.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, what Russia did with Assad and, by the way, with Iran, who you made very powerful with the dumbest deal perhaps I've ever seen in the history of deal-making, the Iran deal, with the $150 billion, with the $1.7 billion in cash, which is enough to fill up this room.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But look at that deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Iran now and Russia are now against us.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So she wants to fight.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She wants to fight for rebels.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There's only one problem.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You don't even know who the rebels are.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So what's the purpose?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, Mr. Trump, your two minutes is up.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And one thing I have to say.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Your two minutes is up.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't like Assad at all, but Assad is killing ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Russia is killing ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Iran is killing ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And those three have now lined up because of our weak foreign policy.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, let me repeat the question.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: If you were president...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: what would you do about Syria and the humanitarian crisis in Aleppo?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And I want to remind you what your running mate said.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: He said provocations by Russia need to be met with American strength and that if Russia continues to be involved in air strikes along with the Syrian government forces of Assad, the United States of America should be prepared to use military force to strike the military targets of the Assad regime.

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He and I haven't spoken, and I disagree.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I disagree.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You disagree with your running mate?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think you have to knock out ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Right now, Syria is fighting ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have people that want to fight both at the same time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But Syria is no longer Syria.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Syria is Russia and it's Iran, who she made strong and Kerry and Obama made into a very powerful nation and a very rich nation, very, very quickly, very, very quickly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I believe we have to get ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to worry about ISIS before we can get too much more involved.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She had a chance to do something with Syria.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They had a chance.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that was the line.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she didn't.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: What do you think will happen if Aleppo falls?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think Aleppo is a disaster, humanitarian-wise.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: What do you think will happen if it falls?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think that it basically has fallen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK?

speaker: TRUMP
text: It basically has fallen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me tell you something.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You take a look at Mosul.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The biggest problem I have with the stupidity of our foreign policy, we have Mosul.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They think a lot of the ISIS leaders are in Mosul.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So we have announcements coming out of Washington and coming out of Iraq, we will be attacking Mosul in three weeks or four weeks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, all of these bad leaders from ISIS are leaving Mosul.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why can't they do it quietly?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why can't they do the attack, make it a sneak attack, and after the attack is made, inform the American public that we've knocked out the leaders, we've had a tremendous success?

speaker: TRUMP
text: People leave.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why do they have to say we're going to be attacking Mosul within the next four to six weeks, which is what they're saying?

speaker: TRUMP
text: How stupid is our country?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: There are sometimes reasons the military does that.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Psychological warfare.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I can't think of any.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I can't think of any.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'm pretty good at it.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: It might be to help get civilians out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have General Flynn.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have -- look, I have 200 generals and admirals who endorsed me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have 21 Congressional Medal of Honor recipients who endorsed me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We talk about it all the time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They understand, why can't they do something secretively, where they go in and they knock out the leadership?

speaker: TRUMP
text: How -- why would these people stay there?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've been reading now...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Tell me what your strategy is.

speaker: TRUMP
text: for weeks -- I've been reading now for weeks about Mosul, that it's the harbor of where -- you know, between Raqqa and Mosul, this is where they think the ISIS leaders are.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why would they be saying -- they're not staying there anymore.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're gone.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because everybody's talking about how Iraq, which is us with our leadership, goes in to fight Mosul.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, with these 200 admirals and generals, they can't believe it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All I say is this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: General George Patton, General Douglas MacArthur are spinning in their grave at the stupidity of what we're doing in the Middle East.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I'm going to go to Secretary Clinton.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, you want Assad to go.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You advocated arming rebels, but it looks like that may be too late for Aleppo.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You talk about diplomatic efforts.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Those have failed.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Cease-fires have failed.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Would you introduce the threat of U.S. military force beyond a no-fly zone against the Assad regime to back up diplomacy?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would not use American ground forces in Syria.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think that would be a very serious mistake.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't think American troops should be holding territory, which is what they would have to do as an occupying force.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't think that is a smart strategy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I do think the use of special forces, which we're using, the use of enablers and trainers in Iraq, which has had some positive effects, are very much in our interests, and so I do support what is happening, but let me just...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: But what would you do differently than President Obama is doing?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, Martha, I hope that by the time I -- if I'm fortunate...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Everything.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I hope by the time I am president that we will have pushed ISIS out of Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I do think that there is a good chance that we can take Mosul.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, you know, Donald says he knows more about ISIS than the generals.

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, he doesn't.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There are a lot of very important planning going on, and some of it is to signal to the Sunnis in the area, as well as Kurdish Peshmerga fighters, that we all need to be in this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that takes a lot of planning and preparation.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would go after Baghdadi.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would specifically target Baghdadi, because I think our targeting of Al Qaida leaders -- and I was involved in a lot of those operations, highly classified ones -- made a difference.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I think that could help.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would also consider arming the Kurds.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The Kurds have been our best partners in Syria, as well as Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I know there's a lot of concern about that in some circles, but I think they should have the equipment they need so that Kurdish and Arab fighters on the ground are the principal way that we take Raqqa after pushing ISIS out of Iraq.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you very much.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We're going to move on...

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know what's funny?

speaker: TRUMP
text: She went over a minute over, and you don't stop her.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When I go one second over, it's like a big deal.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You had many answers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's really -- it's really very interesting.

speaker: COOPER
text: We've got a question over here from James Carter.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Carter?

speaker: QUESTION
text: My question is, do you believe you can be a devoted president to all the people in the United States?

speaker: COOPER
text: That question begins for Mr. Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Absolutely.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, she calls our people deplorable, a large group, and irredeemable.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will be a president for all of our people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'll be a president that will turn our inner cities around and will give strength to people and will give economics to people and will bring jobs back.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because NAFTA, signed by her husband, is perhaps the greatest disaster trade deal in the history of the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Not in this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It stripped us of manufacturing jobs.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We lost our jobs.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We lost our money.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We lost our plants.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It is a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And now she wants to sign TPP, even though she says now she's for it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She called it the gold standard.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And by the way, at the last debate, she lied, because it turned out that she did say the gold standard and she said she didn't say it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They actually said that she lied.

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK?

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she lied.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she's lied about a lot of things.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I would be a president for all of the people, African- Americans, the inner cities.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Devastating what's happening to our inner cities.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's been talking about it for years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As usual, she talks about it, nothing happens.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't get it done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Same with the Latino Americans, the Hispanic Americans.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The same exact thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They talk, they don't get it done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You go into the inner cities and -- you see it's 45 percent poverty.

speaker: TRUMP
text: African- Americans now 45 percent poverty in the inner cities.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The education is a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Jobs are essentially nonexistent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, it's -- you know, and I've been saying at big speeches where I have 20,000 and 30,000 people, what do you have to lose?

speaker: TRUMP
text: It can't get any worse.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she's been talking about the inner cities for 25 years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nothing's going to ever happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me tell you, if she's president of the United States, nothing's going to happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's just going to be talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And all of her friends, the taxes we were talking about, and I would just get it by osmosis.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's not doing any me favors.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But by doing all the others' favors, she's doing me favors.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, thank you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I will tell you, she's all talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It doesn't get done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All you have to do is take a look at her Senate run.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Take a look at upstate New York.

speaker: COOPER
text: Your two minutes is up.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, two minutes?

speaker: TRUMP
text: It turned out to be a disaster.

speaker: COOPER
text: You have two minutes, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, 67 percent of the people voted to re-elect me when I ran for my second term, and I was very proud and very humbled by that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Mr. Carter, I have tried my entire life to do what I can to support children and families.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, right out of law school, I went to work for the Children's Defense Fund.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And Donald talks a lot about, you know, the 30 years I've been in public service.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm proud of that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, I started off as a young lawyer working against discrimination against African-American children in schools and in the criminal justice system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I worked to make sure that kids with disabilities could get a public education, something that I care very much about.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have worked with Latinos -- one of my first jobs in politics was down in south Texas registering Latino citizens to be able to vote.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I have a deep devotion, to use your absolutely correct word, to making sure that an every American feels like he or she has a place in our country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think when you look at the letters that I get, a lot of people are worried that maybe they wouldn't have a place in Donald Trump's America.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They write me, and one woman wrote me about her son, Felix.

speaker: CLINTON
text: She adopted him from Ethiopia when he was a toddler.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He's 10 years old now.

speaker: CLINTON
text: This is the only one country he's ever known.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And he listens to Donald on TV and he said to his mother one day, will he send me back to Ethiopia if he gets elected?

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, children listen to what is being said.

speaker: CLINTON
text: To go back to the very, very first question.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And there's a lot of fear -- in fact, teachers and parents are calling it the Trump effect.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Bullying is up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: A lot of people are feeling, you know, uneasy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: A lot of kids are expressing their concerns.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, first and foremost, I will do everything I can to reach out to everybody.

speaker: COOPER
text: Your time, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Democrats, Republicans, independents, people across our country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If you don't vote for me, I still want to be your president.

speaker: COOPER
text: Your two minutes is up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to be the best president I can be for every American.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, your two minutes is up.

speaker: COOPER
text: I want to follow up on something that Donald Trump actually said to you, a comment you made last month.

speaker: COOPER
text: You said that half of Donald Trump's supporters are, quote, "deplorables, racist, sexist, homophobic, xenophobic, Islamophobic."

speaker: COOPER
text: You later said you regretted saying half.

speaker: COOPER
text: You didn't express regret for using the term "deplorables."

speaker: COOPER
text: To Mr. Carter's question, how can you unite a country if you've written off tens of millions of Americans?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, within hours I said that I was sorry about the way I talked about that, because my argument is not with his supporters.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's with him and with the hateful and divisive campaign that he has run, and the inciting of violence at his rallies, and the very brutal kinds of comments about not just women, but all Americans, all kinds of Americans.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And what he has said about African-Americans and Latinos, about Muslims, about POWs, about immigrants, about people with disabilities, he's never apologized for.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so I do think that a lot of the tone and tenor that he has said -- I'm proud of the campaign that Bernie Sanders and I ran.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We ran a campaign based on issues, not insults.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And he is supporting me 100 percent.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because we talked about what we wanted to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We might have had some differences, and we had a lot of debates...

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: TRUMP
text: but we believed that we could make the country better.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I was proud of that.

speaker: COOPER
text: I want to give you a minute to respond.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have a divided nation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have a very divided nation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You look at Charlotte.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You look at Baltimore.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You look at the violence that's taking place in the inner cities, Chicago, you take a look at Washington, D.C.

speaker: TRUMP
